description: Absolutely the worst dining experience ever. I first started coming here in 2001. One of my favorite restaurants ever. Since my last experience the hostess was horrible. She has a chip on her shoulder like we should be serving her. Anything to give us a bad experience, she did it. How they can stay in business with that kind of service is beyond me. Whatever. Good luck. I wish you the best.
author: Tara A.

description:
Ambience was very small and cute, don't recommend for big parties. The wait was around 25-30 minutes, but I came on a Friday so that was expected. 

I ordered the linguini with clams which was very simple and lemony, exactly how I liked it. 

Pricing was typical of a Italian restaurant, not too expensive and not too cheap. 

Service wasn't bad, except the waitress took a little longer than usual to approach our table. 

The only downside of eating here is the parking... Granted, I came on a Friday night, it took 45 minutes to an hour to find parking. 

Overall, the food wasn't bad but I probably won't be coming back only because finding street parking was terrible.
author: Kelly C.

description:
I had really high hopes and it just kind of... sucked.

I ordered the carbonara and it tasted burnt. The pancetta they used was sliced really thin and I guess they burned it all. It wasn't ALL bites that tasted like that, but about 3/4s and it was just one of those times where you're like eh, not worth complaining, just won't enjoy it.

I'm also biased when I know in Italy they use thick pieces of guanchale. Although, this was probably one of the worst carbonaras I've had in the city. 

I also had carpaccio and it was meh, at best.

The linguine with clams was whatever, and same with the tutto mare special. Maybe they needed a little more garlic or something, but everything seemed like it was missing that extra pizazz. 

Maybe it was a bad night.. because I know this place is pretty popular?
author: Angela L.

description:
We were there last night, 2.5 hours before a concert at Nob Hill Masonic. VERY crowded, but we got in in about 15 minutes. Service great. My $22 veal piccata thin and overcooked. Would maybe try again  not when on time constraint and not when so crowded. Everyone nice - but a bit chaotic for me.
Great people watching and lots of dog walkers!
author: Chris E.

description: Very simple, but fabulous Italian. Nothing to over done as far as flavor. Ordered the Carbonara, with chicken and it was quite good. The bread basket was so good, with local sourdough and focaccia was the best I've ever had (must have been the rosemary). The table wine was a white and very complementary to the food.
author: Char R.

description: Truly outstanding food.  Very friendly service and casual atmosphere make this a good destination for families in the San Francisco area to frequent.  We will be back again!
author: M. R.

description: Surprisingly we didn't have to wait on a Friday night. We got the gnocchi and risotto. It was NOM!
author: Tamie J.

description: Wait times on a Saturday night were as expected.....long.  I had the linguini with clams and it was fabulous! The lemon flavor was not overpowering.....just exquisite.  I only gave it four stars because they are so busy and limited on servers.  Although our server was pleasant she could have been more attentive with less tables.  My friend had the Chicken Parmesan and thought the sauce was bland, although overall the dish was acceptable.
author: Kelly K.

description:
Still amazing. One of my favorite places in SF to get fresh, homemade pasta. Spaghetti alla Carbonara is out of this world; rich flavors, salt of the pancetta perfectly balanced with the hearty garlic. NOM FACTOR. I also love their pesto. It's a simple dish but add chicken, MMMmmmm

Also I love their staff; the hostess is so friendly and sweet, servers are always very friendly and make my dining experience enjoyable.

I never liked their bruschetta, too try and the tomatoes aren't amazing unless they are in season but some people seem to love it!
author: Meredith M.

description: We loved our delicious lunch & the friendly staff. Worth the wait since they don't take reservations. Cozy & family owned for thirty years. Almost afraid to give this review since they are already so popular but have to since they made us so happy.
author: Mary D.

description:
A small intimate locals dinning place.  Fabulous original Italian food.  Get there early to beat locals. Very short walk from Mark Hopkins and Fairmont hotels.
Dave H.
Orange, CA.
author: Dave H.

description:
This is the second time my boyfriend and I have come here for dinner. We are from San Diego and were determined to find this place again. This place is so adorable and has such a romantic atmosphere. The first thing we noticed was Robin, our waitress who happened to be the same one from our first visit. She is amazing!! 

The food here is outstanding. Try the fettuccine al pesto. It's amazing with the pine nuts.
author: Mariela M.

description:
Last one in for dinner after the theatre and we were treated like family. The smells !!!, the food !!!, the staff !!! Wonderful wonderful..
Can't wait to go back.
author: Mark L.

description:
of course it'll be expensive - it's an italian restaurant in the peak of nob hill. it was still really good! i went here with a couple friends that i hadn't seen in a while, and they sat us in a cute, intimate window booth and gave us fresh baked bread while we waited.we had to wait a few minutes for the table (party of 3 around 7 pm) which was expected, and they brought us water outside while we waited.  the service was attentive - no complaints!
i got a vegetarian pasta dish that i have forgotten the name of.. there were no left overs so obviously no complaints. my friends loved their dishes too - one of them got the risotto special off the house special list and we all loved it. 
we also got the flan, which could have been iffy - but it was amazing!! just so expensive and hard to get to ):
author: Emma G.

description: This place is delicious!! Their gnocci was amazing. My gf and I shared the gnocci and the veal. She's a big veal fan and she herself said it was delicious. The pasta that came with the veal wasn't that exciting, it was pretty bland to be honest. Maybe so it wouldn't take away from the flavors of the veal? We got there at 5:30 and they open at 5. It was a Tuesday night and it was already packed. This place is super popular obviously. I would highly recommend this place, and come early!! Get the gnocci!! Great sauce and very filling.
author: Heather S.

description:
Such a great neighborhood spot.The service is amazing, even when they are extremely busy (which is pretty much every dinner). Everything is made to order, so if you want less butter, no garlic, etc, they can do it for you. 

The portions are huuge and everything I've had is delicious, starting with the complimentary bread, which come with regular and focaccia. My favorite dish is the Fedelini alla Cecca with tomatos, basil, and garlic. It's smple, light, flavorful, and filling. The house wine, both the red and white, are also both really good. 

And to top it off, their prices are cheaper than most places in little italy, about $10-$16 dishes. And it suits all occasions, a romantic dinner date, or a casual dinner with friends. And you can order take out! Great service, even better food, and good prices. I love everything about this place. 

They don't take reservations, but you can drink wine outside while you wait :) I haven't been for brunch, but I will definitely try it soon.
author: Maleenee B.

description:
A really cute little cafe in Nob Hill. Perfect for a cozy lunch :)

A friend and I shared the Crostini di Polenta and the Penne Bettola (Yummy!!!) and the portions were big enough to fill us up. Lots of great options for vegetarians!
author: Bhavya K.

description:
Veal Piccata To Die For!

My associate and I had dinner here at the suggestion of a co-worker, and the concierge at our hotel a few blocks away. This was hands down the best and most reasonably priced meal of my entire stay in San Francisco.

The restaurant is cozy, and you enter right by the kitchen, where you can see the chefs at work, and smell the wonderful aroma of the food they are preparing. Great way to start. 

We were seated at a nice table where we could look out at the street for entertainment. Being seriously hungry, we were having a difficult time settling on what to order. The waitress described several items that we had questions about, but her description of the veal Piccata (Vitello Piccata) along with her indication that it was one of their most popular dishes, helped us decide on it. We also ordered the Insalata Mista (mixed greens with lemon herb dressing) which she indicated was large enough for both of us to share.

The salad was light and flavorful and perfectly proportioned. The Veal Piccata arrived, and I can't fully describe its lovely savory aroma of garlic, wine and herbs. The flavor did not disappoint. The lemon and capers provided a pleasant contrast to the butter and wine in the dish. I thoroughly enjoyed each bite. The portion was almost too much for me, but I didn't leave a single bit on the plate. 

It was served with perfectly prepared snap peas that were neither over or under cooked, and a perfect complement to the veal. The side of penne romana was nicely cooked and tasty, but I'm not a big pasta person. With so much food in front of me, I focused on the veal and the snap peas since I couldn't possibly clean my plate.

Service was great, and our bill for the meal was extremely reasonable, and the least expensive of our entire visit to San Francisco. I that wish we had eaten here every evening.
author: Faridah S.

description:
Hands down favorite Italian in the city and best neighborhood spot if you live close by. The pesto on anything is to die for, and make sure you ask for their house made focaccia, you won't be sorry! 

Finally the house wine will not disappoint, much like an outstanding Italian restaurant.
author: Amy V.

description: Loved everything we ordered here! The bruschetta was perfect ($5.50 for 2 pieces). I had the spaghetti carbonara which was incredible -- HIGHLY recommend it! My sister ordered the pesto tortellini with pine nuts which was also really good. My mom had the calzone which I really loved. It was stuffed with cheese, spinach, onions and garlic and a marinara dip on the side which was possibly the best marinara I've had. For desert we had the pumpkin gelato cheesecake which was also great - wasn't on the menu, but I saw a yelp review about it and asked about it -- & they had it! Highly recommend this place! Only (small) complaint is that I wish the food came a little more quickly!
author: Katrina L.

description: So want to give 5 stars but when both host and waiter aren't particularly enthusiastic to welcome 4 happy ( mixed aged so not wild and obnoxious mum is 77!) women. After 5 fantastic experiences over the years tonight's experience was terrible. Food was great always but service was lacking and painful. Waiter took our order but really couldn't have cared less if we came or went. Host seemed annoyed to have us visit. What a sad traditional. As a business owner I understand transition and thankfully only front team was frustrated and sad. Food was demotion and one of the assistant waiters/helpers was sweet charming and happy to offer the biggest smile and heaping scoops of cheese. Too shocked by changed and hospitality staff to catch his name but his smile and food almost made up for host (way too cool for school and waiter, just ordinary) and waiters apathy. Such a bummer that a neighborhood restaurant no longer cares about clientele. We will give another chance at some point maybe but really sad that it has changed so much.
author: Melissa L.

description:
If you want Italian food, go here. 

They don't take reservations so you might have to wait a while, but you can sit outside and drink wine while you wait. The food is priced very well and you always get enough to eat. I love the gnocchi bolognese.

My fav Italian place hands down.
author: Light Bulb J.

description: Got here, put our name down for a table for 4, and we were told the wait would be 45 minutes. We went for a 20 minute walk and returned to check in with the hostess. At that point she asked if we were 2 or 4. We said 4 again and she looked a bit embarrassed. She had clearly passed us up because the actual wait was less than 20 minutes. They then seated tables of 2 and 4 ahead of us. We finally were seated an hour later when they had closed and trays of food were arriving from some other place.  They told us we couldn't order large plates because the table we got was the best of tiny and wouldn't fit anything more than pasta bowls. What a snooty, stuck up, San Francisco Snob Hill shit show.
author: Afaan N.

description: Amazing food and service! Elaine is the friendliest most attentive server she made the visit a 5 star! She started noticing me putting the lemon from my tea in my boyfriends beer so his next beer she brought had a lemon in it! The food was delicious and perfectly seasoned!! Everything tasted so fresh and wasn't too salty or over seasoned! Seriously amazing all around!
author: Jistice G.

description:
We live close by so are regulars here. Be prepared to wait! Great offering of simple pasta, pizza and Italian inspires food. 

Don't be afraid to add a little meat to your pasta dishes, it's not clear on the menu but they will add, chicken, pancetta and other delights!

The bruschetta is always super fresh and the lasagne is one of the best that I've had!
author: Jason V.

description:
This place is awesome.

The pesto and penne battola are signature dishes and are great hardy bowls of pasta with great flavor.

The wait can be a bit frustrating as the place is very small, but on a nice day it's very enjoyable.

The staff is friendly for the most part, and the kitchen guys work their butts off for you night after night.

Pizza's to go are the way!
author: David K.

description: They really really really need to change the hostess. Very rude and unwelcoming. I will never step a foot in that place. I had my child and wanted to sit down and start him with dinner while my wife got ready at the hotel room and she made it so difficult. The other day we went there and she told me that it would be an hour wait then saw my kid and said well actually it's an hour and half. Very rude person too.
author: Abdul M.

description: This is a great neighborhood Italian cafe. Great food, and ok service...it seems like they could use another server sometimes.  If there's a wait I recommend getting a glass of wine, and people watch on the patio. This is the more casual, sister restaurant to Vinticello a block away.
author: Thomas R.

description:
I've been living in Nob Hill for just over 2 years now and have never tried Nob Hill Cafe until a month ago and can't get enough. The staff is incredibly friendly and their pasta is top-notch. I highly recommend the Spaghetti alla Carbonara or (if you like spicy) the Penne Bettola .

Pro-tip: The wait is most likely always long. So get there 30 minutes in advance, order a glass of wine, and sit outside while you wait. 

Another pro-tip: If you live in the neighborhood, you can order for pick-up 15 minutes in advance. Highly recommended.
author: Aubrey M.

description:
This place was absolutely amazing nothing to complain about. Wait was a little long but given it was a Saturday night and the restaurant was pretty small accomodating a group of 5 was a bit of a challenge. Unlike the previous Italian place we tried to go to they did not turn us away. We ended up waiting about an hour for our table but in the meantime they handed us a drink menu to enjoy drinks while we waited. 
Service was superb! Everything came out so efficiently, fast and of course delicious. I had the pasta carbonara and it was super rich and amazing. Might of been of the best carbonara I've had. Another one of my favorite was the cheese ravioli I with a lemon pesto like sauce. It was zesty and fresh and nothing that I've tried before. 
Everything was absolutely amazing and I would come back again for more yummy pasta. No need to go to little Italy for some Italian food. Found a great place in Nob Hills
author: Ysabel N.

description:
What a gem. We enjoyed a sharing dinner of antipasti  for 2 mostly grilled peppers, zucchini, artichokes with olives, mozzarella and prosciutto..enough for 4 people! 
Pasta course feasted oh gnocchi bolognese best ever sauce, soft fluffy gnocchi. We thought, no we're done , really until the most fantastically delicious and lemony local Sole dinner. Perfection. Lovely gracious help, expect a wait but there is seating to accommodate. BTW, ALL that good, and a bottle of Zinfandel too for $100. Love love this place,
author: A N.

description: This is a cute restaurant, but if you are coming here for good Italian, you will not get it. I'm not sure how there are so many good reviews praising the food, but I was not impressed with the gnocchi bolognese or the stale bread. Three stars are for the portions and the general ambiance.
author: Shabnam E.

description:
Adorable neighborhood gem that serves delicious food in a cozy atmosphere. You may have to wait for a table but there's always the takeout route which only is about 20-25 minutes I believe. 

Their focaccia bread is to die for...I am still dreaming of it two days after my meal. Seriously, worth every carb. I had their gnocchi bolognese which was good but not phenomenal in my opinion and I've had the pasta with eggplant before too. I look forward to coming back and trying other dishes. But remember: focaccia!!
author: Denise R.

description:
Will not be giving Nob Hill Cafe a third chance. It took us almost three years to give it a 2nd, and now I remember why. Came in on a Saturday night, place was packed, which I expected. Wine while we waited helped, but tasted stale. 

What we tried: 
+ Beet salad - really tasty and a healthy portion of beets, candied walnuts, and cheese. yum!
- Vodka sauce didn't have much flavor, and wasn't as creamy as we'd hoped. Also, dish would have been better with some sort of protein.
- Major disappointment of the night was the risotto. Two days later and I'm still thinking about how awful it was. It was a heaping pile of extremely dried rice and tasteless chicken (looked like the kind you buy pre-cooked from Trader Joe's). We mentioned this to our waiter who took the plate away without saying much. They brought out a new dish which was laughable, but also insulting. The dried rice was now floating in a pool of questionable liquid. This was one of the worst dining experiences I've had lately. Half due to the awfulness of the dish, and half due to the fact that our waiter was so apathetic about it all. Not trying to get too dramatic, but I really was frustrated...a place like this should respect food and diners much more than what we experienced.
author: Brianna M.

description:
I absolutely adore Nob Hill Cafe. I feel SO grateful that this gets to be my neighborhood restaurant -- the food is hearty, simple and delicious, the staff courteous and personable, the ambiance intimate and homey.

I'm a big fan of the pizzas and pastas, though keep in mind that portions are large. (Tip: You can add additional toppings to their pies for just $1 -- I usually opt for some prosciutto or gruyere.) I also love their calamari salad with white beans, which I'd argue rivals Delfina's -- and it costs just a fraction of the price. Even their daily specials have always been fab, especially the lentil stew.

Big, big fan for life! Hoping that Nob Hill Cafe stays around forever and ever.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Have been going to this wonderful place for years. The Carpaccio Cipriani and Penne Bettola are the best. The staff is always incredibly friendly.

Bottom line: 
Great food, great prices, great atmosphere.
author: Gina M.

description: We loved our experience! Great, local gem with affordable, hearty Italian. Delicious bread, great service, and comfortable ambiance. Warm restaurant on a cold night. Perfect date spot!
author: Garrett R.

description: Worst experience ever.  My daughter put our name in tonight.  She was told 45 a minute wait.  She called to check on timing after 40 minutes.  She was told to be here very soon as if we were not we would loose our spot if we were not here.  We left our drinks at a lovely hotel a few blocks away to rush over.  When we arrived my daughter checked on our status and was told it would be just about 10 minutes.  After about 35 minutes I went in myself and asked why the wait?  The hostess said it would be soon.  And asked if we would like to PURCHASE a glass of wine.  I said sure I would prefer a bottle though.  I ordered a bottle.  It never actually came and 25 minutes later, with attitude we were told our table was ready.  We were then put at a 2 top.  There are 3 of us...  I asked for a different table and was told that was all she could give is.  When the server greeted us, my wife asked if there were any specials and the server said, "The special board is over there."  I asked if she could suggest a nice bottle of red wine and she pointed to my menu and said she would check back with us after I decided what bottle I wanted.  I excused myself and walked over to the the waitress and asked why we were being treated so rudely.  She stated that we insulted the hostess and we were on the verge of not being welcome.  With that I looked at her and said not to worry as we would rather not support there business.  With that we simply left after nearly a 2 hour wait.  Never have I experienced such treatment.  Nor will I ever go back!
author: Scott H.

description: The best pasta in the city. Come early for dinner because they do not take reservations and are always busy.
author: Y L.

description: Great food! The service is so-so! I asked for spaghetti and got penne, but it tasted so good that I don't care!
author: Deepika N.

description:
Can I swear on here?  Because my pasta was freakin' good.  

Fresh tomatoes, fresh basil, just the right amount and combination of herbs, perfectly cooked pasta in a big round ceramic bowl.

The people here are great.  As if it's their duty to feed me, and feed me well.  Ah, thinking about the experience makes me smile.

Be prepared to wait, to be real close with other patrons (a lil cramped, in a good way), and to enjoy a hearty Italian meal.
author: Christine Y.

description:
My last yelp for Nob Hill Cafe was in 2008, and my love for Nob Hill Cafe has grown even more. Why? It has not changed since 2008 and that is what I love about it! It is still the quaint warm oasis in the middle of aristocratic Nob Hill. Some of the patrons act a little hoity-toity, but I pretend to be the same when I'm there :) Just kidding...

After repeatedly failing to get reservations for my birthday at the "hottest" restaurants in San Francisco, my daughter reminded me of how much I love Nob Hill Cafe and that they do NOT take reservations. Leave it to a CAL Bear! Lol!

An exhausting but exhilarating trek up Mason from Union Square led us to the familiar twinkly white outdoor lights, and we knew we arrived. We were seated at a table immediately and oh, how Angeline Pinot Noir tastes so good after a day of shopping! We started with the antipasto misto which is exceeds any antipasto dish in Honolulu, I must say. We ordered the Linguine Alla Vongole, Gnocchi Bolognese, and Vitello Piccata. Everything tasted wonderful and my dinner was topped off with a complimentary Ganache dessert, with a candle, that was to die for--and I don't generally eat chocolate!

I love that Nob Hill stays true to what it's known for: good, hearty Italian fare in an adorable neighborhood in the most beautiful charismatic city in the world.
author: KJ N.

description:
I've been living in Russian Hill / Nob Hill for just over 4 years now and have never tried Nob Hill Cafe until a week ago and can't get enough. The staff is incredibly friendly and their brunch/ breakfast menu is amazing. I highly recommend everyone to try them out ASAP. We came on a rainy day and were seated right away (normally there is always a huge line out the door when I have walked by).

Food:
We ordered from the brunch menu. I ordered their omelette (comes with a side of potatoes and cornbread) and added avocado and my fiance got the French Toast (with a side of potatoes and bacon). The French Toast and the omelette tasted great and we enjoyed the OJs (I think they make them fresh). 

We will be back soon!
author: Sepi N.

description: One of my favorite neighborhood restaurants. Cute, quirky place that serves traditional Italian cuisine with a slight twist. The risotto sandoria alone is enough of a reason to bring me back again and again.
author: Vivien S.

description:
This is a quiet and fancy restaurant. Definitely worth going to but be aware of a wait list to get a table, so bring a jacket and expect to sit outside until an opening is made. While you wait, the staff will bring you warm drinks and maybe a simple appetizer if they are not too busy. 

The food was great and delightful. I really enjoyed the gnocchi though it could have been cooked a little bit longer. (maybe that is a personal preference). I also enjoyed the atmosphere of a casual yet warm cozy setting. Furthermore, the staff was super friendly, always smiled, and was very respectful and attentive to our needs. 

Overall: this is a great place to go on a date or to eat out after a stressful day. This place will calm you down with a good home-cooked style meal.
author: Gavin P.

description:
I'm a father of 3 year old triplets, so I appreciate a restaurant whose waitstaff know how to accommodate parties with young kids. This is the main reason why they get 5 stars from me. They get it.

Food wise, I'm quite well satisfied. I had the smoked salmon scramble from the Sunday brunch menu. It was filling, and tasty. Their take on corn bread is also rather special, having a sweet theme to it. 

Plan to walk here. Parking is hell. But then again, this is San Francisco. Parking is hell everywhere.
author: Roy S.

description: Got food poisoning. It was the only food I ate today and it hit me about 1.5 hrs after eating. Otherwise, a good lunch.  Very good service/ staff and everything was very good except I feel like crap. My stomach is in knots :(
author: Liz H.

description: Pretty decent food overallbut not too many GF items.  They can modify some of the dishes to make them GF although no GF pasta or pizza available.   My husband loved his eggplant dish and my son liked his pizza enough but I'm basing my review on the frittata I ordered off the brunch menu.  It was ok but not great.  I made it a little better by adding marinara sauce because it was a bit dry.  Not a true frittata either more like a scramble.  I didn't really enjoy it truthfully.  Considering all the great places there are to eat in San Francisco, I would rate the food a 2.5 stars however the waitresses were very friendly so I bumped it up to 3 stars.
author: Lisa F.

description: Wonderful Italian food, especially considering the size of this very tiny place.  Pizza was perfect.   Eggplant was clearly fresh and homemade.   Fritata was more like a scramble, but excellent.
author: Miles F.

description: Favorite little Italian restaurant in SF! Right next to the Grace Cathedral and Huntington Park, it's located in a cute little neighborhood in Nob Hill. Almost every time we have to wait 15-30 minutes for a table but definitely worth it!! They serve the best bread and my favorite dish is the Spaghetti Carbonara. I work at a hotel and recommend this place all the time and guests come back to me saying they loved it! You must go here!
author: Alyssa I.

description:
The place is well located and the atmosphere is cozy. It's overall a great neighborhood restaurant. 
Foodwise it is decent but nothing extravagant. Other Italian restaurants in the city may be better.
We got the calamari salad, the lasagna, and the gnocchi.
Salad was awesome, lasagna was okay, and we got the wrong pasta.
Service was not great and could be definitely improved.
Tiramisu is great. 
I would give this place 3.5 stars if I could.
author: Akram A.

description:
Recommended by the hotel. Food was great but the service was not. Once our waiter took our order we did not see him again until we flagged h down to get the bill. 
We were advised of the no res. policy so we did not mind the 20 min. wait.
author: Scott D.

description: Convenient local Italian walking distance from the Fairmont Hotel. No hills to get there. Friendly, honest wait staff. Seating is limited so get there early.
author: Alan Y.

description: I would not recommend the brocettia. It was a little bland. Staff were extremely friendly. Food a little salty but good. Brocettia was a let down. Just olive oil, tomato's, and basil. And for $7 something you only get two pieces.
author: Parker T.

description: Well it would have been nice to try this restaurant out. After walking half a mile uphill, we find the restaurant is CLOSED until the next day... Written on a piece of printer paper pasted to the window. Probably should post that somewhere on their website so people don't waste their time.
author: Kayla B.

description: Cute gem of a restaurant in Nob Hill. Adorable environment and very authentic Italian. You can't go wrong with anything on their menu.
author: Samara C.

description: This place is an institution in Nob Hill. It needs to be on everyone's bucket list. It's been open for two decades so they must be doing something right. They do not take reservations so if you arrive after about 6 prepare to wait a while. The restaurant itself is very small, so you will be almost cozy with your neighboring tables. My two favorite dishes there are the lasagne and the calamari steak. Truly a neighborhood gem.
author: Lori M.

description: I adore this place!  They have great Italian food, and decent wine selection (doesn't take much to please me).  I love it as a more romantic, quiet spot. The customer service is fantastic.  It is one of my fave places to stop at when we are visiting from Columbus, OH.
author: Cathy S.

description: Very good food. Ceaser was a little wilted and the dressing a touch too fishy for my personal liking but I still ate it. I went in right when they opened for the evening at 5. Bread was delicious and perfect for dipping into my sauce.
author: Jessica S.

description: I got the gnocchi in bolognese sauce. It was amazing, the chef is awesome. This is a great hole in the wall place to eat.
author: James H.

description:
A winner every time; a favorite neighborhood spot.
I continue to come back to Nob Hill Cafe over and over again. The service is consistently solid; food is plentiful and wonderful and the price is pretty spot on for the area.

At night, especially on the weekends, you can expect to wait outside for 15-45min, but the girls typically come out and take drink orders so beer and wine while you wait == win. Just be prepared for the wait; if it's cold; have a jacket; obviously. 

Food, as I mentioned prior, is wonderful. I've pretty much had everything on the menu as well as ripped through a lot of their specials. On the menu I tend to fall back to the veal plate as my goto; but the squid ink seafood bowls are bomb diggity! 

Go here... you won't be upset. 

See you there
author: Chuck R.

description: My first visit to San Francisco and I had the great pleasure of eating dinner here. It was very close to my hotel at the top of Nob Hill. It's a cozy place with limited seating, so get there early to avoid an extensive wait time. I had there Gnocchi dish which I read to be one of the best and it didn't disappoint. Dessert was a cappuccino cheesecake that was also   to die for. Service was also excellent and very accommodating. I highly recommend this place if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Chuck K.

description:
i have eaten at Nob Hill Cafe for the last 15 years on and off and never had a bad experience. We just came here last Friday night and everything was OK.

Maybe the mistake was ordering ahead and having it delivered. The sauces smelled off and I wasn't even going to try the chicken, based on the smell. We threw out $50 worth of food.

Sorry Nob Hill Cafe, I love you guys, but something was not right this evening. Not sure I'll be back for a while.
author: C B.

description:
Upon arrival at 8:20pm, my wife and I were told there would be a 30-40 minute wait.  Unfortunately, they do not take reservations.  We had already walked quite a distance and decided to wait to be seated. To our surprise we were seated after 20 minutes. 

The quaint and quiet atmosphere made for a enjoyable dining experience. We shared a pasta dish and pizza that we both enjoyed very much. Overall, it was a memorable experience. 

Note: The bathroom is tiny!
author: Terry M.

description:
This place has character. The service is nice, atmosphere cozy, and food is good. Many of their dishes have the same sauce flavor, which makes up a majority of the taste. So if everyone in your group orders something with tomato sauce, it's going to taste the same (for the most part). 

Parking is difficult...lots of hills and street signs to deal with.
author: Epic S.

description:
Yum.

We arrived at 10 minutes to 5 on a Tuesday night and were the 4th party in the door. By 5:30, every table was filled. This is a Very Popular  restaurant (and small). I would not recommend it for parties of more than 4; I'm not certain if they can even put together a table of that size.

We were early enough to choose our table and sat right next to the kitchen - our favorite spot in any restaurant. We like to see what they're doing (and, in this case, smell the food).

We ordered the salad of the day - baby kale with gorgonzola, apples, almonds, and poppyseed vinaigrette. It wasn't bad. Not the fault of the cafe. I just don't like kale enough to ever order this again. I had hoped, with baby kale, it would be better but... too "scrub brushy". However, if you like kale, you might like it.

The polenta was delicious and the marinara sauce was very good. I mopped up every bit with the bread.

We split an order of spaghetti carbonara - very tasty with a lot of proscuitto. The waitress offered extra parmesan and freshly-ground pepper. We had said we were splitting everything, and the kitchen  divided the carbonarainto two bowls (no charge for the split).

We shared an order of tiramisu for desert, easily large enough to share. Spouse got a cafe au lait (with a nice layer of foam) and I had hot tea. Tea drinkers will be pleased to know that the cafe offers a wide choice of "real" teas -  caffeinated as well as herbal. I was pleased that one of the choices was Darjeeling! They brought a nice little ceramic teapot with enough water for two cups, hot enough to brew a decent pot.

Next time, we'll order a caesar salad. We watched one of the chefs making one. There will definitely be a next time , and we'll arrive at 5pm again!
author: Vicki B.

description: Don't eat the seafood. I puked twice already now that I'm home. Cute place but wow- for being a special on the menu you think it would have been fresh or at least decent. Never eating here again. And to think there were so many other places around there I could have had a wonderful meal at. Grrrr.
author: Krisztina L.

description:
On a Tuesday night at about 6:00 the place was packed.  Our estimated wait of 20 minutes was right on target.

Service was pleasant and we anticipated a great meal but our expectations were not realized.  One of the other reviewers mentioned they did not like salty and I'm afraid that the over salting of food might be a reoccurring event.  

We had the  Gnocchi Bolognese which at first bite seemed fine.  After the second bite we both realized that the Na Cl was overdone.  It wasn't to the point of being inedible but it ruined what could have been a great sauce.

What decent chef does not taste his/her sauces was they are prepared?

We mentioned this to the hostess as we left and she acknowledged our comment, but I had the feeling that that was as far as it was going.

I am not going to chance another try.
author: Bradley C.

description: I may be biased since I live in the neighborhood but Nob Hill cafe is one of the most consistent and delicious Italian restaurants in San Francisco. This tucked away location has great ambiance and always delivers quality food. Make sure you try the focaccia bread and carbonara at some point. If you're looking for a classic Italian meal, with a moderate price point and no fancy dress code, this is your spot. You can also call ahead and place an order for pick up.
author: Nick M.

description: A very cute and cozy restaurant with delicious food and good wine. what more could you want. They have a nice outside waiting area for over flow where you can drink wine and mingle. once inside it is very intimate. they had great specials and a decent daily menu. food is well priced for Italian. I only wish, in such a "healthy" city, they offered more gluten free options but that is a minor minor complaint because I still loved the Sole I had.
author: Corey B.

description: Popular restaurant hidden in the residential area. And although this place is small, the environment was cozy with good service. Parking was hard to find, but the wait time was quick; came at a good time (6-7pm) because while eating, there were people waiting outside. Ordered lasagna and linguini alla vongole. Both were good! The linguini came in a large bowl with lots of clams and the lasagna was cheesy. This is not your typical Italian food like Olive Garden. Until another Italian place matches up to this restaurant's standard, would certainly come back when in the city.
author: Rochelle G.

description: Just one word awesome. Service was excellent and the food was very tasty. Its a small quaint place with limited seating so be prepared to wait a while during the busy hours. Take this opportunity to order some wine and sit outside  and enjoy the evening, while watching people go by. The kitchen is right in front and the chef is cooking up a storm it in it self is a show if tour a real foodie. Robin our waitress was very nice and offered good service. The food was steaming hot and indication  of the freshness no microwave here.
author: Julio M.

description:
Love this place. Cute, intimate, right smack in a neighborhood, terrific service, delicious food.
Got the pizza special, linguini with clams (REALLY good), squid salad (really good), and garlic bread (yum but probably could have just gone with the free foccacia they bring out).
Whatever you do though, GET THE SPUMONI GELATO. It's not spumoni and it's not exactly gelato, at least not what most people typically think of. It actually looks like a pistachio cheesecake. It was one of the most delicious, unique desserts I've ever had, and I would totally come back just for dessert (though if I come here, I'd do the whole shebang).
My only small negative was that they brought our entire meal out at once and didn't pace it. Understandable because their kitchen looks tiny, annoying because our table was way too small to comfortably accommodate the plates and glasses, preventable if they had just spaced out when they made their orders.
Would love to make this a regular date place (though the wait was about thirty minutes on a Friday night starting around 7:45pm)
author: Melissa T.

description: Delicious food!  Great service!  Spaghetti with meat sauce was amazing.  Lasagne was great! The chicken picante was superb.  Wait on a Tuesday was about 10 minutes at 7:30pm.  You should try this place!
author: Alexis C.

description: Gnocchi all the way. Best i have ever had... and then the bread dipped in the bolognaise sauce. Food this good should be illegal... but for real get it!!!
author: Jim S.

description: A must-do when it this part of the city. Tiny little restaurant that is always full because the food is amazing! Try their pasta in garlic cream sauce with pancetta. If you go on weekends with no reservation, prepare to wait, but it's worth it!
author: Summer-Rose S.

description:
I had high expectations for Nob Hill Cafe. I love Italian food and the reviews were positive overall. Alas, disappointment was on the menu for this evening. 
The food was not the issue here; it wasn't spectacular in any way, but it was above average in most cases. We started with a daily special antipasti; prosciutto wrapped asparagus with mozzarella and marinara. It fell a little flat, as the asparagus was a little undercooked and the prosciutto seemed like a weak link that barely registered under a lot of marinara. For main courses, we each had pasta, but they couldn't have been more different. I chose the gnocchi Bolognese, which was very good, at times. The problems here were twofold. One, the plating was poor; by serving the dish on a flat plate, the temperature upon service was uneven, so as I worked from one side of the plate to the other it went from tepid to hot to cold. Two, the gnocchi were very unevenly made, so though the smaller pieces were perfect pillowy goodness, larger pieces were a bit gummy. On the positive side, the sauce was rich and meaty. My wife had the fedelini alla Cecca, which was quite good. Though the pasta itself was unremarkable, the sauce was fresh and light (and HOT!) For dessert we shared a slice of what they call gelato try-it. This is a layer of gelato on top of a thin layer of cheesecake with a layer of flavored cream on top. Ours had pumpkin gelato and Grand Marnier cream. It was probably the highlight of the meal.
Now for the real problems with our dinner. First, the table we were seated at has no business being in the restaurant. It is a nightmare location crammed into a nook next to the entry to the service area. There is a constant cavalcade of staff bustling by and the small half-wall that separated my wife's chair from the dishwashing area was constantly being bumped, disturbing her seat. Now, if you are going to seat people in a location that every member of the wait staff passes twenty times per hour, PAY ATTENTION TO THEM. Having empty drinks for long stretches and waiting ten minutes to get bread brought to the table (without olive oil) while being ignored by everyone constantly passing by is infuriating. I also need to comment on the noise level in the restaurant. It is quite noisy, as you would expect a small popular place to be, but the most noise here comes from them bussing the tables like they hate all of the plates and flatware. Numerous times we watched in shock as plates and glasses were literally tossed onto tables and place settings were slapped down like dominos in a southern grudge match. And it wasn't just one employee; everyone who turned a table got into the act. It was a little disconcerting and very annoying.
author: Jason E.

description:
When we moved to SF first this lovely restaurant was only down the street from where we lived. It's a beautiful restaurant, really friendly staff. Doesn't take reservations but it's lovely just hanging out on the street for your table and you can order wine which is fun!
Food has never failed, the breads that they bring to start are fab. My main dish to go for is the veal - amazing price and it is so flavourful.
The last time we went we just wanted to share one glass of red, and the waitress split it between 2 glasses!
This is my go to place with visiting guests, or romantic dinners!
author: Kim M.

description: Best Italian restaurant in town. Away from the tourist area of union street. Small and cozy place. The food is perfection. Hidden gem... I recommend the carbonara, pesto fettuccini and the gnocchi
author: Sarah G.

description:
I was looking for somewhere with a nice atmosphere and a street bistro feel where we could enjoy the spring sunshine. Nob Hill Cafe satisfied on all counts. The waitress was really helpful in selecting a gluten-free meal for me and my friends were happy with their selections as well (spinach salad with chicken and the other had the duck sausage pizza). 

The misto salad was really light and fresh and my friend and I were able to split it as an appetizer. I added chicken to the polenta appetizer and was really full (in a good way). There was definitely enough to save for later, but since my hotel has no fridge I couldn't let that savory goodness go to waste. 

I was really hoping for a bistro experience and I was delightfully happy with how good the food was, how nice the service was  and how cute the restaurant was. I'm a happy girl.
author: Sarah L.

description:
First tip.  And it could save you life.  (Take a cab)  We are staying at the Grand Hyatt in Union Square.  A family friend told us that we should definitely check out Nob Hill.  I had actually had my eye on a place called Scala's Bistro, since it was just .1 mile from the hotel, however the recommendation of Nob Hill was to hard for Suzie to pass up and just .3 miles further, she pleaded with me with her big blue eyes batting... pweeze..Ah jeez.. okay.   I consulted the google mappy thing on the Yelp app and chartered our course for Nob Hill.  Notice the word Hill.  We set out for dinner wanting to get there before the wait started.  Off we go down Stockton and then make a right on Taylor and start up a slight incline for a block.  Followed by the next block which is noticeable steeper.  By the next block, I noticed that there were Sherpa's available at base camp 2 for the final leg to the summit.  We had already passed one gentlemen who was grasping his chest and leaning against a wall.  Oh wait, that was actually me, it's all bit hazy since the air is quite thin up here.  Finally, we hit a plateau, with a cathedral soaring up the heavens.  Very appropriate, since it would be a good place to bury me at this point.  Chafed, winded, and at this point completely knackered, we spied the sign Nob Hill Cafe.  Victory is ours!!

Nob HIll is tiny, quaint and smells amazing.  The hostess welcomed us and we were sat at a little 2 top, next to the kitchen and the dish washing area.  Loud clashing of pots and pans, bustling wait-staff and bus folks and the ever engaging aroma of loveliness.  Our waitress was really great and let us know the specials and asked if I was okay.  Apparently, I looked as bad as I felt.  Nothing a couple glasses of Prosecco wouldn't cure and my spirits lifted immediately.  We ordered the Calamari Salad, Gnocchi and Carbonara.  

Calamari was fresh and served with white beans, lemon and capers.  Great portion for two to split.  Refreshing and well prepared.  My Carbonara came out with Romana creme sauce, pancetta bites, garlic and egg.  It was again a healthy portion, full of flavor and extremely filling.  Top Drawer.  Suzie's Gnocchi Bolognese was the bomb.  The fennel sausage in the meat sauce was exceptional.  Fennel should be used more often in a dish like this.  I will definitely remember this the next time I make a bolognese.  This had to be their signature dish, since almost everywhere I looked this is what folks were ordering.

The menu has many offerings including pizza, anti-pasta's, salads and mains.  Service was excellent and pleasant.  She was extremely well informed, able to have knowledge of the wine menu as well as entree's selection.  I overheard her mention to tables as well as ours, "if you don't know what to get, let me know what you are stuck between and I will help you make a decision".  Elena was really on her game.  A nice surprise was the price point.  Quite affordable for a meal of this quality.  Get there early so you don't get stuck in line.. however, they will provide you with a glass of wine while you wait.
author: Jens B.

description: Always constant and THE BEST on Nob Hill.  LOVE this place!!!!
author: Thomas B L.

description: This is right on our door step and we couldn't ask for a better Italian local. The pasta dishes are all so fresh and delicious currently my favourite is the gnocchi tomato bologniase! It's a very popular spot right at the top of Nob hill and you can't reserve so be prepared to wait a bit with a drink.. It's worth the wait. It's also ideal for a takeaway if you don't want to wait for a table. A local I plan to take all friends and family to when they come visit.
author: Nicola T.

description: Visiting from So Cal// This cafe came up on Yelp and we came for a 30min wait... worth it. Every bowl of pasta ordered at the table was wiped clean. I ordered a special and it was possibly the best bowl of pasta I had ever eaten. I recommend an order of the garlic bread with dinner.
author: Niccole D.

description: I read so many great reviews of this place, and my expectations were high. Being close to the hotel I was staying at, it was an easy decision. The wait was an hour for a table, which I have no problem with, considering they don't take reservations and it was in the middle of dinner hours. I ordered the Cesar salad to start, and for $9 (without chicken or meat), I expected a delicious salad, and it was rather underwhelming. The dressing was watery and the Parmesan looked and tasted like Kraft grated Parmesan, the kind you find in the grocery store for $4. My entree was the gnocchi bolognese. Again, it was nothing special. Overall, the meal satisfied my hunger, but I wouldn't return.
author: Joe A.

description: Clam pasta was too sour. Oil linguini was nothing special. The server didn't come to refill the coffee until we asked for few times.
author: Anya C.

description: What an incredible treasure! My boyfriend and I traveled from Austin to San Francisco and we're having a hard time finding a restaurant for our last night. We wanted to stay away from the touristic restaurants and find something authentic. Ultimately we decided on Nob Hill café and were very impressed! it was Sunday night and we had no trouble parking. We walked in 30 minutes before closing and were seated immediately. The hostess noticed I was cold at our table by the door so she offered to seat us in a cozier section, THANKYOU!! Our server Robin was very nice and offered us a small wine tasting because we had no idea what we wanted to drink. She guided us through the menu and our plates were EXCELLENT! Everything was so delicious and fresh. We were surprised at how well we were treated since we walked in so late. we never felt rushed and the staff/cooks were so sweet to us when we left. The food and service was flawless, I miss it! I'm now back home in Texas wishing I was eating Nob Hills cafe's Carbonara!!!
author: Sonia V.

description:
I really wanted to love this place.  Just came back from a fabulous vacation in Italy and is in the hunt for a good carbonara place in the Bay Area.  Came here because it was highly rated for their carbonara....sigh, my hunt continues.

My husband and I attended a matinee show in SF and were hungry for an early dinner before heading back home.  Since Nob Hill Cafe doesn't take reservation, we arrived by 6 pm to beat the crowd.  We didn't wait too long before getting seated.  The hostess had a wee bit of an air about her when I merely asked if there were any available tables in the adjacent room for 2.  She just said, "no." O-kaayyy.....

Our waitress promptly greeted us and opened our wine for us.  Corkage here is $20. Not too bad for S.F. I was eying the antipasto starter, but it's a typical 2x portion.  My husband doesn't eat meat so I asked if there was a possibility of getting a 1/2 portion.  I was told that was not possible, but she politely explained the antipasto comes with grilled veggies.  So I decided to order it and will take left overs home if we can't finish.  We also ordered the ribolita soup, the crab ravioli special, and the pasta carbonara.

When the antipasto came, I was not impressed.  The plate came with "generous" amount of grilled veggies and artichokes, but 1 thin slice of prosciutto and 2 pieces of pancetta about 1" square and 1/4" thick.  THAT'S IT??? I paid $14 for 3 small pieces of meat? My husband loved it, but I was left disappointed.  His ribolita soup was light and flavorful. So far it's great for him as I munch on bread and grilled veggies.

Then our main courses came.  The carbonara is very clumpy.  I think the chef may have let it sat too long.  I tried tossing the pasta to loosen them, but they were just kind of stuck to each other; could used a little olive oil to loosen them a bit.  My husband's crab ravioli sauce was very salty.  It was hard for him to eat it.  At one point, he had to tell our waitress about the salt.  The waitress acknowledged that she had heard the same from other folks...BUT didn't offer to replace it with somethign else! No, she was just very sympathetic. Uh...OK.  So we just didn't finish our meal.  I took 1/2 of my pasta home.  I reheated for lunch the next day and toss it with a little EVOO and it was very good.

Overall, not worth going back for.....my hunt continues.
author: G K.

description: AMAZING rosemary focaccia bread, really.... sweet and moist like cake. Service was attentive without being overly so. Busmen had just right amount of promptness and disdain. Antipasto platter plenty for 3-4 diners.
author: D J.

description:
This is a cute spot tucked away in Nob Hill.  Before walking in, I was reminded of the classic (1968) movie Bullit since Steve McQueen's character (Frank Bullit) lived across the street and purchased a stack of TV dinners at the grocery store next door.

Anyway - this was the closest place walking distance from the Mark Hopkins that didn't involve hills.  We were seated promptly and the staff was friendly.  I tried the Beef Carpaccio and the Mushroom Risotto.  I would order the Beef Carpaccio again.  It was a well portioned plate and tasted great.  However - I was not a fan of the Mushroom Risotto since it was dry/fluffy and not creamy.

That being said, I will try this spot again very soon.  Although, my current rating is 3 stars only, I'm hoping to try more good food to raise my rating.  I hear the gnocchi bolognese is a hit.  Looking forward to it!
author: Alvin J.

description:
OH EM GEE. Yum!! Love love loved this place. What a hidden little gem, although not so hidden considering the mobs of people waiting to be sat at this place on a Friday night. Well, we waited and it was worth it. Came here on a very last minute triple date with 2 other couples after one of them heard about how yummy this place is. Super cozy, small space with unbelievably delicious food. I find it super hard to find old school, great, and reasonably priced Italian food in SF, but this place has it. We all shared a few bottles of house red and white wine, and split the Ziti with spicy vodka sauce and the tortellini with pesto and pine nuts. Plates embarrassingly clean by the end of it. Oh and did I mention the to die for free bread? I'll be coming back here on the regular. 

One star off for the service, not very friendly or personable, but not so bad that it became annoying or anything.
author: Alexis T.

description:
What a cute little Italian place!  Pasta used to be my favorite cuisine but after I discovered ramen and sushi, it fell back to #3.  Nevertheless, I still love it!  There's a bit of a wait since it's kind of small, but the patio is comfy to wait in.

We ordered the garlic bread, insalata caprese, linguine alla vongole, and the gnocchi bolognese.  Since I went with a gf and her bf hates cheese, we piled on the garlic and mozzarella.  Garlic bread was a little tough for my liking that it kind of hurt for me to eat.  I'm not fond of super crunchy bread.  The salad has balls of mozzarella, but it wasn't too heavy/cheesy to the point of ruining our meal.  My linguine had plenty of clams and the lemon zest was definitely noticeable but I still liked it.  My friend swears on the gnocchi but she was a bit disappointed since it didn't come out piping hot, which probably would've made it taste much better.  Neither of us finished our dishes though since they are huge portions.  I was very happy to have leftovers for the next day.

Like I said, the place is soooo cute, great for date night!
author: Jane N.

description:
|| Atmosphere
Stopped by during the late morning for a small bite to eat. At 11.30am there were about three other tables being served aside from ours, so it's obviously a popular place. Very cute place. 

|| Service
Attentive, very friendly waitress, extremely speedy. 

|| Ordered
Insalata Caprese ($8.25)
Prosciutto E Melone ($8.50)
plus a Peroni (~$5) and glass of Prosecco (~$10). 
The prices were reasonable. 

|| Food
The prosciutto dish size was really substantial. The melon was juicy and cold, but the prosciutto seemed dry around the edges, as if it was old. 

The Caprese was disappointing. The beauty of a Caprese is its fresh flavours and simplicity. Unfortunately, it was too heavy on the balsamic vinegar and came with onions and olives - all of which are unnecessary on a Caprese (in my opinion). The olives were a little wrinkly and the dish didn't taste fresh. 

|| Verdict
The antipasti dishes we chose didn't seem fresh. I'd return again to try some of their heartier dishes.
author: Emma R.

description: I love everything about this place.  I love that's it a small place and you can look in the front window and watch the cooks.  I love that it's too small to wait inside - so you wait outside and you can drink standing on the street. Once your in it's Italian cooking like you would experience in the east.  (I am speaking from experience.) The pastas, the breads, the antipasto...fantastic. Plus, if your like us and you walk up Taylor  to the restaurant - you'll feel like you earned the right to consume the carbs.
author: Gary A.

description: Such great food at the Nob Hill Cafe! Been coming here for over 25 years and it always puts out consistently heavenly dishes. Yummy yum yum!
author: Sharon S.

description:
Nob Hill Cafe is my go-to Italian food restaurant. It's simple, basic Italian food and the atmosphere just makes it. 

Food - The only dish I was "mehh" about was the chicken parm. Every pasta dish I've ever had was excellent - very rich, millions of calories, but excellent. One time, the server even misheard my order and brought me something completely different - the pasta is so legit, I didn't even care! Anything there will make me happy. Also, the rosemary bread they serve before dinner is the bomb. So much yum! 

Service-  Fast, professional and great. You can tell they're juggling a million tables because you see them buzzing around all night but they always manage to meet your every need. Great service. 

Atmosphere - Perfect date night place! Intimate, a tight squeeze, but buzzing with lively, happy customers and twinkling with tea light candles.
author: Amy C.

description: We are in San Francisco on vacation, upon check-in the front desk suggested we visit here.  We were sooo happy they sent us to this little gem!  I had the lobster ravioli & my husband had carbonara, both were DELICIOUS!  If you want something that is not touristy, and food that tastes like Italy, you should visit here.
author: A W.

description:
Love me some Nob Hill Cafe.

How can you go wrong with this little restaurant tucked away into a quiet area of Nob Hill. Their cute outdoor string lights give extra charm to this place. The food has been excellent every time I have come here. I recommend the Carbonara, definitely tasty. Good wines. Makes for a cute date spot or dinner with family or friends. The restaurant is pretty small, so their can easily be a wait any night of the week. However, the wait is well worth it. I'll be back. Again.
author: Lauren P.

description:
Great restaurant.
Very nice atmosphere and environment. Situated in a quiet and refined neighborhood.
Staff was friendly.
The lasagna tasted great - slightly different from the usual sort.
author: Jia Xi T.

description: Nob Hill Cafe is amazing and probably the best Italian food in the city.  It's quaint atmosphere-comfortable atmosphere, but get there early so you don't have to wait.  However, if you do get a glass/bottle of wine to do so outside while you do!
author: Randy H.

description:
Our adventure was rewarded! 

We tried new things this weekend--the staycation general rule was to go to places we haven't been before.  This one was very convenient.  

The theme was Italian, the clientele was San Franciscan.  We were at the top of Nob Hill, and we could tell.  So what do the rich people eat?  

My Lady had a frittatta putanesca, which looked great.  The potatoes were mixed into the frittatta, which surprised her, and while she had expected a corn muffin, we wound up ordering one for her.  The corn muffin was more muffin than corn, with glaze on the outside and sweetness on the inside.  

I ordered a pizzetta di salsicia, because the ingredients looked so unusual.  Besides Aidell's chicken sausage, it was topped with "baked egg."  What, I wanted to know, was baked egg?  It seems that they open an egg on top of thin-crust pizza, over the tomato paste and sausage.  It added a flavor and texture I would never expect in a pizza.  Well played, Nob Hill Cafe!  

The wine was worth it, too.  2 glasses of Marche Verdicchio, a mild medium white table wine, and a glass of Prosecco accompanied our lunch.  

That's a whole lunch for $55.46 + tip.  Bonus points!  This experiment worked out well.
author: David D.

description:
Really great neighborhood gem. Maybe not as good as venticello a block down. But better price and they have take out. 

I have tried the vodka sauce pasta. The gnocchi. The spaghetti carbonara. The antipasta mista and the all the deserts. 

They were all great. The only let down was the creme de Carmel. Too watery and the sauce was off tasting. 

No full bar but good wines. 

Nice service. Can be loud and babies can be crying. That can wear on you. But they have take out. 

I recommend the gnocchi or the Pollo Alla Parmigiana. Or the vodka sauce pasta. All great. Can't go wrong here.
author: Dakin G.

description: I revisited Nob Hill Cafe today after a couple years today and it's as great as ever! We sat outside and enjoyed delicious omelettes. I had the shrimp omelette ($10.75) with avocado, cheese, white onions, and potatoes and a corn muffin on the side. The service wasn't perfect as my coffee never came but I didn't reorder it as I figured it wasn't meant to be and I'll sleep more easily tonight without large quantities of coffee. They still have the delicious $3.50 fruit bowl too but I didn't order it as the omelette was more than enough food. I definitely will not wait so long to come back again!
author: Meghan P.

description: Good atmosphere and service, but found the food disappointing. We went there for lunch and I had the melanzanie salad. Unfortunately it was served straight from the fridge instead of at room temperature, which robs tomatoes of their taste. My husband had the calamari was salad. It was also too chilled and pretty tasteless.
author: Beth B.

description: Thank you person on the street for pointing me in this direction. The potato dumplings were out of this world. Tender light with a nice sausage and Pomodoro sauce on it. Dessert was whipping cream with mousse and fresh berries. The service was a bit rushed but the ambience was nice as I had a window cove seat looking at the pedestrians..
author: Deborah T.

description: After receiving a recommendation to check out this place, we set out to climb the hill. The food was excellent. We ordered garlic bread, caprese, ricotta ravioli in pesto and linguini in olive oil. For dessert, chocolate cheesecake and pumpkin gelato. I absolutely loved the ravioli. Incredible. Our server Elena was super friendly, handled all our questions and our banter. She made several food recommendations since we are vegetarian. I would absolutely recommend.
author: Jake S.

description: Got there around 8 and told we'd have about an hour wait for 4 people.  90 minutes later , still sitting out in the cold, waitress never brought us drinks. We watched over 20 seated before us. Finally seated were told out of bread by one waitress then brought leftovers by another.  Food was ok, nothing great although something smelled delicious.  Slow staff and only few tables for more than 2.  Not great.
author: Carol S.

description:
Good food, nice location, friendly service.

Parking could an issue and there isn't a public parking close-by.
Also since the Grace cathedral is only a block away, tourists may eat up the few nearby street parking spots.
We were really lucky to get a parking spot exactly in front of the cafe! 

I see most of the reviews are for the dinner menu. 
We ordered off of the brunch menu and it worked out pretty good to say the least !

I had the Louisiana Omelette with Andouille Sausage - and it was just perfect! Bell peppers, onions and cheese in the right amount. Omelette was fluffy and hands down yum! Most of the brunch items come with a Corn Muffin and I must say it was one of the best corn muffins I have had - fresh, fluffy & not too sweet - definitely to my liking.
My friend had the Lime Tequila Chicken Omelette - a slightly more lemony than expected - but it was pretty good nonetheless.

We also ordered a Ciabatta French Toast for the table. I must say that I have had better french toasts. (and probably why I took off one star). The Cinnamon Batter was slightly over-done for my taste.

All in all, a definite thumbs up !
author: Salil K.

description: We wanted to get seated for a party of 4 and we couldn't because our 4th person was not here. We were going to just order for our friend but it's against their policy which is lame. 3 of 4 people are here... Let us sit down and eat. I bet the food takes 20 minutes to get made. Stupid policy.
author: Young Y.

description:
Excellent Italian, tucked away on Taylor, and only two blocks from my house! YES!

In the shadow of Grace Cathedral, I stumbled upon this little slice of heaven, and I'm absolutely on Cloud 9!
I came here with my parents one night that they were in town and we had the: bruschetta (simple, fresh, and so tasty!), the magherita pizza (it's a classic!), house made gnocchi (ALMOST AS GOOD AS NONA'S!!...almost) and the carbonara (bacon, eggs, and pasta. 'Nuff said). Everything was excellent! The pasta was all fresh and it tasted like good home cooking!

**My one complaint: The pizza didn't have that crisp crust I love that comes from a wood fired oven. I don't know how it was baked, but the pie was a bit flat.

The tiramisu more than made up for the pizza disappointment, and an espresso to top it all off! 

Come early because sitting is tight, and they don't take reservations. Take advantage of the outdoor seating and the beautiful weather, and watch the neighborhood bustle by. Enjoy moderately priced Italian without having to deal with the North Beach overload.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I like this place because it is so cozy and I fell very well eating here. The bread with butter is delicious. For lunch we had a Crostini Di Polenta, Spaghetti a La Carborna and Tortellini Romana. Everything was delicious! 
We seated near to the kitchen and was not a smart idea. Was too much noise.
author: Valéria M.

description: Nob Hill Café has by far the best Italian food I have ever tasted, it is 5 star no doubt.  All the pastas, the pizza's , specials (lobster ravioli) were delicious! It is a very busy place and typically for lunch the wait is under 15 mins or shorterm however, for dinner on a Saturday night , it was just under 40-45 minutes. We got a really nice table at the back. The wait staff is extremely attentive and food came on time despite the dinner rush. I would recommend it over North beach Italian!
author: N J.

description: I love this place! Food is delicious and vibe is laid back. There is always a wait but it is worth it.
author: Ed J.

description: Delicious traditional Italian food, lucky we live a block away and we know better to order to go since there is always a wait!
author: Gio S.

description:
This place is Awesome! Just takes walk in's we waited 35mins but took a walk to La Beau Market on Leavenworth st to pass the time. (2 blocks)
I had the Gnocchi bolognese and shared a Tiramisu, can't fault either! 
Price was unbeatable for the taste and portions. Can't recommend enough.
author: Mitchee F.

description: While staying in the area we walked to the Nob Hill Café for dinner. Nice local place with a very small interior (Be prepared to wait / no reservations) Service was excellent. Reasonably priced menu items. Tried the highly recommended pizza and was not disappointed. One size (about 10") was a nice appetizer. Three entrées, all excellent -   Spaghetti alla Carbonara, Penne Bettola (penne w/vodka sauce) and a Tortellini Romana. All were nice sized portions. We finished the meal with an order of tiramisu which was good/average. We highly recommend the Nob Hill Café.
author: Reservation For 3.

description:
During the recent movie filming of "Hereafter" (Matt Damon, Clint Eastwood) in Nob Hill around Clay and Taylor, we rediscovered Nob Hill Cafe and had breakfast and lunch here while waiting to see Mr. Damon and Mr. Eastwood during the filming. 

What a quaint cafe that seems to be a neighborhood favorite - it's always packed at peak times for breakfast, lunch and dinner. I thoroughly enjoyed my brunch omelet with andouille sausage and other Louisiana accents, my marguerite pizza at lunch, and pasta with clams - yum!! 

And yes, the famous San Francisco twins all dolled up complete with hair and make-up and bright lipstick dine here twice a week, and they always sit at their special window seat. I love sitting at the cafe's window seats too to watch the foot traffic go by - of course, pedestrians also like to peak in to see you and what you're eating too! 

The cafe is on a neat little section of Taylor Street in Nob Hill next to a dry cleaner and a corner market surrounded by gorgeous Nob Hill homes - very charming! The service is nice, and the manager comes around to help serve food and chats with the customers too. Love it!
author: Maile N.

description: The food was very good, not great, but good. The building was very worn and not in great shape. Seating was cramped and the service was less than average. Not a bad dining experience, but way go here with so many options in SF?
author: Ira P.

description: The wait was an hour long in the cold. Big bowls of pasta served to my table, I got carbonara and it was so rich, creamy and delicious. It just got to be too much cream by the time I got to the bottom of the bowl. Also it was bland when it got to the table. I had to add salt, pepper, cheese, and chili flakes to flavor it up. Same went with my friend's clam linguini, bland! Polenta appetizer was really yummy, baked and hot! My friend's rigatonni sausage pasta in red sauce was the hit of the table. It was good after seasoning, would I hike up the hill and wait an hour, no.
author: Karen T.

description:
Visiting San Francisco for the first time, staying in Nob Hill. Hotel staff recommended this place for a casual, but good meal. 

About a block away, as we walked past Grace Cathedral, we started smelling the garlic. Believe me, if you have any kind of Vampire problems, this is the place to come to fortify yourself with the amazing root herb!!

We stepped in, put in our name and came back out to wait with the rest of the crowd at the small tables on the sidewalk. While we waited the staff came our several times to get drink orders and update folks on their status in line.

Once seated we found ourselves surrounded by fellow lovers of real Italian food... wine, smile, hands moving, and laughter. The staff was attentive and happy to be there, desire the obviously demanding pace. 

We both ordered the pizza. We had a glass of wine each, and munched on the two different kind of bread they brought to the table while we waited for our pizzas to arrive.

The pizzas were wonderful; hot, spicy, cheesey, and complex flavors all blended together to delight our tastebuds. The crusts were well cooked and stood up to the job of being folded in half, from tip to crust, and being eaten that way.

We ordered the gelato expecting a small dish with a scoop or two of a Italian ice cream. Instead we were presently surprised when the waiter brought out a piece of our with an amazing 'crust' of stiffly whipped cream and sugar.

We recommend this place to anyone within walking distance. Fantastic food!!
author: Steve W.

description:
Wonderful food and ambiance !  Service was spot on and the food quick and delicious
Had the Caprese Salad and the Gnocchi with Tiramisu!
author: Jared B.

description:
You know what? Just go here and thank me later.  Seriously, I've been eating food since I was born, and I have to say, this is some of the best consumable carbon-based macromolecules you will ever come by.

All of the pastas here are simply killer, so my only suggestion is to order the carpaccio as an appetizer and then come up with some randomized way of figure out which pasta dish you're going to cross off your list of "best pastas ever stuffed into your face hole".

The unassuming little spot comes out of no where and the names isn't wildly indicative of what it is, but trust me, this place is amazing.  This is one place where I'd be willing to wait an unreasonable amount of time because the food and the service so great.  Plus, you never feel rushed, which probably explains the wait. 

Oh, protip: get the gelato, they make a cheesecake crust then fill it with the gelato then refreeze it, so you get a slice of gelato/cheesecake magic.  I got a mango with toasted coconut and almost forgave Mussolini for Facism by association.
author: Dan C.

description: Visiting from the Midwest, Italian family with access to great authentic Italian food at home-we took our San Franciscan son and his girlfriend to this darling restaurant for a special dinner. Cute and cozy atmosphere, friendly staff. We had a wonderful time. Unfortunately the food is priced well beyond its quality. We spent $300 for a VERY MEDIOCRE meal-tasteless over-cooked pasta and sauces, boring run of the mill salads. My 3 star rating is generous.
author: Kim V.

description:
I will never go back.

To sum it up: Please cut the asshole crap and let me enjoy my meal
Returnability: I would have been back every month
Superstar Factor: On the superstar scale, Nob Hill Cafe is the restaurant equivalent of a locally famous Mel Gibson. You're good at what you do, but, Lord, I just can't stand you and your prejudices.

First of all, this place is special to me. So like so many other failed relationships, I still want very much to love it like that first magical time. It was recommended to us by the concierge at the Fairmont and was therefore the first restaurant where my boyfriend and I tried when we moved to San Francisco years ago. So it means something. I'm, if anything, predisposed to liking it. But, there's really only so many chances I can give, because nobody likes an enabler.

We always order at least the carpaccio, which can be a bit lemon heavy, and the carbonara. I've had the tortellini, veal and gnocchi, all of which I enjoy. We like the lasagna, too. The caprese and polenta apps are good, too. 

Since the food was good, naturally we try to return as often as possible. So, we've managed to make it back on birthdays, anniversaries, and many random nights out. Our experience tended to be very up-and-down. For a while we couldn't put our finger on why. The food was pretty consistent (sometimes a little lemony). Then we realized that it was the service. Every time that our server was the blonde lady, we had a fantastic and special evening. Pretty much every time our server was the guy with the accent, we had a miserable time and lousy, brusque service. 

Before looking at the other reviews, I could not figure out what it was. Then thinking back on it, the only time we had good service from the male server was with a mixed crowd of white people (the bf and I are Asian). Coincidence? I certainly, certainly hope so. 

Suffice it to say, I will, very regretfully, not be returning to the restaurant anytime soon. Maybe once more on our next anniversary with the hopes that we merely caught a string of randomly occurring very bad days. However, if we ever go back, we will most certainly ask for the blonde server.
author: Jess C.

description: Excellent food and service. Delicious. I would highly recommend this restaurant, we were only in San Francisco for a few days and ate here twice. Added bonus you can avoid the killer hills if you are staying at The Fairmont Hotel.
author: Linda M.

description: Great neighborhood cafe. Very charming, great friendly service. We loved the margerita pizza.
author: Kyle M.

description: We had dinner here one evening while in town for a conference. The service was amazing and the food was tasty. The homemade rosemary focaccia bread is amazing.
author: R C.

description: Great out-of-the-way place that can be crazy busy sometimes, but worth the wait. And if you're walking up from the Castro area you'll get your exercise in as well!
author: Bryan B.

description: Id go back but it wasn't my favorite Italian. My friend and I waited an hour and 20 minutes for the table, but it was Sunday on a holiday weekend so I guess that happens. We split the pesto tortellini which was good but not amazing. We also got the gnocci bolognese which had a lot of ground sausage. The flavor was good but fennel was overpowering. The gnocci had a nice soft consistency. Also had the house wine which tasted like it had been open a couple days. Everyone was nice and the place was cute.
author: Julie M.

description:
Came here at 6pm last Saturday and was so lucky to be seated right away.  I heard this place gets packed and the wait can be super long. 

For apps we got the caprese salad and bruschetta.  The bruschetta toast was perfect... it was garlicky, buttery, crispy... and when you bite into it the tomatoes didn't fall everywhere.  I was amazed!!  Usually, once you bite into a cristini, the toppings fall off everywhere... but it wasn't the case here. 

For mains, we shared the Coppa Salami pizza (one of their specials).  It had coppa salami, fontina, gruyere, and arugula.  One bite and we were both doing the happy dance.  The salty cheese and salami went well with the bitter bite of arugula.  Happy tummies for sure!  We also shared the spicy penne with added pancheta.  Nuff said.. YUMMMM! 

With all of our apps, food, and two glasses of wine, it came out to $50 without tip.  SOOOOOO cheap!!!!!  I would recommend this place to anyone. Service is very direct and to the point.  If you like that, then you'll love it here.  I'm more of a personable person, so I like to have some sort of courteous interaction with the wait staff, but its really to the point business here with the waiter we had.  My date loved it, while I was too shy sometimes to ask for his attention since he was always whizzing by super fast without a smile. 

We were still thinking about the awesome food the next day.  Planning my next carbo load already!
author: Vicky T.

description:
This is a true neighborhood gem...

So many things I love about this place, but a quick summarized list:

1. Wait for a table? Have a drink outside on the sidewalk while you wait. Ok!

2. Delicious rosemary foccacia right as you sit down? Yessir.
