3.  Absolutely reasonable prices in an expensive neighborhood/city? You bet.

4. Ridiculously delicious, creamy, pancetta-y carbonara? Oh yes, I'll have two.

5. Pretentious atmosphere? Not here. 

Nob Hill Cafe feels honest and genuine. You never feel like it's trying to be anything it isn't. It's solid, inexpensive, CONSISTENT, honest Italian-fare, that benefits from great service and attention to quality.

It has become our go-to spot when we don't feel like cooking, or simply feel like going somewhere that's almost as cozy as home.
author: Will S.

description: It's solid Italian food with a great ambience and, most important, very little wait. My neighborhood place for an impromptu dinner.
author: M. M.

description: Meals are outstanding. You need to make a reservation for dinner. Service is great and they are always busy.  I love their salads along with pasta and pizza. They do have daily specials on their black board.  Nice neighborhood addition.  Giving a 3 for the wait and host - 4/5 for the food.
author: Stephanie C.

description: It's fine. Nothing to write home about, but a totally legit option if you're nearby and hungry for Italian.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
**Sept. 17 - Dinner**

If I could give this place a negative rating - I would gladly do so. 

My sis, Mom and I all walked in and the place was packed for a Saturday night. It was a given and we knew that. 

However, their was a party of four Caucasian group seating outside and the lady said out loud: "they're going into this restaurant dressed like that?"

WHAT?! I just didn't hear that - did I? Oh hell no!? 

To all you real SF folks, my sibling and I were wearing our puffy jackets (Patagonia and Marmot if you need to know the brands) and my mom in a black sherpa like hoody all with jeans and flats. We weren't wearing anything scandalous! 

My sis checked inside and came out...and I told them what happened. 
My mom stared at the lady while we stood outside and my sis said out loud: "Please, it's not like it's Gary Danko. For crying out loud, we ate the Boulevard dressed like this..." Mind you, my mom was still staring at this point. Lady didn't say crap!

The hostess called us in and told us to wait inside since my Mom was diabetic and she needed to eat bread and drink juice. 

By then all of us were fuming. 

We got seated... in what my mom would say: the grungy side of the restaurant (near the kitchen) and the "nicely dressed folks" were seated by the bar. 

Their were two servers: one blonde and one douche bag... oh my bad, one "Italian" server that looked and acted like he hated everybody that walked in the restaurant and by no means did he hide it. 

He took our order... no hello or what not. Douche bag server forced me to order for my sis who's out with the nanny taking care of the nephew. Apparently, my sis had already talked to the hostess telling her our situation: 2 people will switch to be with the baby and so the food needs to come when the other two is done so the food won't be cold.

However, douche bag server could care less. I went up to him and the conversation went like this... he was standing with the other blondie server and the hostess near the bar:

Me: (tap tap on the shoulder - gently) "excuse me sir, can you please hold the Linguine Aglio Olio pasta for my sister?"

Douche bag: "NO! I can't hold it. Kitchen is closing!" (this is where he wanted to stab me with his killer looks)

So I return to our table and told my family what happened. My mom told me to take a chill pill and let it go. 

However, my dad pointed out a good fact: if the kitchen was closing, then why where there five or more "WHITE" parties coming into the restaurant? Why aren't the kitchen closed for them but for our party, it was?

WTF?

By then, we were on fire. It was fueled more by our douche bag server literally dumping all our pasta in our table. It was a small table and their dishes aren't really the smallest so there we were, all trying to fit all those damn pasta in that table and being rushed by him. He didn't even bother taking away our appetizer plates and didn't give my mom a steak knife for her veal!

Lesson learned: 
1. Don't go here if your party is full Asian. You need to add a token white person to blend in the crowd.

2. Don't you dare dress up. The most expensive dish is the veal and it was $18 - please. My mom said it was so hard.

3. If you see two servers and one is the blonde, ask for the blonde not the Italian douche - it'll ruin whatever experience you're thinking you'll have in this place.

To the owner/management of this place: my family and I have been to a lot of restaurants in the city and around the continental US and even internationally -- more expensive and more luxurious than your restaurant... BUT we've never been racially profiled until your place!

Please teach your token male server that was working there on Saturday, Sept. 17 around 9 pm some manners. If he hates serving "colored" people like my family then he's in the wrong business and wrong city. Tell him to try Alabama! 

Last: to all you reading this review... I rarely bring the racial card but this restaurant made it quite evident that they were being racist to us. Therefore, if you're Asian and want to experience first hand what my family and I went through... go on weekends at night and seat where that douche serves. If you're really craving Italian... FIRENZE... doesn't even compare to this junk.
author: Cath M.

description: What a great find a top a very steep hill I had to climb in San Francisco - it was worth it! Joined two friends for lunch while we were visiting the city. Hot here a little early and even though the restaurant was totally empty the waiter would not seat me. After the small awkward blip however the rest of the meal was amazing! We got three plates with the intent of sharing. One gnocchi - this was delicious and had an amazing cream sauce; 2 was the ravioli with one of the best pesto sauces I've had; and 3 was the spicy pasta rigatoni also quite tasty! It was a really nice day so we enjoyed the food outdoors. Service was actually impressively quick and with great presentation and taste. I don't live in the area but I would frequent this place a lot if I could. It's the perfect spot for a great Italian meal - and by the way the restaurant inside smells amazing!
author: Demetra T.

description: Went here on a saturday, but there was only a 30 min wait for a table. The place was small and intimate. The food was good and not to pricy!
author: Marcus J.

description: Great local Italian restaurant!  I live nearby and walk past this restaurant several times a week, and it's always busy during peak hours.  My suggestion would be to come early.  Their Penne Bettola is my favorite - it's like a spicier Penne Alla Vodka.  I've also had their pesto gnocchi and eggplant parmesan, although my go to order is the Penne Betolla and polenta appetizer - both of which are great.  The service is friendly, the food is good, and overall this is a winner.
author: Zach S.

description:
Been here three times, twice for brunch and once for dinner and the experiences have been uneven. I don't quite understand why they're always so busy because the food seems pretty mediocre to me. It looks like a nice little neighborhood place and I really wanted to make it my go-to joint for Italian food since it's a block from my house, but the food simply doesn't live up to expectations. 

I had the grilled prawn and avocado omelette for brunch both times. The first time, it was really good but the second, it was way overcooked. I also tried the ciabatta french toast. The bread didn't soak up enough of the custard and it was dry. 

For dinner, I had the gnocchi. It was way overcooked; the texture wasn't light or fluffy, but rather mushy. Toward the end, the plate was a mess as the dumplings simply disintegrated into the sauce. I tried my friend's clam linguini and it was bland. 

All in all, the food here is uneven and simply not worth the wait.
author: Alice W.

description:
Came here while on vacation in SF on a friend's recommendation and very glad we did! The veal piccatta was amazing - especially the pasta that comes with it! The rosemary bread they bring to the tables is to die for, and they make it from scratch right there. 

Be prepared to wait for a table as they don't take reservations. We waited 45 minutes on a Saturday night, and weren't seated and eating til 9pm, but they'll let you order wine on their front patio to make up for it. The inside is small, but once we were seated it didn't really matter. 

Also don't order the misto appetizer plate unless you're really into raw veggies. We thought it'd be more prosciutto/mozzarella but there was only one piece of each and then a bunch of uncooked vegetables...great if you're into that kinda thing...just not what we expected. 

Overall, great place for a nice dinner!! And the service is wonderful!
author: Megan P.

description: Possibly one of the best places in SF, located in one of my favorite neighborhoods in the city. Great old fashioned Italian food, with cosy atmosphere and well-done professional service.
author: Nave A.

description:
There is always a line - make sure to stop in early, put your name down, walk around Nob Hill, then come back. 

I live right next to this restaurant and am glad I finally gave into the hype to see what was going on. It's super small, so if you are claustrophobic, you may want to think twice. We were seated after an hour (put my name down first) and bread/water was brought quickly. They've got a lot of great wines to kick off the dinner, but I decided to get a beer. 

I tried one of the Penne pastas + chicken meat, and was impressed. It was very delicious and prices were reasonable. 

I'd gladly eat here again when craving Italian.
author: Albert K.

description: This is such a wonderful place.   The food is great.  The staff is very friendly.  I've eaten here at least a dozen time and every time has been great.  It's not a very big place, but somehow they always manage to turn the tables and keep the wait short.  The only drawback is that they don't take reservations, but at the same time that makes it easy to swing by at the last minute and not worry that they're already full.  If it's nice out, you can sit outside with a glass of wine while you wait for your table.
author: Greta R.

description:
Such a lovely little gem. I grew up in a family where my friends didn't want to go out to eat, they wanted to come over to my house for dinner, so its a bit hard to impress me with Italian food. This place is a little taste of home!

The gnocchi is just outstanding--by far my favorite pasta on their menu, but its safe to say you cannot go wrong with your choice. So if you love carbo-loading as much as I do, this is the place to go. Not only is their food incredible, but the place itself is cute and quaint with an open kitchen.  Reminds you of a little place found in the streets of Italy.
author: Nicole M.

description: A really great little place to have lunch. I can't remember the dish I had but it was some sort of sea food pasta and it was amazing. Just good quality pasta and a good casual atmosphere with excellent service.
author: Mark D.

description: This little neighborhood restaurant was quite a nice find. We stay quite often at the Mark Hopkins and take a nice stroll to the Nob Hill Café for lunch or dinner. It is very quaint and the food is awesome. It can get crowded in the evenings but worth it. Seating is cozy but that adds to the ambiance. Very nice staff working there even though they get very busy they stay calm. In the evenings, they won't let you sit in the outside front patio/sidewalk area because the "Old Lady" upstairs may dump a pot of water on you if the noise gets to loud. Not sure if its true but I'm going with it is because it just adds that much more to the Nob Hill Cafes romance. Overall you get your monies worth and probably more because of the atmosphere.
author: B D.

description: Nob hill cafe is my favorite neighborhood Italian restaurant in San Francisco. I used to live right next door and would eat there at least once a week and would love to take friends and out of town visitors there. Good food, casual but fun atmosphere, and decently priced. The house wine is a good deal. Calamari salad is yummy as are many of the baked pastas.
author: Karan K.

description: One of the few restos on Nob Hill that is not operated by a hotel.  Small, two room Italian that has a few specials and the core pasta and pizza choices.  The wine list is surprisingly fair.  They were extremely kind to my father-in-law who required special care.  Unfortunately we had to wait outside for a table and being summer it was quite cold...
author: Phil G.

description:
Still as fabulous as i remember. Intimate Italian eatery..full of warmth.

We enjoyed our meals and service was stellar.
Veal Piccatta for me ( so good ) 
Mr Man had the Gnocchi ( loved it ) 
We plied ourselves with Chianti as we savored every bite and chatted about our great day.

Chocolate Ganache ( my fave ) for dessert with glasses of tawny port.

We waddled out sated, and smiling .
author: Denice Z.

description: Excellent food and service !! Cute little place with incredible pasta :) def recommend
author: Chelsey P.

description:
I have been coming to Nob Hill Cafe for years, and it does not disappoint.  It is packed on Sunday with neighbors and local churchgoers, but the servers are welcoming and accomodating which makes for a pleasant experience.

I had the Frittatta Putanesca, which was Baked Eggs with Fontina Cheese, Pancetta, Bellpeppers, Mushrooms, White Onions, Capers and Fresh Herbs.  Alas, I think that they forgot the herbs or were a little underhanded.  I ended up stealing greens from my neighbors plate to provide some much needed freshness to this dish.

Husband had the Louisiana Omelette with Andouille Sausage, Bell Peppers, Roasted White Onions, Tomatoes Mozzarella and Provolone Cheese which is served with a corn muffin and rosemary potatoes.  I am not a huge fan of the muffins - I think that they are dry.  The omelette, however, is perfect - spicy meat + crunchy veg = love.  Mom had the Prawn-Avocado Omelette with Black Tiger Prawns, Fresh Spinach, Avocado, White Onions Mozzarella and Provolone Cheese which was served with salad and that muffin.  I really liked this omelette - TONS of spinach and shrimp, both of which were excellent.  Dad had the carbonara which was a well-executed preparation of the classic egg, cream, and pancetta laced pasta.

You can't beat the coffee here.  I would not trek across the city to check it out, but it is a solid 3.5 stars and worth a stop if you are in the neighborhood and you are hungry.
author: Stephanie B.

description: Dont get the pizza. Food is average italian fare but whatever you do end it with Chocolate chip gelato. I am going back just for dessert!
author: Dan A.

description: A wonderful restaurant. Especially if you are staying at a hotel at the top of the Hill, Fairmont and Mark Hopkins. It's a short walk and you don't have to walk up or down any of those steep hills! Service was excellent and the food was delicious; all for a reasonable price.
author: Raymond W.

description:
Excellent Italian food.  

Simply but very good home style flavors and cooking with generous portions and reasonably priced.

We enjoyed the Pesto and the Carbonara and the bolognese gnocchi was very good as well.

If you are looking for a quality meal for the family I would highly recommend Nob Hill Cafe.
author: George W.

description: Loved it! I really enjoy a romantic little restaurant that is both big and small. Big because it can accommodate a good number of patrons but small because it felt like they were catering to us alone. The overall experience here is amazing with good food and ambiance to match. We love Italian food and Nob Hill Cafe has good food. Ordered pasta and an individual pizza with a caprese salad on the side. We really enjoyed the food and the prices are very reasonable for the area. They have several tables outside if you prefer. Come check it out for yourselves!
author: Michael D.

description:
I love this place. Classic neighborhood italian place with rotating specials, good wine, and a menu that you can always revisit. It reminds of this place Anchovies in the South End in Boston. 

It's a great place for a Friday night. Good friend. Good wine. Good hearty food. Good prices. 

I am a huge fan.
author: Paul I.

description:
Pleasantly surprised, no fuss, descent plates. We shared the veggie mozzarella platter for two--great spread of crisp crudités and some nicely sautéed veggies that tasted just like real vegetables! We also shared the homemade gnocchi a la carbonara - sucker for homemade pasta. The carbonara was as dirty delicious as it gets, with LOTS of bacon in a rich thick cream sauce. 
Even the house bread was good-I woke up thinking about it! The neighborhood joint can be delicious!
author: Gina P.

description:
The only way that Nob Hill Cafe could be any better would be if the sundried tomato pesto rigatoni with sausage special from last night was on the regular menu.

But even if that doesn't happen...I love you so much, NHC.
author: Ashley T.

description: Firstly, we waited two hours just to be seated and order our food. There was only one hostess trying to handle all the customers waiting and nowhere for them to wait. We thought it would be worth it so we waited anyway. Once we were seated we had to ask for water and bread. Our server was completely inattentive. I don't know wether she was just a bad server or just so busy with everyone else. They definitely need more staff. I overlooked these minor details hoping the food would make up for it. I had the special seafood linguine and it was not memorable in the least. And the tables were all so close together it was very awkward having a conversation. I left feeling scammed. I'm going to add that I noticed most of the people who give this place rave reviews are from out of town. SF locals expect a much higher standard for food especially with the competitiveness of Italian restaurants here.
author: Christopher J.

description: Outstanding lunch near Grace Cathedral. The fig and feta pizza from the special menu was wonderful. My husband had the gnocchi which was divine. Our three boys were also pleased. I would go back here in a heartbeat!!
author: Rebecca T.

description: Very disappointed. No where near an Italian meal. American imitation of Italian food. Meal was just edible. Over priced for very little effort. Will not be returning.
author: Keeley C.

description:
I love this place. It has good food, good staff and they remained consistent in the quality of the dishes offered. I've been going here for lunch or dinner for about 9 years now- that is a long time to account for and still say I have never been disappointed. 
Try the veal cutlets or the Petrale sole.
author: Ana D.

description: Popped in here by chance - followed some locals. Great atmosphere, friendly service, slightly sourdoughy bread appetizer, carbon era sauce made on the spot, tangy clam linguine - overall it was a lucky great find
author: Antonio I.

description:
I really need to stop sleeping on my reviews, surprised i missed this one.

This is one of my favorite restaurants for italian food.  Its small, its cozy, and the food is not only more than affordable, its consistently good.  Ive never been disppointed, whether it be the insalata caprese, the crostini di polenta, chicken parmigiana, linguine alla vongole, or their spaghetti carbonara, its all always delicious.  Sample a couple of their different cheesecakes for dessert, a perfect ending to your meal.

I agree that it can be a little annoying with how long the wait is at certain times, but keep in mind it is a small restaurant that does not take reservations.  Also keep in mind that this is not the best place for big parties, if there are 4 or more people in your group, your wait could be even longer.  The staff try their best to get people seated as soon as possible, and while you're waiting outside they are more than happy to bring you glasses of wine to make your wait a little more tolerable.  

My advice is try to go earlier in the evening, around 6:00-7:00 to cut your wait time down, otherwise dress very warm because that San Francisco breeze will have you shivering if you're not prepared.  Be patient, sit and enjoy a couple glasses of wine, IMO its worth the wait.
author: Juv C.

description: Serviceable food with hit or miss service. If you're a party of three they may shove you into a table clearly meant of two people. A little insulting.
author: whatever I.

description:
I've been here 3 times in 3 years, and I've never been disappointed by either the food or the service.   Yesterday my son and I a light lunch - Prawn & Spinach Omelette for me, and a Crab Omelette (a special for the day) for my son.  Both were sensational and impeccably prepared.  No surprise, even the worst meal I've had here was still very, very good.

So, if I like it so much, why only 3 visits in three years?  Did I mention that I'm from Boston, and only get to SF once a year or so?
author: Larry S.

description: Fabulous food, tables very close together, friendly professional staff. Worth a trip just to smell what's coming from the kitchen.
author: Terri S.

description:
Food is average. Watch out for the Irish male waiter! He will sneak up on you and the next thing you hear is the twist cap of a $40.00 bottle of nasty white wine. He intimidates you into accepting this awful swill. It won't even be the wine you ordered!

He is a real piece of work! Best advice, if he is your waiter order an over priced bowl of watery soup and run for your life, after paying with bare minimum tip of course. He seems to be Eastern European trained and that speaks for itself!

The blond woman wait person is a joy! I only have sweet service from her.
author: Willy L.

description:
Went here with my husband on our honeymoon. We only waited about 10 minutes on a Monday night. The service was excellent!! Every server who spoke to us was polite and helpful. 

My husband had the lasagna and enjoyed it, although it wasn't the best he's ever had. I had the fettuccini pesto with chicken. Very yummy and filling. 

Overall really great experience. Only $36 for both of our meals. I would return if I'm ever in the area again.
author: Valerie D.

description: Excellent food, great service and cute atmosphere. Moderately priced. Gets very busy!
author: joan d.

description:
This place is BOGUS. Their recipes for basic italian dishes are weirdly constructed (no breadcrumbs on chicken parmesan? WTF) and the alfredo sauce was completely inedible/overly buttery. That said, I gave this place two shots and was disappointed both times (with a 4 month spread).

Skip this place and go to cafe macaroni!
author: S L.

description:
An old time favorite that I should think about going to more often.
Take a taxi, parking is difficult at best.
author: Leonard H.

description:
Why is this place popular?  Do San Franciscans not understand what italian food is?

First, they serve "creamy pesto" on all their pastas.  "Creamy pesto" appears again and again, all over the menu.  

There's no cream in pesto!  "Creamy pesto" is as Italian as the orange powder packet you find in a box of Kraft Macaroni & Cheese.

Second, my pasta was overcooked mush, the consistency of baby food.  Nob Hill Cafe is unfamiliar with the term "al dente." 

Great pesto and al dente pasta are easy to get right.  I can't believe a well-liked restaurant in a great location fails to grasp these basic concepts.

San Franciscans, wake up!  Real Italian food is delicious and amazing!  You deserve better than Nob Hill Cafe!
author: Victoria P.

description:
I met up with an out of town friend for dinner and sometimes it's a lot of pressure to try and pick a restaurant that reflects the amazing food we enjoy on a regular basis in SF. I was pleasantly surprised with choice to dine at Nob Hill Cafe. 

The cafe is really cute and has a warm cozy feeling (guess that's almost everywhere in SF though ;) ). The food was some of the best Italian I've had in awhile. The linguine with clams was perfectly cooked and the fresh bread was delicious. We couldn't resist sharing some tiramusu for dessert and it was probably the best tiramusu I've ever had.

I can't wait to try brunch here!
author: Leanne S.

description:
Lots of great things going on at Nob Hill Cafe:

1)  Outdoor seating while you wait.  Our wait time, at about 8:30pm on a Saturday, was about twenty minutes.  Totally reasonable.  Tea and drinks were offered as well.

2)  Prices are very fair -- most entrees are $15, which is considerably cheaper than most well-reviewed restaurants in the neighborhood.

3)  Delicious food.  I enjoyed the best gnocchi I've had in over a year, and the portion sizes were large enough for take-homes.  I also enjoyed a few bites of a very fresh calamari and bean salad.

4)  Service was fast and extremely helpful.  The calamari salad came within minutes of our ordering, and entrees came just a few minutes after we finished the salad.

I'd highly recommend to friends and family visiting the area.
author: Bill H.

description: Went for the clam linguine. Big portion, can be eaten by two people. The atmosphere and surrounding neighborhood was great, however I'm not sure what I have eaten. The clam was over powered by the sauce and there is no distinct taste of the clam. Maybe the clam should have kept in the shell cover or Cooked/ steamed separately.
author: John C.

description: A giant MEH for the Nob Hill Cafe. I've eaten here twice because of friends' desire for 'simple Italian,' but I have not found any dish that I have found particularly enjoyable. I find it crazy that there's always a wait when I walk by, especially given that there are so many other Italian restaurants in the area. The food is not authentic, and it seems to be catered towards a more alfredo-sauce-loving clientele. My least favorite dish was the Linguine alla Vongole. Totally fishy and the clams were definitely of the cheap canned variety. The pasta sauces are bland and the appetizers are very simple. This restaurant also leaves that greasy restaurant smell on your clothes and hair which is one of my biggest pet peeves. The next time my friend wants to eat here, I think I'll have to put my foot down.
author: Regina L.

description:
I was honestly really excited about this restaurant after reading all of the reviews.  Two friends and I were planning to go to a nearby Italian restaurant, but when we arrived and learned the wait would be an hour, we called over to Nob Hill Cafe and were told the wait would be 20-25 minutes.  Hungry, we walked over, put our name in, and sat down at a table to wait outside.  

20 minutes passed, and we kept waiting,  Then 40 minutes.  We began to notice that parties our same size who arrived after us were being seated.  The hostess came out and assured us that our table was "getting up to leave" so we would be seated shortly. Five minutes later, she came out, not making eye contact with us, and called another party our same size that had arrived a half hour AFTER we did. (What was going on here? Rich regulars?) 

We waited some more (and did I mention it was COLD outside)?  Finally, an hour after we put our name in, the hostess came outside to collect us.  A total of 4-5 other parties who had arrived after us were seated before us.  

I politely asked if there was a reservation system we had missed, as other parties were seated before us.  I was told that this was "how the system worked," as she had our name under this table, and the people who had this table "took forever to leave."  My group is pretty easy to please--to be honest, a complimentary cappuccino to warm us up would have smoothed everything over.   But she did not apologize or offer any kind of deduction.  

The server brought bread (not served warm) to the table, with pats of butter wrapped in foil.  We were seated right inside the front door, with two open windows that blew in cold air, so I was pretty uncomfortable during the meal--I never took my jacket off...and never thawed out from that hour wait outside.

The food: 

We ordered the calamari salad, which was decent, though the beans were undercooked.  The bruchetta was good.

I ordered the spaghetti carbonara, which was tasty, though very rich (think a pool of oil at the bottom of the bowl). It was served hot, though, which was great--the bowl doubled as a hand warmer to help with the cold air blowing in through the windows.  One friend ordered the pesto, which was not bad, and the other ordered the veal piccata, which was much too lemony.  We all agreed the carbonara was the best entree of the three.

One of my friends is Italian, and she said overall, the food was okay, worthy of 3 stars.  Given the situation with our wait time, I gave them 1 star on service, and averaged the two for the rating.

We should have stayed at the first Italian restaurant with the hour wait.  If you're an average yelper and not a wealthy regular of this place, I might suggest looking elsewhere...
author: Rachael S.

description: This place is really good!! Super small. The food comes out pretty quick. A little pricy, but not to bad. Our server took a little while to great us, even though she wasn't that bzy and she past our table a couple times ( I would know since I work in the service industry) but other than that everything was great!!
author: Katie B.

description: I really love Nob Hill's Gnocci Bolognese & get it every time I'm there.  Brought my son to lunch today and he had one of their specials.  He said it was good too.
author: Ferne F.

description: My sister and I were visiting San Francisco and came upon this place by chance and boy was I glad that we did. Nob Hill Cafe is this adorable cafe that felt very local in a nice location (if you walk though, be ready for a work out) . When we first arrived there was a small line outside for people waiting to get in, this is always a good sign. My sister and I put our name on the list to be seated and waiting about 10-15 minutes, during that 10-15 minutes though the hostess gave us menus and asked us if we would like a drink while we waited. She was very sweet and made sure that we were taken care of. Once seated we were given bread and given our drinks quickly. I had a glass of the house red which was nice and warmed me up just enough for the walk back to the hotel. I ordered the chicken with mozzarella and parmigan melted on top  and it was probably one of the best meals I have eaten in San Francisco. The cheese was fresh and balanced the chicken and tomato sauce out wonderfully. My sister enjoyed her meal and said that it was delicious. All of the the meals being served looked divine. I would definantly go there again.
author: Melynda D.

description:
Ordered the gnocci, with insalata mista.  Food was fantastic,though the wait was long for a table (sunday night) ordered the house chianti, which was ridiculously priced at $12/glass
Order the wine by the bottle!
author: Mark S.

description: This little hole in the wall was so amazing! My boyfriend and I decided to walk from our hotel in fishermans warf which probably was not the best idea.... Needless to say we were starving once we got there!! Staff was friendly, the place was so busy but we got there right in time to get a perfect table by the window! The bread was warm and the pasta was fabulous!! I can't wait to go back!!
author: Chelsea G.

description: First time to San Francisco in over 10 years. Stumbled on this place thanks to other Yelp users. We did make the mistake of trying to walk here... Lemme tell you, if you are staying at the Omni hotel, and you are kind of out of shape, call an uber. We made it about three blocks (right into Chinatown) before we started crying and then broke down and called an uber. So just call one. But by the time we got there... It was SO Worth it. My bestie and I ordered the Bruchetta and each got the Tortellini with Pesto. It was delicious. Seriously delicious. I would go back and eat more if I could. The only thing I would maybe change it the wine storage... I'm no wine snob (I leave that to my parents) but I could definitely tell that bottle had been opened for a while. Overall, the next time I'm in the city, I would totally go back. The service was great, food delicious and it was a nice and quiet atmosphere. 5 stars for sure!
author: Brooke L.

description:
I go out to eat quite often here when I'm going to a show in the Nob HIll area. They have excellent quality Italian food.

Last night my guest and I were asked to hurry and finish our wine and leave as people were waiting for a table. I've NEVER had this happen to me before. Never. Anywhere.

With wine and dinner we spent close to $130, and then we were asked to hurry with our wine and leave? This is not the Olive Garden.

Never going back again. Never.
author: Steven C.

description: RUDE employees, walk in cook shakes his head no, before closingthrowing the setups on the table. Won't ever return. These people LACK customer service skills.
author: Gabrielle D.

description: My husband and I are huge fans of Nob Hill Cafe. The food is delicious, all fresh, with pasta from scratch. The Gnocchi is perfect, as is the pesto. I am a creature of habit and always order the same thing, but my husband has had numerous items off the menu and been pleased each time. The pizza is his easy go-to. Service is always friendly, never rushed. There are two downsides, though. One: There is always a wait of around 30 minutes. Two: The restaurant isn't large, so their tables are very close to one another. Neither of these items bother us at all, but we would advise against visiting Nob Hill Cafe if you're looking for a quiet, intimate dinner locale. This restaurant is much more "your favorite local Italian place".
author: Lauren S.

description:
Yikes, my girl and I came to this place as a 2nd choice. Fino Restaurant was an hour wait, and we couldn't wait that long. We were finally able to go there the week after (see my review). However, it was a good thing since we got to experience Nob Hill Cafe.My girl and I walked from Post St. to Nob Hill Cafe. That is not that easy of a trek, but the small journey was worth it.

We get there and I liked the ambiance of the place from the get go. The host was real friendly. Got our names on the list and told us the wait. We are finally seated and I swear this place can be one of those restaurants that can be featured in one of those shows on Food Network.

Most of the entrees are less than $15. Keep in mind though, there aren't much choices. I was skeptical at first because of this. Also if you see the menu, most do not come with meat. You pay a bit more if you want to add chicken to any pasty entree. But it will still be less than $20.I order a rigatoni pasta with sausage dish that was on the special menu that night. My girl ordered the Linguine alla Vongole (baby clams, white wine lemon sauce).As we wait for our food the complimentary bread was delicious. There was one bread in the bunch in particular. It was of a really good muffin consistency. We were eager to ask for more, but we have learned from our many years of eating out to have self control to save room to really enjoy the main course.

So we get our food and I will admit I was surprised at the portions. Our dishes were only about $13 each, and I was expecting pretty small portions. However my fat ass was able to get stuffed. If I wasn't so fat I would have been "satisfied" with some left over. But, I just continued to eat until I put it all away, then helped my GF finish hers. Everything tasted fresh and clean. When I say "clean", it just didn't taste processed or premade like low rated restaurants. The rigatoni dish I ordered is not on the regular menu, but I will recommend it if you see it. My GF's dish I must caution that when they say white wine LEMON sauce, they mean it. The distinct taste of the lemon is there. It may be overwhelming to some, but it was something new and I welcomed it. The baby clams offset some of the sour for a perfect combination.

In the end, we had a surprisingly great experience here and would definitely come again. Staff was all friendly and right on top of everything even though it was a full house and what seemed like limited staff. Value was extremely good with great tasting food.So if your first choice is not available, this is a very good alternative and you'll find it perhaps your first choice in the future like we did.
author: Eugene N.

description: Great spot in a wonderful area. The staff were very attentive and great food. I would definitely recommend if you're visiting the area. Only limitation is the size of the restaurant
author: Christy R.

description: This place is awesome! It is simple basic Italian-style food very classic. Delicious appetizer, worth waiting!
author: Lynn Y.

description: Will pronounce their spaghetti carbonara as...bland and frankly heavy. Has anyone ever noticed it's next to impossible to find street parking here?
author: Alfonso L.

description:
We saw the reviews on Yelp and we're looking forward to coming here for a Saturday night dinner. We waited for 40 minutes - the server was lovely - offered to bring us wine as we sat outside.

Unfortunately the only word I can use to describe the food that we waited for is 'disappointing'. The caprese salad was bland - none of the ingredients seemed particularly fresh and it lacked a large quantity of balsamic vinegar. We assumed the mains would redeem this place which was good enough to have queues outside... they didn't. We got two specials - the chicken pesto risotto was good but not outstanding, and the seafood linguine was again bland - impressive given the list of ingredients.
author: Charlie L.

description: One of our favorite spots.  The food is excellent and they will make your entree to order if they dont have exactly what you like.  The serice it great.  There is a crowd at night so be prepared.  Its a very intimate place.
author: Liz H.

description:
My friends and I were in town for business and try to eat at places in the neighborhood to get a local flavor.  Nob Hill Cafe was a great find.  We arrived on East Coast time feeling like lunch, but they were still serving brunch.  We sampled had items from both menus and appreciated the flexibility of choice.  The food was fresh and flavorful.  The service was quick and friendly, and the atmosphere was pleasant.  My friend who'd traveled to Italy said her meal tasted just as good as the ones she'd eaten in Italy. 

We recommended Nob Hill Cafe to a couple of colleagues who came in the next day and they were equally pleased.

A great find.
author: Carol A.

description:
Alas, Nob Hill Cafe, you left me no choice.

This place really has a lot to offer in terms of local neighborhood charm, good prices and romantic decor but my experience this past weekend was unforgivable.  My fiance and I were seated at a table for 2 around 8pm.  We ordered an antipasti plate, pizza and the veal osso bucco special.  We also brought our own wine and were charged a $20 corkage fee which was completely expected and is standard fare for San Francisco so no big deal.  Including tip, our bill was around $100 and we were mostly done with our entrees not long after 9pm.  

At this point, we noticed the busboys starting to aggressively remove items from our table which is usually to be interpreted as the restaurant wanting you to leave so that they can re-seat your table.  Since we were still in the process of finishing our wine, we remained seated and the manager came over to ask if we enjoyed everything.  We indicated that we had and that everything was very good.  She then said, "... OK, that's great, well, we really need the table."  In other words, "We don't care that you've only been here about 75 minutes (maximum) and spent $100, we want you to get up because we care more about making money than providing a pleasant, relaxed ambiance in which you can finish your meal at your own pace."

I've never been told to leave by a restaurant in my life, and I cannot excuse this.  It would have been more understandable had we simply sat down for coffee and dessert, but we had purchased an entire meal and were only occupying a 2-top.  To me, evicting your customers violates Restaurant 101 and I can't justify going back.
author: Mark G.

description: A small Italian cafe... Very quaint.  Food was good.  Ordered Tortellini and it was wonderful.  Great bread.  The reason for the 4 star instead of 5 is because the restaurant was very small, definitely not for large groups.  The restroom was very very small.  Could hardly move around in it and could use some cleaning.
author: Andrea P.

description: It's a very small restaurant. We were lucky. Right after we got seated, a line started to form outside the door. They make good Italian food. You can taste that everything was freshly made.
author: Shirley G.

description: I've eaten here 3 times. It's always been mediocre. I always want to like it. I always forget how bad it was, and every year it's: wash, rinse, repeat. I've had the carbonara twice, the flavors it does have aren't pleasant. My g/f got the lamb shank, braised. Braising is pretty much guarantee of tender anywhere but here. It was tough, the polenta tasted funny. I honestly wonder if the cook can taste things: everything is just slightly off. The staff is pleasant which is a plus. Insult to injury though, you have to wait 45 minutes to get a table, always. I'm still looking for a good italian place in the city. I'm going to stop going here.
author: Kendrick T.

description:
Live 1/2 block (500 feet) from restaurant and have visited several times.  Last night niece was in town with baby (infant) and went  ahead to get table.  Host (young lady) indicated there was a table available but could not seat me until all guests were at restaurant.  Explained situation but she would not yield.    Explained my wife and niece would be in restaurant a few minutes after I called (still not good enough) but indicated it was policy (don't seat until all present).

Restaurant owners need to train staff to be better at making judgment calls and customer service.  She was rude and moreover set my mood and view of the restaurant going forward.    Nob Hill cafe may be happy catering to out of town visitors but sure don't have much concern about folks in the area.  

Food was good (not excellent) and service was great.  Specials seemed a bit over priced for the items available. 

Have not given up yet but sure would be great to see a little more customer service.
author: Steve F.

description: We love this cute little neighborhood cafe! The food is outstanding and the Paggio Pinot Grigio is simply the best and the specialty pizzas are to die for. We were excited to be able to celebrate our first anniversary here as it was also the scene of our honeymoon a year ago! Don't miss this out of the way cafe! Delightful!
author: Randy Y.

description: Dinner before a show at the Masonic - a big splurge for us but worth it - everything was outstanding. It was Saturday night before Easter. We arrived just as the last tables were seated around 5:10 so we had a 40 minute wait. No problem, I had read all the online reviews so knew about no reservations, the rustic bread, prices, and popularity. We made the short walk to the corner to the lovely park. Nice and mellow with kids, people, dogs, and Nob Hill. Back at the restaurant we got a window table, I'd expected we might end up with the hallway table but nope, we got lucky. Our food came out hot (if you want to a quick meal, keep this in mind - took a while for the Pollo Alla Parmigiana to cool down ). Only snafu was minor- (efficient) waiter asked if we wanted pepper on our soup and then forgot. No worries. The café is small, busy, and fast. I figured if we asked for anything unusual or different it might be a problem. We reminded him about the pepper and it came some time later - soup was excellent either way.  My mantra the entire time was just enjoy and go with it. Paid off, I'd go back again but have to fill up my piggy bank first.
author: Jj M.

description:
If you needed a reason to love SF and a reason to move here.  This would be the reason.

Tucked away, this place had a bit of a wait. And sometimes, the hype isn't there. SF'ers will wait. And we did.  

We were here on a chilly evening, and managed to grab some seats outside when we waited 40 minutes for a table.  And the people waiting.. Literally, what are they smoking?! Because there were just little balls of great energy! Sweet. Chatty. Nice.  Even if the food wasn't good, the patrons made the night worth it.

Finally, when were seated in the crampness of this place, our Irish waitress with her smile just beaming was ever solovely... 

Ok. Stop right now, because all you need to know is one thing: Polenta.

The baked polenta dish literally made me smile and say. No more! I can handle no more such goodness.  The polenta was baked in this tomato ooziness with spinach, and cheese.  Literally, by far one of the most delectable things I have had in a long time.

And the meal only continued to get better..

The gnocci substituted with the pesto/romano sauce was delectable.  The original dish had all this meat, which was a bit too much.. But this way, it was veggie and the pesto was perfectly esto! Huge order, that I ended up taking home.

The penna bettola in a spicy tomato sauce was really delish.  Just enough sauce for that great kick to it!  And even better the next day.

And finally, the encore..

The spumoni gelato served on graham cracker crust.  Seriously?! Who are these people! Do they never want you to leave and try other italian restaurants.

Hands down.. this will make it on my lists of places, because it's something special.

Oh and the staff! With such a line they are hustling.  Kudos to Elaina for trying to keep the tables moving and the patrons outside happy.  Well done and Bravo!
author: Natalie G.

description:
This is my favorite spot in the neighborhood. I come here often and sometimes get takeout as well. My favorite item on the menu to order is the linguine alla vongole. It is delicious. I've ordered many other items on the menu and you can't really go wrong with any of the pastas.

When eating in you should note that the place does not accept reservations, and sometimes there can be a wait for a table. If you are waiting for a dinner table either order a drink and enjoy it outside or take a walk over to Huntington Park to pass the time. 

The staff is very nice, and will always bring bread and butter to your table before your meal is served. If you stop by for brunch or lunch there are a few tables outside that you can eat at on a nice day. Take advantage of this when the weather is good.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Back in my starving college-student days I made the "mistake" of walking in one afternoon and splurging on a bowl of pasta primavera & a cafe latte. I told myself it'd be a one-time treat. 

Both the pasta & the coffee were heavenly. I couldn't stop thinking about that meal. I would have talks with myself, reasoning why I couldn't return. That $12 for a lunch was far more than I could afford, especially on a repeat basis. Yet time after time I'd find myself walking back in, head down like a junkie heading into the heroin clinic, and order it up again. Thank goodness I eventually moved to Chicago after graduation. And thank it again that I'm back in the Bay Area as a solvent adult, ready for more Nob Hill Cafe!
author: Jen L.

description: Delicious, reasonable prices, good service. Totally go back if I could! Really enjoyed it!
author: Hila I.

description: LOVE this cafe. It's a tradition now I bring my friends and family visiting in San francscio here, it's lovely in the heart of Nob Hill. Great Italian food, I've had both lunch and dinner here. Delicious gnocchi bolognese and Caprese salad. Adorable place in a cute and quant neighborhood. Definitely a gem and great customer service. Cheers :)
author: Emmy L.

description: Wow this place is packed. I guess when you're the only game in the block you'd be too as long as you made solid food. Got the calzone and a margherita pizza. Pretty good, but Im not sure it warranted the wait some people were enduring even on a weeknight. We took our food to go and sat in the park down the way. I liked the flavors but it just didnt wow me. Now I've heard the pastas are good so perhaps it warrants a return to taste what's in their wheelhouse.
author: Kim N.

description:
Definitely a good convenient place to check out if you're in Nob Hill. Good tasty food, but a little pricey in my opinion. I definitely think it's a good place to go once with some friends, but the wait is terrible. Go early if you're going to go.  Love the Vodka pasta dish. Bomb diggity. 

Would give this place a 3.5, but can't on this rating scale...

Enjoy!
author: Michael C.

description:
I live right next store to this place and it is always busy, so I must be missing something. I have been here several times and it never hits the spot for me. 

They serve bread before your meal, but the butter comes cold and wrapped in foil (the worst!). 

I have had more than one of my meals there just taste flat, so I end up adding a lot of salt and I am dissatisfied. 

If you order anything, get something off the specials menu because they never change their regular menu. 

The best part is the ambiance....small, romantic, tucked away in a neighborhood.
author: Julie J.

description:
I have to admit that I haven't been here for almost 10 years.  

My wife and I went here about 10 years ago when we were staying at the Mark Hopkins Hotel.  She was pregnant and she was attending a work conference.  I tagged along.  This fine establishment is about a 1 1/2 blocks down from the Mark Hopkins Hotel as I recall.  It was so good we went there two nights in a row.  Small place but they break out the Christmas lights and it's a hot spot.  Food and wine were delicious.
author: Kevin W.

description: Absolutely amazing little Italian restaurant. The gnocchi is really great. Everything I got here was delicious and they have a great wine selection. This is a regular place I will visit whenever I am in the city. Yum!!!
author: Sarah M.

description:
1) Rude server. 
2) They usually don't take reservations but, I don't know why, today the tables outside were all reserved.
If they had given me the opportunity to reserve a spot, I would have done it.
Now I am here with my dog and still trying to find a place where both of us can eat.
author: Angie G.

description:
Honestly, every meal I have here makes me love it even more! The service is wonderful-you may wait and wait for a table but once you are seated they are always attentive, personal, and extremely helpful.

Their gnocchi is honestly to die for - last night the special was a red beet gnocchi with a four cheese cream sauce. Heaven. The gnocchi was creamy and slightly sweet (beets) and the cream sauce was perfectly tangy, creamy, and not too heavy.

I have tried to force myself to order something new every time I come which is incredibly hard because I always fall in love with what I ate the last time and want to order it again. So clearly I have yet to be disappointed. Last night my mother and I each had a delicious, perfectly dressed salad, shared the gnocchi, and shared their unbelievable, homemade chocolate ganache...more than enough food all of which was wonderful.

Price wise it is completely affordable, I always have leftovers, and they are generous with their delicious herb bread as well. Literally cannot say enough great things about this restaurant! 

Because they do not take reservations there is always a wait but plan accordingly and you are fine. Depending on which room you are seated in (both are tiny and tables are close together, but really who cares) it can be a bit loud depending on the amount of wine your fellow diners are enjoying. And the kitchen is open to one of the two rooms. But these things actually contribute to my love for this little gem because it is entirely unpretentious, perfectly cozy, all-around a pleasant dining experience.
author: Mari S.

description:
Really great place. We stopped in for a late lunch one afternoon and ordered a few pizzas and a couple of pasta dishes. Was super delish. I wish I could replicate the pizza I had here at home because it was one of the best I've ever had.

Thankfully it was a late lunch so we were able to be seated rather easily. But the place is uber small and it was a bit tight for five of us to sit around a table meant for four. I'd definitely go back though...great food!!!
author: Colleen C.

description:
You literally can't miss this place when you're on the block. A very local neighborhood kind of vibe to it. Didn't have to wait too long to be seated. 
I had ordered the Gnocchi Bolognese, which was new to me and it was great! The sauce was good and the potato dumplings were perfectly cooked! 

Highly recommend this place if they're looking for a cozy and local Italian place to have dinner!
author: Katherine L.

description:
This restaurant is missing some of the most critical elements of a pleasant dining experience.  The bread was spectacular, but it set high expectations for an otherwise disappointing meal.  The salad dressings (Caesar and honey mustard) were too heavy and smothered the flavors of the beautiful fresh ingredients in the salad (mixed greens, candied walnuts, cheese, and pears).  The mains we ordered (the squash and sage ravioli and Hawaiian pizza) were loaded with salt, again ruining beautiful, flavorful dishes. 

Moreover, the service was less friendly than I would have liked for a cute restaurant in a great neighborhood.  This restaurant has a lot of potential, but it's not quite there.
author: Vijay N.

description: Food is excellent.  This place is always busy, so expect a wait.  Lasagna and garlic bread were wonderfully simple and flavorful.  Service was below average but didn't overly detract from a great lunch.
author: Super T.

description:
I eat at the place on a regular basis. I love the casual atmosphere, the way they do just about everything well, and the no rush attitude (to push you out that is) of this place.

Let the buyer beware: This place can be popular, which may mean you have to wait. And you can't go wrong if you order pasta and a glass of wine (or a beer for that matter).

Most of the time, the service is impeccable, however, took the family there today for brunch and had lousy service...my guess is that the woman serving us (whom I have never seen before) must be fairly new. The kitchen staff was right on top of things...she was not! Nevertheless, I'll be back!
author: Ron C.

description: After reading the reviews i was hoping for a good if not great Saturday night meal.  We waited over an hour to be seated.  Husband ordered the lasagna and i had a waldorf salad.  Lasagna came out ice cold.  The bottom of my shoe would be more tender that they served me on the salad.  Very disappointed.  Won't be back
author: Laura M.

description:
I have been dining at Nob Hill Cafe for more than 15 years.  It remains one of my favorite intimate spots in the city. The food consistently falls in the good to outstanding range. I find their offerings to be fresh and seasonally appropriate.  The wine selection is average for a cafe of this type. Some of the deserts are just amazing.

If you are in the Nob Hill area, I suggest that you will be extremely pleased if you dine at Nob Hill Cafe. Parking can be challenging, the wait can be long, and the weather can be brisk (bring a jacket for your outdoor wait).  All that being said, this is still one of my top 5 picks for moderate dining in San Francisco.
author: Theresa K.

description:
What a treat Nob Hill Café was. 

I was in San Francisco on business for a couple days and while there, finally met a lovely friend I'd only known through email and Facebook for a little over a year. She suggested two places to meet for dinner, and I chose Nob Hill Café due to the proximity to my hotel and the awesome-looking Italian fare on their menu. 

The Yelp app provided great directions, and the photos helped me recognize it when the cab got close. The staff was absolutely fantastic -- I arrived before she did and they don't seat incomplete parties, but they hooked me up with a fabulous Sonoma Coast red wine and a chair while I waited. Even the server who helped me was also from North Carolina! 

Nob Hill Café is small and has tables which seat only 2 or 4 people, so timing is of the essence if you want to eat here during peak times. It was nearly empty when I arrived around 5:30 p.m. and started to fill up quickly. When my friend arrived later, we were able to get a table by the front door. We talked and talked forever before ever looking at the menu, but our server was very friendly and patient with us. At last we decided on the Fedelini alla Cecca, an awesome angel hair dish with tomatoes, basil and garlic. 

The service, food, wine, and atmosphere were all impeccable. I will absolutely eat here again!
author: Donna B.

description: This little quaint restaurant is a definite must, when in San Francisco. The food is absolutely delicious, tortellini with the pesto sauce is to die for- so much flavor. Also, For an appetizer, the Carpaccio is highly recommended. The waiters are very attentive and friendly...You won't be disappointed with this little gem! Enjoy!
author: Nadia M.

description: Really???  Visited every notable US city, and too many eateries that I SHOULD remember....  This is...  "Little Italy" food - at it's best - outside of the REAL San Fran Little Italy!  Multiple visits (twice in one week) with EQUAL fantastic service, food cooked right out in view, quiet, COZY atmosphere, and courteous service well beyond closing time. Obviously the equally continuous FLOW of first date kissing couple locals combined with foreign speaking tourist families  evidences something magnifico. You will HAVE TO wait - so expect it - NO REZ accepted.  But definitely worth the wait unless you're ADHD.  Best of all...,  NOTHING in SF beats price per quality.  A hidden gem and extremely recommended.
author: Chris S.

description: Delicious italian food right in my local neighborhood.
author: Catherine S.

description:
I was told about this place by a friend and my boyfriend and I decided to give it a try. After a long wait for a table (we came at a pretty busy time) we were seated by a wonderfully friendly waiter who took our order. I got the carbonara and the boyfriend got the chicken parm. 
I wanted to love this place, I really did. They had so many things going for them- friendly and helpful staff, great ambiance, very clean... but the food was just okay. My carbonara wasn't too tasty and was very greasy. The bacon in it was much too fatty and chewy, and the dish lacked flavor overall. The chicken parmesan fared much better. The chicken was nicely fried and the sauce was very tasty, but it wasn't a dish that would inspire me to come back.

Overall, I'd give it 3 stars. It was good, but it wasn't great.
Plus the parking was awful... but that's San Francisco for you.
author: Christie H.

description: Went here for a friends birthday dinner and the place is very quaint. I got the salmon chowder which was Ahhhhhmazing and a beer. Weird combo, I know. But the heart wants why it wants and who am I to argue?
author: Brittini S.

description:
Wow! I ate at Nob Hill Cafe once for lunch and once for dinner; lunch was good, dinner was amazing!

The restaurant is very intimate--only two small rooms, maybe a dozen or so tables. I had no problem getting a table for lunch, but for dinner on a Sunday night I had to wait around 30 minutes for a table. It was totally worth it! The bruschetta was crisp and the tomatoes were fresh, and the lasagna dish was one of the best I've ever eaten. My wife had a calamari steak which was cooked perfectly, as was the accompanying pasta and chickpeas. For dessert, we had a cheesecake with chocolate gelato and chocolate chips. If there wasn't a doily on the plate I would have licked it clean. I can't say enough good things about this restaurant, get you some.
author: Matt S.

description: Really loves this place! Had the risotto and buratta salad while my partner had the salmon. Service was attentive but not overbearing and everything tasted delicious, from the wines to desert. Will def b back!
author: Amanda T.

description:
OVERALL:3.0   FOOD:3   SERVICE:4   AMBIANCE: 3   VALUE:2
Expectations & appetites were high as a kite, and man was it a long, hard fall down to reality.  Went for late lunch/brunch, and based on all the rave reviews and our comparatively blah food experience, gotta assume the kitchen was just slacking on the tail end of their shift.  Dunno, it was such a huge letdown that giving them another try just seems....like such a chore.

GRILLED PRAWN & AVOCADO OMELET ($10.75):
Good flavors, OK quantity shrimp/avocado, TONS of spinach (yay!), but it was frozen (nay!), and wayyyyyy too much grease.  Rosemary potatoes were dry, unpleasantly hard (not crispy, HARD) and apparently missed the rosemary train...BLAND! And I usually get all kinds of excited over cornbread, but this muffin was dry, stiff, cold, and just not enjoyable at all.

SAUSAGE MUSHROOM PIZZA ($13):
Good if you like medium-thin crust, super cheesy, SUPER greasy slices.  Flavor was OK: standard italian sausage, ungrilled white mushrooms (boo!), and tomato sauce was good, but forgettable.  Not for me.

For these prices and almost rundown interior, I'd pass next time around.
author: Amy K.

description: Two successive nights, two different dining rooms, two opposite waiters. Night One, a Thursday: My family enjoyed a marvelous meal attentively served by a welcoming skilled waitress. Night Two, a Friday (We decided to go back for our last night in town, because of our Night One experience): When I explained that we were a party of three with my wife following closely behind, my son and I were curtly schooled in the policy, "We don't seat incomplete parties," and dismissed. A few minutes later when my wife arrived, we were seated in the diner-like side of the restaurant. On Night One we dined on the intimate Italian bistro side. The two sides could not have been more different. On the Italian side, the ambiance, food and service were superb. On the diner side, the atmosphere and service were breezy and the food was mediocre. We gave up our reservation at Boulevard for Night Two. I wish we hadn't.
author: Terry G.

description: Great neighborhood spot, and a fantastic meal. Very nice owner who was very welcoming. Penne alla vodka, chicken parmigiana, and the spaghetti with pesto were all phenomenal. Paired with a bottle of the house wine, it was extremely reasonably priced for the neighborhood. Will make this place a very frequent choice for a relaxing night out.
author: Karl K.

description: If you like Italian food, you'd like Nob Hill Cafe. Even though it's just a little hole in the wall, their food is good and comes in large portions. However it is VERY cramped and always packed. Also this is not a good place to bring large groups. Good Italian food.
author: Ethan P.

description: A perfect date spot for a romantic Italian dinner; this place is a must try for any Nob Hill resident. Share a pizza (I get prosciutto and spinach), an entree (I love the tortellini in Alfredo sauce) and a bottle of wine and you're night is set.
author: Michael H.

description: Second time being here. The first time was a very pleasant experience. This time was not so pleasant at all. My wife and decided to take my mother and my grandmother here for some good food. They were visiting from out of town. My wife had dropped my mother, grandmother and I off at the corner while she parked the car. We go into the restaurant and there were 5 tables open and we sat down at one. A server of some sort gave us menus and I informed we had one more person coming. My wife was parking the car. The server informed the manager or head server that our party was all here. The manger snatched the menus from us and said we can't seat you until all members of your party are here. She was very rude with her tone and manner in which she did this. I said this is stupid. I was very very upset because now we had to get up and my grandmother is 80 years old and doesn't move around very well and wait for my wife. If my wife hadn't been walking up as we were at the door we would have left. We sat back at the original table and told the original server that we were all here. They gave us a different server. As we were sitting and ordered our food. They sat a group of two women and we noticed that they were waiting another person. Interestingly enough they didn't get the same rude treatment. The server that we had the second time we sat down was very professional. The blonde manager needs a lesson in customer service.
author: Kristian M.

description:
I've gotten take out here several times mostly because it's on my way home and if I call in the order as I leave work, it's ready when I get there 15 minutes later! So far I have simply followed the recommendations of the waitress who answers the phone, first trying the Penne Bettola and then the Linguine alla Vongole, both of which were delicious and for under $13 each, with enough to share, they're a great deal!

The cafe looks adorable and I'm dying to try their brunch, but so far I haven't managed to muster up the courage to wait for a table for dinner. Not when their deliciously hot food travels so well :) The perfect dinner in on a cold and rainy night in SF. I recommend!
author: Emily S.

description:
Bottom Line: nice little americanized italian restaurant that really likes cheese.

This place is on a side street up in beautiful Nob Hill.  It has a quaint and cozy atmosphere that carries on over into their great service.  

The green salad was very simple.  Some various lettuces and greens with a light vinagrette. Their main dishes are pretty good, but a little on the heavy side - with lots of cheese on their main dishes (margherita pizza and lasagna.)  

My main complaint is that although the pizza was good, I prefer my margharita pizzas to be a lighter thin crust affair.  Their margherita was just another pizza, but with basil and some chopped up tomatoes on it.  Oh yeah, and tons of mozzarella was all over.  

Both the lasagna and the pizza warranted a blotting technique to get some excess oil from the baked cheese all over the top.  Once sopped up, the food was very good.

Why did I give this a 4 star, when a similarly greasy breakfast joint (Nob Hill Grille) (I wonder if all the Nob Hill named restaurants are greasy...) got a 2 star?  Have you tried blotting corned beef hash or poached eggs?  Not as easy as blotting a pizza or lasagna.
author: Anson G.

description:
Great Italian options! Cozy!

Go with the chicken parm.
author: Vicki L.

description:
We have lived in the area for years.  This is our Sunday night spot for dinner.
Comfortable, cozy, wonderful servers, and fabulous rich filling Italian food.
All the pastas a are wonderful, and the wines are terrific.
author: Dr. Octagon O.

description: Stopped in for brunch/lunch on a rainy day. Food was good had the tequila like chicken scrambled eggs. Great surprise! The decor and atmosphere felt dated but the waitress was super friendly and funny. Felt like she took the time to get to know everyone.
author: Z W.

description:
Since I walk and bike everywhere in San Francisco, it is rare to find me on Nob Hill for dinner... There are just too many good hill-less options to choose from close to home.

However, Monday was a rare car day, so up, up, UP we went to Snob Hill! Snobby or not, it is awfully pretty up there and Nob Hill Cafe is no exception. It is pretty, quaint, and entirely yummy.

My best friend and I had to do our biweekly catchup and this was the perfect locale. Whether you are whispering privately or laughing from your toes, Nob Hill Cafe felt completely appropriate for the occasion.

The food was excellent. I had the best pesto fettuccine I have ever had.  It was savory, rich and buttery. So much that I was full after about 10 bites, but couldn't help nomming the rest of it.  It was so delicious.  

Philly had the lasagna and said that it could have been the best lasagna he has ever had... I must take him to Antica Trattoria to truly test that possibility. It definitely tested my resolve to not eat meat as it looked and smelled truly fabulous.  Needless to say, there wasn't even sauce left on the plate when he was finished! A rarity.

Thank you yelp for finding me two more "best ever" meals. I owe it to you!
author: Hayley W.

description: Delicious food!! Highly recommend their pastas. Usually has a long wait, if you get there pretty early around 6 you won't have to wait as long.
author: Madie H.

description:
Having driven all the way to San Francisco for a concert, I was excited to try a hole in the wall since SF is so well recognized for them. As they should be because this little place provided exemplary service and exquisite food. 
First and foremost, there were other guests that we're waiting the half hour wait and they offered my friend a chair since she had crutches. Thanks, strangers!
We were pretty tight on time since the concert was starting in about an hour so the hostess called names super fast. Beware to not leave the area because they will move right along. On to the food..
Maybe it was the fact that I was starving but their dishes were delicious. I asked for what I thought was an odd combination of their tortellini with some type of vodka tomato sauce and the server was more than happy to accommodate. She even gave me a really good laugh. My friend ordered spaghetti a la carbonara and we couldn't help but pick at each other's food! 
They served us so quickly so that we wouldn't be late for our concert and our server was on point to make sure we had a fantastic first visit and a speedy one. I have never seen such great service where they truly put the customers first. Will visit again most definitely!
author: Tammy T.

description: This place is really small but intimate. Very good ambiance. They serve one of the best free bread in town. So soft and fresh, I even see customers dropping in just to purchase some bread. Pasta is good but they give really little meat and seafood. Overall a good spot because it always smells so good, the kitchen is right by all the seating so you can see all the action and smell all the goodies.
author: anna w.

description: This place is really solid.  The menu was good, lots of options. Although it's not obvious from the name, it's an Italian place.   It's tiny, and very cute.  The food was really good - we had pizza, chicken parm, and gnocchi - and we enjoyed everything that came to the table.  Decent wine list and good beers, too.  Friendly, attentive service.
author: Sheila C.

description:
I live on the block and its an awesome place to get take out. I've eaten here as well but everything is amazing. LOVE IT.

The gnocchi with the meat sauce is one of my go to's if Im in another mood I get the tortellini and pesto.  

The soups they have are a little disappointment, there never creamy or thick enough for my licking. The potato leek soup I had the other night I was soooo exited for. It was straight liquid no nice chucks of potato or anything.
author: Jess O.

description: Great late lunch spot. Friendly and helpful wait staff. Small, sunny cafe with sidewalk dining option. Tried the house special gnocchi and it was delicious!
author: Rebecca C.

description: Very friendly staff and relaxed atmosphere. Loved my white cheddar, pancetta and apple pizza, and my husband loved his seafood risotto.
author: Sara W.

description: Wonderful adorable and quaint cafe. Very authentic and the Italian food is amazing! You forget your in California and feel like your in Italy. It's precious ! I love it ! I will be back!
author: Holly P.

description: This is a cute date place. Food and service was enjoyable. Few wines served by the glass while more are served by the bottle. I had the fettuccine with creamy pesto, hubby had the penne special. Both were yummy. It filled up quickly for dinner, we went on a Tuesday night. A very intimate setting.
author: Marian L.

description:
Do you like hour and a half waits for mediocre food surrounded by tourists and 23 year olds who think they are the next Kerouac? Then this place is for you. 

Soup that tasted like burnt broth with a few celery pieces floating in it, caprese salad that had little taste and looked like weeds, fatty carbonara that you can only eat half of before you feel sick. Best part was a decent glass of wine for six bucks.
author: Mister G.

description:
This place has amazing food for the prices! The gnocchi, lasagne and pesto fettuccine are all to die for (and they keep really well too for dinner the next night!) The bread is awesome and the caprese salad is a great starter.

The only reason why I can't give it 5 stars is the wait time...it is a tiny restaurant and very worth the wait, but the past 2 times we have went there we were told around 40-45 min for a table and it took well over 1:15. As long as you've built this into your expectations and plan on a few glasses of wine before dinner (or a nearby bar) - you'll have a good time, it just might take much longer than they tell you. Still, it's very worth it!!
author: Ashley G.

description: Great.  Some of the best pasta, butter and cheese I have had.  Good Ceasar salad too.  Friendly, good service.  I would go back.
author: T B.

description: I went here for a lovely meal with a friend before a concert at the Masonic. We both really enjoyed our meal and agreed that the service was unforgettable...in a very good way.
author: kim w.

description:
The service was excellent, the ambiance nice, and most of the food was excellent. I did do a daily special of pork chops, and it seemed a bit...pedestrian for this place.

However, worth a visit!
author: Tim N.

description:
Cute location, very classic feel.  

Very small restaurant, but worth the wait if you can.  Food is great and reasonable.  Service is ok, nothing special, but not bad at all.

Pizza for Brunch - TWO THUMBS UP!!!
author: Jorge C.

description: Delicious dinner for out of towners!! Drove up from L.A. With the family and the fairmont suggested it to us. We walked over from the hotel and were seated quickly. The food was tasty, fast and enjoyable for kids and adults!! Staff was friendly and accommodating! Which made the small quant table enjoyable!! Thank you for a great meal Nob hill cafe!
author: Tracey B.

description: Felt disappointed walking out if this place. Had heard great reviews and it was walking distance from the hotel so we went for dinner. The place itself has a great small , local feel to it . We were however disappointed by the food. We ordered the gnocchi bolognese , which we felt was a rather small serving for the price. We also ordered the the spaghetti carbonara. This  really lacked flavour. I expected yummy creaminess and didn't get it. Overall I for $40 I wouldn't go back .
author: Kirsty D.

description: WOW!!! This was worth the uphill climb for us!! I will be back here again for their Pesto Fettucine. I have never had better pesto in my life. My companion and I both agreed we could just slurp it like soup for god sake's, it was that good!!! Generous but not overdone portion, delicious polenta appetizer. We also ordered the pesto garlic bread which was quite unremarkable but the trip is worth it for the fettucine. Service was very pleasant and friendly, no wait as we came at just the right time. Prices are reasonable.  must try if you want some delicious Italian food in a great neighborhood!!
author: Clare R.

description:
The pasta carbonara isn't prepared correctly.  Instead, they should label it alfredo with pancetta, because that's basically what you get.  Never should a traditional carbonara dish be as 'saucy' as the Nob Hill Cafe prepares it.  I'm fine with a chef preparing a traditional dish as his/her style, but call it something else.

Overall, nothing to scream about town.  Nice service for the most part.  Smells absolutely orgasmic while you're hungrily waiting outside.
author: Aaron A.

description: Group of three for a weekday lunch. Delicious pasta! My husband ordered the penne with vodka, I ordered melenzane parmigiana, and the third guest got the angel hair with tomato and garlic. All three of us loved our food. It was served piping hot and was very flavorful. Would definitely recommend for a hearty comfort meal.
author: Maria H.

description:
Brunch review only:

Nob Hill Cafe is a cute little place to have brunch and dog watch... and this is exactly we did.  Came here on a lovely saturday morning with my friend and our loves (our pups!) It's absolutely delightful to have places with out door seating so we dont have to always leave our dogs outside by themselves... or at home all alone!!!

We got a table outside, in the shade... remember, SF is a microclimate... so being in the shade is 10 degrees colder than being in the sun, so always bring a jacket.  The waitress came over and took our coffee orders... and once the hot coffee arrived... i was fine!

I ordered the shrimp and avocado omelette... and it was yum yum yum!!!  the prawns were not over cooked... and let me just say... they were prawns and not shrimpies!!!
author: Kelly H.

description:
I took some guests from out of town here for lunch. The food has always been great and today was no exception, but the service may have been the worst I've ever had. The kitchen staff was so friendly, but it ends there. When we were seated by An unfriendly waitress 
 it took her over 20 minutes to come back to our table. We were well into our appetizer when we ran into a friend and invited them to join. We had a bench seat with only two people so seating was not an issue but we were informed this was some thing we were not allowed to do. The two blonde waitresses both told us our third guest could not join since we had already been seated.  After some explanation that we did not sit down with the intention of adding another guest they said this was okay. When our guest arrived they rudely told her that it was not okay to do this but they were making an exception. They did not bring a plate or a setup for our guest nor did they offer to take her drink order. We had to flag our waitress down to even try and make a lunch order.
Thirty minutes later our waitress finally came back to take our lunch order and that was the last time we saw her. We had to ask someone else to refill our drinks that had been empty for over twenty minutes.
The food is good but the service is sub par to say the least. There are so many great Italian  restaurants in this city with much much better service. 
Save yourself the frustration and 2 hour lunch!
author: Lauren P.

description: I love this place. I've been going here for 20 Years and the food and service has never suffered. The chefs are incredibly nice and always treat me very well. Best thing is the sole fish. So well done. Great place for takeout as well. I would recommend this place to anyone.
