The wait is frustrating- we were told it was a twenty minute wait and it turned into an hour and fifteen minute wait, so go expecting to have a glass of wine or three as you wait and take the wait time given with a grain of salt.  It is truly worth it.  The fettucine al pesto is delicious, absolutely delicious!  Other pastas are also very good and the pizzas are solid.  Very friendly service.  Feels like you are in an Italian neighborhood cafe.
author: Alison S.

description:
The Nob HIll Cafe is located in a quite little neighborhood and walking distance from our Hotel.

We stumbled on to this restaurant when looking for a nice little Italian place. We come back now every time we are in San Francisco.

The food is always fresh and the focaccia bread is wonderful.

Get there early so you don't have to wait, it starts filling up by 6 pm.

I recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for a nice family style restaurant where it is quite with good service and food.
author: Deedee S.

description:
I don't understand how people keep rating this place so highly.  The service is a little slow and definitely not overly friendly or helpful.  The menu is blah... and my gnocchi had chunks of raw potato in it (gross).

There is so much better Italian food in this city I have NO idea why people wait up to an hour for this place.
author: Cate M.

description: My review is long overdue.  Nob Hill Cafe is a favorite restaurant of mine and it is like going home, although at home I can't get carbonara.  The taste, portion size and price is perfect.  Combined with the Antipasti to start and it is the ideal meal for me.  Their service is outstanding.  This is a restaurant worth dining at over and over.
author: Jen T.

description: YUMMY! Cute, quaint little place. Good excellent. Tried the gnocchi, penne vodka, pesto tortellini ... All great dishes!  Courteous staff. Definitely go back.
author: Robin B.

description:
This place would definitely be 5 stars if it wasn't so tiny and it you didn't have to wait for a table every single night. 

Tip: Don't come here with a large group, 2-4 people parties are easiest to seat. 

This place has the most adorable, neighborhood feel to it. You know it's a great place when there is a wait for tables every single night of the week (especially since there are plenty of other restaurants in the area without a wait). Food is great. I would recommend the lasagna, tortellini, margharita pizza and brushetta. I've only been here a few times, but I see many more visits in my future. Highly recommended!
author: Kate C.

description:
3.5 stars for Nob Hill Cafe. I would say that if you live close by or happen to be in the neighborhood, it's worth a trip. Definitely no need to go out of your way. I am just happy that they are open on Monday nights. I don't understand why all the decent restaurants in North Beach close on Mondays.

I love how it's a small, cute neighborhood restaurant. We had great service the whole night (lots of water refills and a friendly waitress). We started our meal with the bruschetta appetizer. Honestly, nothing to write home about. While there were plenty of fresh tomato pieces, I just happen to like my bruschetta more when the topping has been marinating in olive oil, salt, and garlic. Instead the bread was toasted with olive oil and garlic and then it was lots of fresh tomatoes cubed with some basil. I am not an Italian expert and maybe this is more authentic bruschetta... I just know my own preferences. Also, I was sad that there were only 2 slices for $5.50. 

I had the gnocchi with meat sauce and I enjoyed it but just found it heavy. The sauce was a tomato based sauce and flavorwise, everything worked. But you have heavy potato pasta with heavy meat sauce... and it's a lot. Portions were decent and not itty bitty. Also, I would have liked it if the gnocchi was a bit smaller (like half the size that they were). It was just a lot to put in your mouth (insert that's what she said joke... cause I know that's what plenty of you are thinking).

Pizzas are small and customizable but I like that they don't skimp on the toppings (lots of cheese) and the pizza is nice and crispy. I think I would go back if I was REALLY craving Italian on a Monday night especially because I live so close.
author: Jackie T.

description:
I'm not sure if the time change was getting to me being an East Coaster eating dinner here at 11 p.m. East Coast time or if Nob Hill really does serve the best Italian food. 

We walked in and were able to get a table for our group (which was fantastic, seeing they don't take reservations). Very small, but quaint restaurant. It has a cozy feeling to it.

I started with a glass of red wine, and Insalata Caprese. The salad was great. The bread they place on the table had a hint of rosemary or something in it, that was also delicious. For my main course, I opted for the Penne Bettola - fantastic. I had to refrain myself from scarfing it all down after the giant plate of salad I had for an appetizer. My mouth is still watering about the food as I type this, even though weeks have passed. 

I highly recommend stopping here if you are in the area.
author: Ashley V.

description:
Nob Hill Café is my favorite restaurant. I love the food and the staff. 

The meatball calzone special is one of the most magical things on earth. I highly recommend ordering it if it's available.
author: Robert P.

description:
All I can say is yummy-yummy to my tummy!! mmmmm good!! This place is totally worth the wait. Sometimes it seems like 45min to an hour is too long, but they always offer a menu to order wine while you wait outside which makes the time go by fast. I am hoping in the future that they will expand hopefully somewhere close to their current location as it is a prime area to be. I love bringing all my family and friends here as they have the most delicious, true authentic Italian cuisine that no other Italian places can attest to. There is never a slow time as they are always hopping because of their great food. 

Positives: exceptional food, wine, location, and service, price
Negative: long wait time (but they really try to do their best despite this)
author: Donya M.

description: Great crowd, classy environment. The food's very down-to-earth but so well-made-- not too heavy or saucy. It's fun to watch the dogs walk by. . .
author: ミカ S.

description: The ambiance is wonderful. Dim, intimate, cozy, and romantic. The food is always amazing. Some of the best Italian food I've had. This is a neighborhood staple. They are on a short wait almost every night of the week. They always have different specials and I have never tried a special that didn't blow me away.
author: Ashley G.

description: The place looked promising and I personally think I would give a much more positive review except for that they gave me the wrong dish, and being a vegetarian and receiving a meat dish where the meat actually looked like it could've been mushrooms...is quite distressing. It was very sickening and I do wish I could've gotten my dish but do to lack of time on my part I had to leave without it.
author: Joshua R.

description: Definitely a great stop in the neighborhood, and very convenient.  Many times during the week because this place is so busy, be prepared for a bit of a wait (usually 15-20 minutes).  The ambiance is nice and cozy, and is perfect for grabbing a meal with some friends and catching up.
author: Mel G.

description:
I wanted to check out this restaurant because it is located in a beautiful neighborhood. I grew up one block away from the cafe. 

Unfortunately, we had a horrible customer service issue. 
I will mention that the food was good. My friend had the sole and I tried the gnocchi. 

My friend walked into the restaurant at 5:10pm, it was already crowded, but there were a few tables open. She is elderly and disabled (using a walker/chair).She asked if she could sit while she waited me for me. 
She was told that it was restaurant policy to not seat anyone until their complete party is there. She could not go sit outside, as it was raining. 
She pleaded for them to make an exception due to her disability. The waitress was very rude and basically told her "that was her problem". 
They put her up against the wall in the corner in her walker/chair. 
They never asked her if she would like a drink while waiting. 
I arrived at 5:50pm. I was appalled. There she was was sitting in the corner, being totally ignored for 40 minutes. 
I have been in the restaurant business for many years, and there is absolutely no excuse for this sort of customer service. 

We will never return and will tell all of our friends about this bad experience.
author: Connie N.

description: Excellent service. Great food. All the staff is from Ireland and they all have the Irish hospitality down. Keep up the great work!
author: Connor S.

description: Nob Hill is a cute little Italian restaurant. Recommended by my sister, I decided it was worth a try. My boyfriend and I made it a date night. The place has a authentic classy feel too it, but it can be casual as well. We got there slighty after 7 and there was already a line. We ended up waiting 45 minutes for a table. It was definitely a long wait, but they they served you wine and drinks while you were waiting which was a plus and there were some tables to wait and sit at while you were waiting. I'd say it was worth it! (they were people waiting all night till closing) Once we got seated. We were served fresh bread and butter- delicious! I could not decided what I wanted pizza sounded good but I was really craving clam pizza with white sauce. I decided to ask the waitress if they could make it for me and they did! I was extremely happy about that. And to top it off. It was AMAZING. One of the best clam pizzas I've ever had. It was the perfect balance of creamy to salty. Yummm! My boyfriend got the sausage gnocchi and enjoyed it too. He was able to finish his and sneak a couple pieces of my pizza too. Service was great! Food was great! Also props to the hostess who was running around all night serving drinks, taking down names and seating people. She was definitely a champ!
author: Sam L.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco, small and limited seating but very worth the wait.  I used to live 2 blocks from this place and would order take out to avoid the long wait.  Yummy!  I wish I still lived in San Francisco
author: Chas W.

description:
Wanting to find a little different kind of place on vacation last August, we Yelped this place and decided to give it a go. It's located off the beaten path in a nice neighborhood in Nob Hill. Parking was a bit of a challenge, and we had to walk a bit, but nothing major.

Upon entering, you'll find a cute little place that is appealing but small. We felt a little cramped at the table we were at, and as it was the main entrance, the cascade of people coming in kept walking past our table. Our waitress was very nice, explained the menu very well, and was attentive all of the time we were there.

The garlic bread was a small portion and did not stand out. It was slightly over done, but not really burnt.

For dinner, my kids had the chicken parmigiana, and I had a specialty pizza off the daily menu. My kids love this menu item and normally get this at Italian joints. They were OK with it, but felt that the taste was different and although ate it, were slightly disappointed. They described the flavor as a bit too sweet for their liking - assuming the sauce was a special one used by the restaurant.

My pizza though was very good. Very light crust (tiny bit burnt - but OK for me), nice toppings, and very flavorful.

Overall, I say it's average. If you are in the area and want a nice Italian place, go! I think you'll come out satisfied. I am not sure I would seek it out again if I were on vacation in SF though.
author: Arthur H.

description:
Great little place that is quiet and has excellent food. Sitting in the window lets you see the passers by but I think any seat is great. Excellent food and great service (thanks Elena!)!

I would highly recommend stopping by!
author: Keilee D.

description: Great fresh food. The special of the night was great. Great neighborhood vibe and prices. Just remember that the table are packed together tight.  We were in town for ADA and wanted to try a local spot this was it. Would recommend to any and everyone.
author: John H.

description: Their food was phenomenal! I recommend the gnocchi. It's a small place so it may take a while if you have a larger group. But the people are friendly and accommodating and the wait is well worth it.
author: Maggie D.

description:
Our never ending quest to find simple Italian (really probably italian-american) food in the city has lead us about two blocks from our apartment. And that is the two blocks that lead you to the nice part of town and not our usual two blocks to the TL.

As said before this place is about a block from Grace Cathedral at the proverbial top of nob hill, so the atmosphere is great. What is probably not so great is that it is the size of a postage stamp (and not those ginormous stamps you get from the nature conservancy, as if they worried about the forest!!) and they do not accept reservations. So pack a coat and get ready to wait. 

Once inside the service was fine for me and my wife. I ordered the pesto tortelini, while wifey got the angel hair pasta. My dish was just about perfect for a pesto, not too oily, not too salty. My wife's 'angel hair' was really spaghetti but little did they know that this is actually what she wanted. Spaghetti or angel hair aside, the tomato/garlic/olive-oil combo sauce had all of the flavor that my wife could want. (sometimes a sauce this simple can get bland) So basically, both me and my wife were very happy. Even though we spent a little more than we would usually for such a simple meal. I am learning to live with all of these yuppies, even if it will kill me.
author: David M.

description: I live down the street from nob hill cafe and have become a regular over the last 6 years.  It is a wonderful place for good food, good service and a great atmosphere.  The servers always have a smile and always want to please. Granted all in the party have to be there to be seated  (for very good reasons, size of place and difficulty parking), but it is so worth it. My favorites, penne betolli, tortellini Romano and gnocchi.  Wonderful wonderful neighborhood place with lots of us regulars
author: Michelle Q.

description:
we had dinner here last night before seeing laura marling at grace cathedral, since it's a block away.  we got here around 7:15, and there was about a 30 minute wait.  the place is small, but we were able to have some wine while waiting.

the hubby and i shared the insalada mista, bruschetta, and the penne w/ spicy vodka sauce.  the server was really nice and split all the plates for us w/o us asking.  everything was tasty and came out pretty quick.  the portions are pretty big, so we were pretty stuffed, but we still had room for dessert.  all their gelatos come like a slice of ice cream cake, so we got the chocolate gelato w/ chocolate chips.  

with 2 drinks, the total damage came to about $55, which is pretty reasonable.
author: Helen T.

description:
It was a nice touch that they offered people waiting for their tables glasses of wine.  It is a small busy cafe.  We unfortunately got seated on the kitchen side of the restaurant so it was a lot of noisey, bustle and smells.
    
I had the gnocchi bolognese since so many raved about it but it was eh.  Like another reviewer said, I like my gnocchi with a little more bite.  The bolognese was quite watery and bland.  The sausage had no taste to it.  The bread with rosemary(?) was soft but it had a weird aftertaste.  

I had a taste of my friends pesto fettucine and it was tasty but nothing special.  Her daughter's Margherita pizza was pretty good.  There were still people waiting for a table when we left at 9:00pm!
author: Linda M.

description: Service is OK.  Food is not up to par.  For some reason, the restaurant's clam linguine is VERY acidic.  Why?
author: Virginia C.

description:
This is the only time I have ever given a 5-star rating, as I was thoroughly impressed with my experience!

I stopped by on a Wednesday evening. There was a 30 minute wait, but they had seating outside for everyone. While I was waiting, the hostess gave me a wine menu and took a drink order. Mmm, a nice sauvignon blanc to help pass the time! Before I could finish, a table was ready and she carried the glass for me to my table.

I was greeted by a blonde server with an Irish accent who was very friendly. I ordered the Gnocchi Bolognese. I asked my server a good wine to go with the gnocchi (I had heard a lot about it), and she told me both the typical red wine pairing and her recommendation, the Valpolicella, a good alternative red wine that also happened to be her favorite. She poured me a swig so I could sample it, and I chose the Valpolicella. A server brought some bread that was freshly baked and helped tide me over until the main course arrived.

I must say, when you take that first bite of the gnocchi, you will know you made the right decision. It just melts in your mouth, and the pomodoro sauce with Italian fennel seed sausage and ground beef is extremely delicious! The gnocchi goes well with the Valpolicella wine. There is a lot on the plate, but take your time, as you will enjoy the last bite as much as the first (and even use the bread to get the remaining sauce off the plate).

I was so impressed with the flavor and texture of the gnocchi that I even asked my server if she could ask the chef exactly how it is made. She came back a few minutes later and told me that it takes a long time to perfect the technique (that just means I will have a good challenge when I try to learn how to make it). I appreciated that she took the time to ask. When it came time to paying the bill, I did not feel rushed at all.

My advice on this restaurant: 
- Make sure someone orders the Gnocchi Bolognese (and make sure they share it!)
- Come here if you like to take your time to enjoy your food. Do not come here if you are on a time crunch.
- Be prepared to wait for a table, as the place fills up fast and they do not take reservations.

To sum up my visit: I was very impressed with my experience, from the friendly service to the lively atmosphere to the delicious food. I only wish I lived in San Francisco so I can go here more often.
author: Robert S.

description: Felt rushed even after the crowd eased and the food was nothing special.  Benefits those who don't want to walk back up the hill after dinner.
author: Ken L.

description:
After 300+ reviews, I'm clearly not going to shed any new light on this place.

To get to the point: It's not amazing food (I confess!), but it's reliable, consistent, enjoyable food. The lasagna tastes like some good lasagna, the gnocchi like some good gnocchi, and the pizza like some good pizza. 

It's got a good vibe, the service is usually pleasant, and the pricing isn't outrageous.

And maybe that's something to treasure in a neighborhood restaurant. Places in this city can be so overrated, overpriced, and downright full of themselves (patrons included), that it's refreshing to find a place that kinda just wants to be what it is, and do it well.
author: Brian K.

description: Loved this place. Very reasonably priced.  Loved the fresh bread that they served before the food arrived. Enjoyed the pasta. Would highly recommended!
author: Tammy P.

description:
I went here last night with 2 others.  As we were being seated, I noticed one of the cooks with a big, plastic tub of pre-cooked spaghetti that had been refrigerated - not a good sign.

Our waitress was friendly and took our orders promptly.  Two of us ordered the Gnocchi Bolognese and the other ordered the seafood pasta, which was a special that night.  We also got a Sangiovese, which was actually a blend.  It's something that should have been noted on the menu.

The food came quickly - too quickly.  The gnocchi was too soft, and the sauce was just okay.  The tiny chunks of sausage in the sauce had no flavor.  It was obvious that the sauce and gnocchi was pre-cooked and had been heated up.

The seafood pasta consisted of a cream sauce with shrimp and calamari, but it was mostly pasta and little seafood.  The menu said there was lobster in it, but there was none.  The shrimp was fresh and sweet, but the sauce was pretty bland.  It wasn't worth $19.  The only positive thing about this dish was the fact that it was cooked to order.  Maybe that's why it was a 'special'.

The waitress was in a hurry to get rid of us despite our whole meal lasting no more than 1 hour.  If you've ever worked at a restaurant, this is what you call a "turn 'em and burn 'em" establishment.  First in, first out - eat your food, pay, now get out.

Don't believe the hype.  The food is bland and uninspiring.  Do yourself a favor and cook your own Italian because, chances are, you could do better than this place.  At least you'll cook it the same day you're going to eat it!
author: Andy S.

description:
Came here on Valentine's Day without a reservation, and had to say enjoyed it throughly.

Me and my fiance got a table right away with no wait around 6pm, which was an amazing feat let me tell you. The service was really good on a busy night, and their bread basket is actually really good (I love bread, so the bread basket at a restauraunt is actually really important).

We had the beef carpaccio, the gnocchi with fennel sausage ragu, and the petrale sole, a glass of wine and tiramisu, which ran us about $60, which isn't too bad.

Now onto the food.

The carpaccio was ok, not great, but not horrible either. It needed a little more red onion, some salt, some more shaved parmesean, and none of that weird sauce they drizzle over the top. I'm a purist, so olive oil is better for me on carpaccio as opposed to something that looks like a caesar dressing with saraccha hot sauce mixed in.

The gnocchi was pretty good, a little too soft for my taste as I prefer my gnocchi with a little more bite to it, as otherwise it's just mush meets mushy ragu-sauce. The fennel sausage didn't really come out as much as I had hoped, but it was still pretty solid.

The sole. Ahhh...memories of that dish still linger in my thoughts today. Way better, in my humble opinon than that at another place called Beretta, it was perfectly cooked, not too dry, with an amazing lemon butter caper sauce, some perfectly cooked penne pasta, and some snap peas. What prevents me from giving this place a full 5 stars, is the fact that I found some little fish bones in a small part of the filet, which is not so fun when you're otherwise enjoying a perfect dish.

Dessert was tiramisu, which is a good old fashioned standby in italian places, it was good here, but not great.

Pros: Great food, decent prices, Good bread.

Cons: Spacing is really tight, and bones in a filet of fish is never a good sign.
author: David H.

description: A little bit of a wait, but so worth it! Fun atmosphere. Delicious food. Our table had the sole, lasagna, and the gnocchi - which were all mouth watering!
author: Katie C.

description: Rude!!!!! I arrived 30 mins before my friend and wanted a glass of wine. The restaurant was empty. They told me I could sit on a chair by the bathroom or outside (in the cold wind!). I said I would order and they said no. Rather than offer a suggestion, they just let me walk out. I am now at the fairmont where at least the staff appreciates my business! I will never go back to nob hill cafe!
author: seattle s.

description:
Simple, delicious, wallet-friendly pasta...served in a bowl.  What?!  Damn, why don't all places do that?  Thought I ordered pho for a second!  

Linguine alla Vongole: baby clams, garlic, lemon and white wine.  Perfect amount of lemon tang and a heapload of clams, served piping hot.  Don't talk to me.  I'm busy stuffing my mouth.

Penne Bettola: garlic and vodka in a spicy tomato cream.  Perfect amount of spice in a simple but flavorful tomato sauce.

Tiramisu: Bomb.  No, I mean it bombed.  It was the only downer  of the meal.  I seriously think they forget the coffee part.  There wasn't even a hint of the flavor.  Just the oddest tiramisu I've ever had.  

Italian food doesn't have to be fancy and simple recipes like the ones at Nob Hill Cafe are winners.  They don't take reservations so be prepared to wait (about 30 minutes for us).  It is also just a two block stroll from the Fairmont Hotel so it's super convenient if you don't want to spend all your cash dining there or taking a cab elsewhere.  

Also, service here is great!  We were offered a chance to order something to drink while we waited (we both had the Santa Christina Sangiovese - way too sweet in my opinion).  Oh, and big bowls of pasta means leftovers, WOO!
author: Heidi L.

description:
Fabulous Italian food for a reasonable price.

It's a cozy and adorable restaurant in Nob Hill.  We had to wait a little bit but by the time we sat down, none of us seemed to mind.  The bread was great and perfect for warming up our tummies.  Staff was extremely friendly.  Tables are small but that made our dinner more intimate and fun.

I ordered linguine with baby clams prepared with butter, lemon, and garlic.  It's simple but wonderful.  I had it for dinner on Saturday AND Sunday.  And I hate leftovers.

My husband ordered the lasagna and it was the sauciest lasagna I've ever seen.  I kept attacking his sauce with extra bread.  Yum.

Another person in my party ordered the gnocci and the flavor was great and the texture was awesome.

The next time I come to this place, I know I'll have a hard time trying to decide what to order.  I just might have to come with many friends so I can attack their dishes, too.  =)
author: Ally C.

description:
A great and bustling little cafe. We had a terrific green salad with pear, gorgonzola and dijon vinaigrette. Followed that up with a very rich lobster ravioli with a bisque sauce.

This would be a definite visit again when I'm back in the neighborhood.
author: Gregory G.

description:
I just have to say that I've been contemplating my entree choice ever since yesterday my parents suggested going to nob Hill Cafe tonight before my mom leaves for her redeye back east. That must say SOMETHING about this place. I mean, do I really go for the lasagna again or should I try and be more creative? But you see I do love the lasagna SO much! Yet there's the carbonara or the tortellini... oh man, now my mouth is watering. 
This day cannot go by fast enough.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Great little restaurant!

My lady and I ate here last night, and though it was a Tuesday the wait was lengthy. They really do their best to make you feel welcome though, serving drinks to all of us who were waiting and generally being very attentive. Since they don't take reservations, they're obviously used to this.

We started off with a salad special which was excellent. One of those fusion sorta things with feta, walnuts and greens over a bed of thin-sliced beets. Quite tasty. Garlic bread was fantastic too, great cheese and seasoning. We both had pasta dishes and they were rich, very well flavored, in my case deliciously spicy, and of excellent size (we both took food home). Prices were normal for moderately nice place, and both the hostess and our waitress were extremely friendly and attentive.

All in all a great, cozy, fun little spot that we'll be visiting again for sure.
author: Davin P.

description: gooooooood ,,  we got in just before the rush !  I got the special rigatoni, my wife got the gnocchi... great place ! highly recommend
author: Vetty F.

description:
Eight words: Spinach ricotta gnocchi in lemon grappa cream sauce.

GTFOH.

Knowing that this is the Italian cafe in my new hood makes me giddy with carb-anticipatory joy. And specials like the aforementioned gnocchi are the icing on the cake. It was between that or the lamb sausage pizza, which I pray they're serving the next time I go. Which will be soon. The wine list here is broad with a nice range of price points. All around solid at dinner--and I hear they have brunch on weekends.
author: Lesly S.

description: Wonderful little place! My husband and I visited San Francisco over the weekend. We stayed at the Mark Hopkins Hotel. We were able to walk just a few block (a lovely walk by the way) to this restaurant. The service was excellent, food delicious and a quaint, romantic atmosphere. We got there right a 5:00 because we had a 7:00 show to catch. There was no wait but the place was filling up quick. To be honest, this little romantic dinner is what made our trip. Very romantic. The stop at  Huntington Park on the walk up was very sweet. Very nice experience.
author: Hannah W.

description: Made a visit to Nob Hill Cafe while staying at the Fairmont for a wedding.  Cute little whole in the wall restaurant.  Walking in with a group of six I was immediately a little apprehensive not sure how we were all going to fit at a table, it was that small.  The staff immediately told us that we could not sit until our whole party was here (we were missing 2 people who were minutes behind us, didn't matter).  Normally I'd take away a star for this first negative encounter, but luckily once we sat down (all of us there of course!) the waitress was actually pretty friendly and did a good job.  Food was amazing!  Luckily my family is pretty generous and we all pick off each others plates and I got to try many of their dishes.  Top recommendations: the polenta appetizer, the gnocchi, and the calamari steak.  Food was all pretty reasonably priced, add a few bottles of prosecco you are looking at little heftier of a tab, but worth it for a great experience.  There's a lot of good places to eat in the city so I don't know if I'll rush back here, but if I'm ever in the area I'll definitely pay this place a visit.
author: Hanna C.

description:
This place is classy and cozy - they are understated and totally affordable for the ambiance and quality of food. The spicy red pasta dish is delectible. A simple pleasure. 

Edit - they have a nice understated brunch on Sundays, with healthy options.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Small place with very nice food. Can be a bit crowded, and you might have a wait at dinner time... They have a good wine selection. Staff is attentive and polite, if not stretched a little thin on busy evenings. They have outdoor seating on the sidewalk, which is very pleasant.

Bottom line: Convenient, good food if you live in the neighborhood, but still worth a trip if you don't live nearby but are looking for a good spot to take someone out to. Also, they offer take out, so if you live in the 'hood but wanna hang in, you can call ahead and have your Alfredo Pesto pasta waiting for you.
author: Wes T.

description:
Homey atmosphere, solid Italian fare, reasonable prices and an inviting waitstaff.  It's no wonder this place is frequented by the famous San Francisco twins every Friday night.  The rest of us peons wait at least 45 minutes for our table while the twins walk in to a restaurant packed with patrons who part like the Red Sea when these two enter and hold court.  This just adds to the charm of the Nob Hill Cafe.  

Filet of sole in white wine sauce and the evening's special lobster ravioli in a buttery cream sauce were perfect with our glass of sparkling prosecco.  The table next to us though, well-intended as they are, got up to leave, looked over at us and said, "We have this leftover Chianti.  Want it?  It's really good!"  Apparently, this man took Pru's "Ummmmm...."  to mean "Yes!  Absolutely!  We are vagrants down to our last few dollars and have only enough for our meal so, yes, please--pretty please--grace us with your leftover booze."  Without so much as waiting for a response, he placed his 1/4 filled bottle of wine in the center of our table and walked out.  Odd and slightly uncouth for these parts, but it didn't take away from our evening and experience at the Nob Hill Cafe.

It was, however, worthy of a mention here on Yelp.  Clearly,  I'm still bothered.
author: Joc V.

description: Great little spot. We started with the insalata caprese which was pretty good. Then shared the carbanara and a pepperoni pizza. The carbanara was perfect, just the right amount of pancetta and egg. The pizza was pretty good as well and just as good the next day. Service is nice and you can most likely get a table without reservations in about 15-20 minutes...
author: Nicolas H.

description: I really like the food here, but I've been 4 times now, and each time, it's made me very sick.  I'll give it 3 stars still, because my girlfriend loved it, and the food tasted good, value was good, service was excellent, and the ambiance is quite nice, but minus 2 stars because they are shooting 0/4 when it comes to giving me food poisoning!
author: Yan L.

description: This was a highly-rated restaurant near our hotel in Nob Hill, so we stopped in early for a meal. I had the Gnocchi Bolognese, my wife had the Carbonara while my son and mom each had a pizza (they were big enough that they could have split one). Everyone was happy with their meals and we even picked up pizzas for the following night.
author: John P.

description: I am shocked at how high the rating is here. First the restaurant was absolutely filthy. Just look at everything from the tables when you sit down to the floors, light switch plates (filthy black) and watching how they handled the bread baskets etc. On to the food- the salad was fine (hard to mess up that) but the bruschetta was terrible. The toasted bread was burnt (BLACK char) which they knew about and placed that side down. Topped with flavorless tomatoes and way too large pieces of basil thrown on, it really was poorly put together and nearly inedible. The lasagne tasted fine. The fennel meat was okay but the sauce could really use some help. Same sauce of course on the eggplant Parmesan. I am really dismayed at the penne they served with the eggplant. The pasta they use is not- the pasta bought at Safeway cooked at home tasted fresher than this pasta. Add lukewarm service (a little attitude from one server) and this place is a disaster. I really don't know where the 4 star review average comes from. What a bust.
author: Piper W.

description: Ate here while on vacation to San Francisco from Alabama. All of the guys at work back in Alabama had raved about this place, so I had to give it a try, but ...I just didn't get it. (I was also surprised to overhear a German couple at the restaurant mention that they had come here after reading about it in a popular travel guide.) Don't get me wrong -- the food was pretty good, but ...it just didn't live up to it's reputation and to the very, very, very, very, very long wait.
author: Melissa L.

description:
One of the first things I look for when I move to a new place are the restaurants that'll become my standard weeknight dinner-out spots.  You come home from work hungry, want to get out of the house, and want something priced in between a burrito and I dunno, anything that's drizzled with truffle oil.  

Happily, I think I've found the local place where I'll become a regular.  There's nothing fancy on the menu here; it's generally all your Italian standards.  But, everything was cooked very well, the portions are generous, and the atmosphere was loud but cozy.  

I had one of the specials: seafood penne with a ginger soy sauce.  My dining companions had a pizza and the lasagna.  As a starter, we had the platter of seasonal roasted vegetables.  Splitting a bottle of wine, our bill was around $70 for the three of us.  Not bad.

I've noticed that crowds form here starting about 8, but they have a couple outdoor tables and the host is happy serve you wine while you wait. 

So while the Nob Hill cafe is expensive enough that I wouldn't go there every week, it's a perfect once or twice a month weeknight splurge.
author: Eric S.

description: I was ignored by staff for 10 minutes, so I left.  I tried to have lunch here on Friday 8-16-13 around noon. They were about half full. 2 cooks and 2 wait staff saw me but ignored me. I waited for about 10 minutes. No one asked me if I wanted a table or where to go to get a table and no signs. So I left. It is unfortunate since I saw so many good reviews on Yelp.  This restaurant was also recommended by the concierge at the Mark Hopkins hotel where I was staying.
author: Linda S.

description: One of my favorite Italian places in the city. It's cozy and the food is as close as it gets to food that you get in Italy. Definitely recommend.
author: K. N.

description: Wandered into this place for lunch - wanted to try something non-touristy, and this was a good find!! Quaint place - nice atmosphere.  Great service!  Food was amazing! I had the Petrale Alla Mugnaia local sole sauteed with lemon, butter, white wine & capers.  The flavors were amazing...the white wine on the fish, and the combo of the creamy pasta sauce were to die for! i kept the bread around to soak up the extra sauce at the end!  I would highly recommend this place...I'm dreaming of that meal as I type!  It's also in a cute little neighborhood with tables outside if it's nice.
author: J W.

description:
Affordable, warm, not at all fussy, and full of delicious dish after delicious dish.

Can also be filed under, "best gnocchi I've ever had in the history of my life," which is *definitely* saying something.
author: Nicole R.

description: So I called today asking if they had outdoor seating. They said yes! When we drove all the way from Palo Alto on my birthday, they didn't serve any food outside. But outdoor seating. AND they only serve alcohol outside. That doesn't even make sense. I would give a zero star, but it wasn't an option..
author: Katie W.

description: Killer food, great atmosphere, great neighborhood. Brought the kids (contrary to the fact their site says "not good for kids) and they loved it as well. Service couldn't have been better. Classic example of great New York or San Francisco neighborhood restaurant.
author: Adam C.

description:
Just moved around the corner and this was the first neighborhood spot we tried. Loved it! The gnocchi are amazing - try them with their white cream sauce instead of the red sauce. Yumola! Now I just need to go there for brunch...

Very reasonable prices for the location, too.
author: Alex K.

description:
Not sure how much value I'm adding with my review since they already have stellar feedback, but whatevs, I'm gonna share anyways because I just had an AWESOME Valentine's meal there last night, which reminded me why this is one of my two favorite restaurants in San Francisco (the other being Limon Rotisserie on South Van Ness). 

ANYWAYS, to the review - food is awesome, prices are very reasonable, and the ambiance adds to the awesomeness of said food. 

The food - never really had a bad meal here, all dishes have either been good, great or out-of-this-worldly! Most of the time, my meal selection borders on orgasmically divine. Last night - went with the pizza with pepperoni, onion, spinach and garlic (i know, not a great Valentine's date meal idea for breath purposes, but my girl loves me, so THERE!). Pizza, as always, was amazing - thin crust pizza, the crust so fluffy, perfect for dipping in my girl's sauce (not like that, dirty person, i mean in her gnocchi sauce...and no, "gnocchi" is not some slang word for lady parts, sheesh!!!). My fiancee/valentine's date had the gnocchi bettola (on the menu as gnocchi bolognese, but ask for the bettola sauce instead). Instead of describing what she thought of her food, I'll just tell u this - we hopped in a cab and were halfway (or $6 in on the meter) home before we realized we forgot her leftovers at the restaurant. she promptly had the cabbie turn around and return to the restaurant even though we had shut down the restaurant - she was willing to pay the extra cab fare out of her own pocket on the off chance that they did not toss our food, just so she could eat her leftovers the next day for lunch! 

Prices - very reasonable. Had two entrees and a bottle of sangiovese for just under $60 pre-tip. Moreover, the portions are big, so oftentimes, you're left with leftovers in the form of another small meal the next day.

Ambiance - VERY small restaurant, you basically feel like you are in someone's home while they cook italian food and serve you dinner. Because the space is so small yet always crowded, it always feels so warm and cozy inside. I'm not italian, but my guess is, if I was, I would think to myself that going to Nob Hill Cafe takes me back to my childhood when nona would be in the kitchen cooking my favorite dish, telling me stories about our homeland...while she poured me some wine (I was a budding alcoholic as a kid, what can i say).
author: Julian M.

description:
I heart you Nob Hill Cafe!

I'm from Seattle and was referred to you on a recent visit by several locals.  We went for lunch before leaving to go to the airport, and we were so impressed.  Nob Hill Cafe is a perfect, little Italian bistro. Great food, friendly wait staff, loads of delicious specials, excellent bread, etc. We could not have asked for more in a casual dining experience, and can't wait to come back for a visit.  I could only dream that I would have a restaurant like this in my neighborhood.

Still dreaming about the butternut squash gnocchi............
author: Torstors D.

description: I hate to say it, but this place really went down hill. Me and my husband have been coming here for years for cozy intimate and casual dinners. But our last two visits were absolutely terrible. From hurried and unfriendly service to bland over-cooked and overpriced food. I wish it was still our little nook in Nob Hill, but unfortunately it is not : (
author: Amber L.

description: I have been here a few times, and keep going back hoping that it will get better. It hasn't. No reservations means that you will almost always be waiting outside, and in addition to that I would highly recommend not going after 9:15. They might ask you to sit outside to eat instead of dirtying a table inside while they are trying to close down the shop. It is a quaint and potentially charming little Italian place. However, there are a ton of quaint and charming places that offer amazing food and delightful service. This offers neither. The food is typically about average. It is never amazing, but has never been bad. If in the area and looking for Italian, go to Venticello.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Starving, famished, hypoglycemic. That was my state when I ate at Nob Hill Cafe. So I must admit that my review may be colored. 

The polenta starter was decent although you wouldn't have guessed that by the way I wolfed it down. I also inhaled my salmon scramble and corn muffin. The muffin I can say with certainty was good especially with the slices of jalapenos.
author: Monica L.

description: We were tired and I was boozy from the free wine at White Swan Inn.  We walked here.  It was decent.  They were kind enough to re-seat us when we asked to not sit literally right inside the front door.  The garlic bread appetizer was a little dry.  I very much liked my clams and pasta.  My boyfriend liked his lasagna all right, but he said it was very light (which I think is a plus) and seemed to not have that much meat.  Best of all was this dessert that seemed to be two giant chocolate ganache balls in a martini glass with whipped cream and raspberries.  YUM.
author: Kathryn G.

description: Great little place in Nob Hill...they have a good selection of Italian food and some interesting specials. The Service is generally good and you don't have to book - although you should expect to wait and have a drink outside at peak times (bring your jacket as it get's cold).
author: Jonny D.

description: Great food! I had calzone and my wife had tortellini and both were amazing. It's small, so larger groups are probably hard to accommodate. We were seated quickly, but there is sometimes a wait. VERY worth it though.
author: Chris L.

description: Love the food here! Service was punctual, you can see them make everything from the dining room, cozy, cheery, and most importantly authentically DELICIOUS! I got the clam linguine and my boyfriend got the pesto tortellini. We both couldn't stop raving about the food all night. I ate until I was miserable even though my portion size was quite large. I can't say enough good things about the food. My only qualm about Nob Hill Cafe is the service. Got everything we wanted, however the waiter made us feel inconvenient and looked in other directions when answering questions. Had to give him the benefit of the doubt and assume he was having a tough night. Will be running back here as soon as I return to the city.
author: Kelsey M.

description: I'll start by saying I'm not a huge fan of pasta and I rarely go out for Italian food- but I stopped by this place cause my friend said it was some of the best Italian food he's had in the city. I got the Pesto Linguine- which I will have to agree with some other reviews in rating it the best I've ever had- but I can't really give this place more than 3 stars cause I thought it was a bit pricey for what I actually got.12.75 for pesto linguine with pine nuts? Isn't pesto just basil and olive oil thrown in a food processor? Is this a normal price? That said, this place was cute and great for a romantic night in the city.
author: Sharon C.

description:
I'm not one to write reviews for the sake of it. But I figured this was worth mentioning. 

There was a hair in my food!! -- enough said?

Granted, every restaurant might have that happen on occasion, and the waitress apologized profusely. What's shocking though is that she took the pasta away, but actually charged us for it!!  

If you can get past all of that, the wines were good, I tried a couple. I was pleased. 

The food was mediocre at best. The gnocchi pasta was pretty good- that seems to be their specialty. But the carpaccio, penne vodka, and cheesecake were below average at best. 

Let's just say, I don't plan to go and pay for hair in my mediocre food again.
author: Siya G.

description: Long wait on a chilly evening before we were able to sit down. Service was efficient and friendly. The angel hair pasta was oversized, overcooked, and bland. The gnocchi was just OK, but the soup was decent. At least it was fairly inexpensive - in line with the mediocre food. Clientele is exclusively old, rich, white, and waspy. Bring your Polo shirt and docksiders.
author: Jon G.

description:
Heard about it a while ago and a block away from where I live so decided to give it a try for lunch. Had to wait 10 minutes for a table but it was well worth it.
I ordered the farfalle with salmon and shrimp... it was like an orgasm in my mouth... no kidding... when the waitress came to ask how it was I had to tell her I was having "a moment," LOL. She just laughed. The service was great, the flavors were excellent and I'm definitely looking forward to coming back ASAP.
author: Carlos T.

description: I should first start off by saying that I'm Italian. I was raised on Italian food from my grandparents who CAME from Italy. We went for a meal to celebrate my grandpa and the food was just outstanding. The pasta ragu sauce reminded me of the stuff that I used to have = so much so that I teared up in the place since I haven't tasted it in years. Wine was great, what a great meal. I'll be back!
author: laura f.

description:
The one and only restaurant next to my apartment (which is a uphill walk from EVERYTHING) -- lucky for me, its a pretty good place :).

Had brunch here and tried their Grilled Prawn and Avocado Omelette ($10.75).  Portions are HUGE and food is good.  The bf had the Pizzetta Di Salsicia (breakfast pizza)...I wouldnt recommend it.

A few negatives: Service was not amazing and the place is pretty dark for brunch (good for being hungover, I'd say).,  However, you can always sit outside and people watch.  

Mimosas are $9....practically same as their HUGE omlette plates.  If they want to double their business...all they'd have to do is make their orange fuzzy goodness $3-6 like everyone else.

I'll still do brunch often here though, and hope to return for dinner -- I still need to see the old twins for myself :)
author: Kendra W.

description:
Wow this place is my favourite restaurant in the city. The sole is to die for. We went with a group of people and we each tasted each others dishes, and everything was superb. 

4 STARS for the restaurant: it consist of two rooms that are both completely different which is kinda weird, but its up in Nob Hill which gives it this intimate classy ambiance

5 STARS for the food: everything we tried tasted great....EXCEPT the gnocchi, i've had better, but the sole definitely makes this place my favourite. Also, try the eggplant as well!!
author: Cnn F.

description:
Came here for my birthday last year.
I ordered the Trancia di Calamari dish, which came with pasta on the side with "vegetables". When I read calamari, I was expecting fresh coils of calamari. What I got, however, was a "steak" of calamari....which was tough, chewy, had no flavor and definitely was not calamari in natural form. This is the first dish that I have ever sent back in my entire life. I ended up getting a clam pasta that had no shells and all of the mini clams were mushed together. 

My bf got the lasagna that was actually really very good. And we split the tiramisu which was delicious.
author: Tien H.

description:
Nob Hill Cafe is wonderful. It's a small restaurant situated just down the block from Grace Cathedral. I've heard this place gets busy but there were still open tables at 12 on a Sunday when my sister and I finished our brunch. The food is spectacular. We got omelettes and they couldn't have been better. My hot chocolate was very good too.

I would HIGHLY recommend taking family, friends, or coworkers for brunch or lunch at Nob Hill Cafe but be prepared for a wait if you happen to arrive when it is busy.
author: Charles M.

description: This cafe keeps you wanting more!  The food is bellisimo, service is excellent and the atmosphere is as sweet as can be.  The bruschetta, pancetta wrapped figs and spaghetti carbonara just melts in your mouth.  Let's open one in Seattle so I can return every week.
author: Emerald P.

description:
I've been coming to Nob Hill Cafe for many years and it never disappoints.  Situated a stones throw away from Grace Cathedral in Nob Hill, cute little restaurant in a great location.

Their minestrone is solid, caprese is really good, and their gnocchi is incredible!  Not many places can make a gnocchi where it melts in your mouth.  Their filet sole is not bad as well.

Street parking is a nightmare but they do valet and also there are a couple parking garages a couple blocks away.  Also you can take the California cable car and get off on Taylor.  Lines can be long at times but a great neighborhood to walk around or have some wine outside while you wait.

And if you go on Tuesdays for dinner, the chances of you running into the famous SF Twins is likely.  Sounds like a nice dinner.
author: RICOLE P.

description: Have dined here 3 times in the last month on business trips to San Fran. Hidden gem- with fantastic homemade gnocchi. Small place- great service and food. Reasonable prices- exceptional quality. Definitely worth the uphill climb if you're not staying in Nob Hill. They don't take reservations and are quite popular with the locals- especially for carry out. Friendly wait staff.
author: Susan D.

description: This place is really cute and comfy.  Me and my husband came here for dinner on our first night in San Francisco.  The server was really friendly and helpful!  I had a pizza special (Tequila-lime chicken pizza with avocado & cilantro) and it was SOOOOO good!  My husband had some kind of cheesy pasta and he liked that as well.   What I really liked was the atmosphere...dim-light and cozy.
author: Ines C.

description: This is a great restaurant!  The atmosphere is charming, the staff is friendly and the food is delicious.  I got the spicy penne and my husband got the special, seafood lasagna. Both dishes were fantastic. I highly recommend this restaurant we came on a Monday night about 7:30 and were lucky to get in pretty quickly.  A little later there was quite a wait but I can tell you it is well worth it.
author: Mary M.

description:
YUMMMMM! I love Italian food, but don't go very often because I work at a restaurant where we make all our pasta from scratch; it's hard to top that. But Nob Hill Cafe did.

Ambiance: Cute, neighborhood feel. We could tell there were a lot of regulars, but for a newcomer, expect that it is cozy -- ie: small, and you're close to your neighbor, but we thought it was intimate.

Service: Though it took a little while for our server to get around to us, I realized she was waiting on the entire room and so cut her a little slack (as you should, because most places have 4 table sections rather than 7). But once she visited us, we were taken care of all night in a timely manner. She was incredibly informative, patient, and obliging, as I had some questions. She wasn't afraid to offer suggestions which I appreciate in a server. Especially after reading some of the other reviews, if we go back, I will be asking for the blonde server. 

Food:The wine list is small for SF but there seemed to be some good Italians and some standard Californias. We tried the Valpolicella and it was excellent, incredibly smooth and rich.
The rosemary bread to start was incredible. We ordered the special Waldorf pizza (gorgonzola, spinach, pear, and chicken -- yes please!) as our appetizer, ate about half and took the rest home. It ended up being the perfect amount for lunch. 
He had the Carbonara and it was PERFECT. 
I ordered the Gnocchi Bolognese, partially because I heard the server tell another table that it was homemade. It was the best gnocchi I have ever had in my life. They literally melted in my mouth. Next time I'm thinking I will try them with another sauce, which our server said is very easy to do. I suppose that's the benefit of coming to a place where everything is made to order.
For dessert I tried the tiramisu, which the only thing I would say was pretty standard. You can certainly taste the alcohol, and it is a little on the fluffier side, though I prefer that. It was good, just not outstanding like everything else. 
Now, as far as outstanding desserts, you have to the try gelato/cheescake combo. They layer gelato on top of cheesecake and top it with homemade whip. We tried the pumpkin Grand Mariner and it was phenomonal. They offer it in multiple flavors though and so we will certainly be back, even if solely for the dessert... and gnocchi.
author: Bridgette M.

description: Yummmm, I love finding new spots within walking distance to my hood. This place is awesome. Small intimate setting, very cozzy. Had the gnocci and as an affectionado - it scored high marks. I had it with the meat sauce and Dad had it with pesto, i think next time I'd go pesto. Calzones were big and yummy, great bruccetta. Highly recommend as a bring guests kind of restaurant. NHC is being added to the date night rotation. :)
author: Donna H.

description: Food is consistent and good but you need to avoid busy hours.  8/07
author: Suz L.

description:
I went to this Restaurant two times in two weeks especially because I wanted to give it another chance after a very bad first experience.
I read all the good critics and I am trying to understand why???
The ambiance is poor (extremely poor)...,
They service is very touristic (seat down eat go, next one) and fake,
and the food not something exceptional..
It is not authentic italian, it is not american, and the total expereince is just mediocre.
author: Marios B.

description:
Expect a lengthy wait, its a small place and seems to be quite popular. Is it worth the wait? FInd out for yourself. 

I shared the pizza special with a friend, duck sausage, water chestnuts, straw mushrooms, cilantro and plum sauce. Great start to the night. A little heavy on the cilantro but we were happy with our choice. 

Entrees- Lack luster at best. We had the eggplan parm adn the lasagna, nothing special and we could certianly make something as good at home. 

The entertainment factor was key however, we got to listen to the hostess all night. She was quite stressed out, understandable as managing a waitlist for 14 tables can be quite a challenge..... She inadequately handled several situations during our dinner and she consistently offered a "20 minute wait" to all those entering to be put on the list. 

I wish their entrees were as exacting as the special we ordered. Overall decent food and ambiance, decent/mediocre service. Wouldn't go back.
author: Thomas C.

description: This little cafe in the middle of a quiet street was the perfect place to grab a comforting meal with a close friend. I appreciated their attention to detail when it came to decorating the outside with quaint signs and pretty lights. On a weeknight this place wasn't packed (we also walked in around 9:30pm which could have been why). Bread and butter were immediately served by the lovely waitress. We ordered the carpaccio ($10) to start-- REALLY delicious. I ordered the pasta with pancetta and cream sauce which was really delish. Mine was a pretty hefty portion and I was only able to eat about half of it. Great if you want leftovers, or maybe go family style and share the dishes you order. My friend ordered the lasagna and seemed to really love it. A really cute cafe right in nob hill-- I'll be back!
author: Ashley D.

description: Best gnocchi I have ever had (and I've had some good gnocchi). Light, fluffy pillows of potato heaven, lovingly bathed in a delicately rustic tomato marinara finished with just a touch of cream. Heaven on a plate in a warm, cozy atmosphere. Great place.
author: Nikki J.

description: Local place, no reservations.  Small cozy place, easy to talk, pleasant staff.  Food ok;  blackened salmon to be medium rare, came medium to well.  still tasty but..... not an unpleasant evening,  not a memorable one
author: Stephen S.

description: Great local italian eatery with good pizza and gnocchi. It gets crowded in the evenings with locals since it is probably the best eatery in terms of cost/value on the top of the hill. Also has good takeout food and friendly service.
author: John B.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for this place yet. It is one of my staples. I live a couple of blocks away and it is my absolute favorite neighborhood restaurant (sorry Lalola!). 

When I moved to SF about a year and a half ago, I ate here most nights for two weeks straight. I almost always get their specials and they are almost always fantastic. The seafood pasta, the meatball calzone, the list goes on! When I had my wisdom teeth removed I ordered their butternut squash soup by the vat. 

There are no reservations and the wait is often ridiculous, but as long as it's not too cold outside the wait won't kill you, particularly if you choose to have a glass or two of the very moderately priced wine, while you wait. 

My only gripe: They stopped ordering their cheesecake from Cheesequake. The new cheesecake isn't nearly as good.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This was the highlight of our weekend in San Francisco!

We stumbled upon this place one evening after a long day of walking the city.  We were tired, hungry and unsure where to go.  Yelp steered us in the direction of Nob Hill which was not too far from where we were staying.  

There will be a wait.  Other reviewers mentioned it, so we expected it.  They gave us an estimation of 45minutes, and they were just about right on.  They offered beer or wine, which we didn't take them up on at first.  They were very busy, and the hostess was running all over the place, but she managed it very well and was quite pleasant.

Upon being seated in the little cafe, our waiter came over to chat and check on us, take beverage orders, etc.  We asked for a wine recommendation (wife is not a huge wine fan, but likes certain types).  We asked what he thought and he recommended a Saugv Blanc that ended up being *perfect*.  Great help on the wine selection.  We ordered a bottle and moved on.  

The bread on the table was quite good, and helped to quench our hunger while we waiting on entrees.

The basic pizza was fantastic - great tasting sauce, simple yet tasty crust.  Just exactly what we were looking for.  They also recommended a penne dish that was equally fantastic.   Again, the waiter's recommendations were spot on from start to finish.  

We sat and enjoyed the meal, enjoyed our wine and just sat and talked.  By the time we were done and ready to leave, there was hardly anyone left in the restaurant.  Not once did we feel rushed out or anything.  Even after paying the bill, the server came and offered anything else we could want, refills on water, etc.  Service was, from start to finish, excellent.

Can't wait to return to SF, if only for Nob Hill Cafe!
author: Chris B.

description:
Definitely like this place. Great service and sweet Italian restaurant feel. 

This place is tiny, but perfect for groups of 2 or 4. 

My sister and I split the vodka sauce pasta for lunch the other day, which was sooo tasty and wonderful. Their portions are generous, and the flavors perfect. 

Ordered their ice tea, and was surprised, pleasantly surprised, that it was a tropical flavored ice tea... not sweet, but just had a floral flavor to it. I kinda, totally loved it. 

The service was sweet and quick. Both of the waitresses made pleasant conversation, and one of them reminded us of a blonde version of Zooey DeChanel. 

Loved being in the neighborhood and I definitely recommend you try it out.
author: Shannel G.

description:
My friends and I had a fantastic, fantastic meal here last night.  This place would absolutely get 5 stars if they took reservations--but having to wait 20 minutes on a Tuesday night is always a bummer.

I got the Gnocchi Bolognese and it was cooked to perfection.  I often find Gnocchi too heavy, but these were wonderfully light and the bolognese was rich and hearty, complementing it perfectly.

The staff was wonderful, providing great service and good suggestions.

I highly recommend this place, but I suggest coming here at odd hours if you don't want to wait too--I could only imagine what the wait is like on the weekends!
author: Duncan K.

description: A decent, reasonably priced Italian restaurant, but not impressive. The pesto was fine, the pork special was good (not great), the wine list was adequate. Service was cool bordering on surly. Fortunately it wasn't particularly expensive, otherwise I'd feel pretty badly about the whole experience, but for the price at least I don't feel like I got taken.
author: Michelle T.

description:
I like this place a lot. It's a friendly, cozy, neighborhood joint with great food. Great price for a bottle of the house red, I think $21 and it's not bad. 

Also- the nob hill twins were eating here when I went! I heard they eat here all the time :)
author: Claire b.

description: We are visiting from Philly,a foodie destination, where great Italian food is plentiful, . After dining here Sat. Night my husband and I wish that Nob Hill Cafe was our local neighborhood restaurant. Our fideleini ceccho , fresh tomatoes and basil sautéed in garlic and olive oil served over pasta  was scrumptious. We followed this with tender and delicious Osso  bucco and polenta. The servings were very generous , as were our glasses of a fine Zinfandel. And our waitress was friendly and solicitous.
author: Susan L.

description:
1) Don't miss this place in SF 2) go early! 3) they don't take reservations

Food: 4.5
Service: 4.5
Atmosphere: 5+
Value: 5

Prime location in SF.  Love everything about this place!!
Caveat: go eat early!!! This place fill up fast!! I mean fast!!

while food is great and time between appetizer and main entree lagged a bit so I can imagine during peak time.

All I can say is don't miss this place...cause it's your loss!!
author: B K.

description:
My mouth starts to water just thinking about the Nob Hill Cafe.  I had the best penne pasta EVER here!  

Started out with a small wait, but we were able to snag a table outside and enjoy some wine while we waited.  Afterwards we were escorted to a snug table, but once the food comes, you won't care where you are sitting.  The bread was delicious, the squash soup was even better and definitely "shareable".  I ordered the pasta penne and it is a dish not to be forgotten!  Another person in my group ordered the seafood spaghetti and said it wasn't good, so the food definitely depends on what you order.  

The server was the best server i've had in SF in awhile.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Carly W.

description: I have had mixed experiences at Nob Hill cafe.  The coffee is solid, wet cappacinos delicious.  It's close by and it beat's the Pete's in the basement of Grace Cathedral by a long shot.  But this place is really more of a dinner spot (they do serve lunch, but aren't open in the morning) and I've only had take out, Pizza, to be exact.  But that's where it fell a bit short for me.  I mean they are tottering on the edge of the Italian 'hood of North Beach, I really think they could do a bit better.  It wasn't bad, but very bland, nondescript.  Some of the staff are extremely wonderful, and at least guy, was not so much.  Hoping to return to try the Cal Steak.
author: Sarah Z.

description: The time I went was not good.  There was a huge group of ladies and it was very noisy.  I asked a waitress to change our seats near the window to be away from this noise, but she said no.  Food was ok.  we could not enjoy much with noise.
author: K K.

description: A nice local cafe for when you're feeling too lazy to put a lot of effort into dinner. The food is good, the servers are pleasant, but the wait can be long.
author: Brooke G.

description: I've been here on several occasions and the food has been consistently good.  I think I've ordered a pizza each time I've dined here because it's quite good and for some reason I haven't been tempted to order a pasta dish.  With that said, every time I've been here, the people I've dined with have ordered one of the pasta entrees that looked great.  The atmosphere is pretty casual which makes it great for a weeknight dinner or relaxed weekend dinner.  The dining room is a little cozy, but I think the warm service and reasonable prices more than make up for this.  I don't think they accept reservations but I've rarely had to wait in line for too long.
author: Kent W.

description: I give this restaurant 3 stars mostly for the atmosphere and because the kitchen is open and you can watch them prepare everything. Don't get me wrong, the food was very tasty and the service was great. The only downside of this restaurant is that it is a neighborhood favorite so you might have to wait outside for awhile to get a sit. Once you are in, it is worth it. Good wine selection and good food!
author: Angelle S.

description: one of my favorite places in the city never mind it's right down the street from me. the pasta is the greatest, freshest made pasta. please pass on any soups on the menu, that's not their forte. The polenta starter is killer. I love going there because you feel like family. wonderful, energetic yet calm atmosphere. perfect place.
author: Natalia W.

description:
Heard a lot of hype coming in so I expected a bit more... I thought our server was fantastic she was friendly, funny, and attentive while also unobtrusive. 

However, my appetizer was crummy. Ordered the prosciutto and melon to start (one of my favorite combos ever) and was very disappointed... This is not the hardest dish in the world to get right. The melon was really cold, like straight out of the fridge and at the same time hard and tasteless. The prosciutto had also been lying around for a while, or at least tasted like it... 

Entree served as a redeeming quality. Split a pizza that tasted delicious and was well cooked (crunchy crust). Good cheese and sauce and something I would have again. 

All in I should probably go again and try more items. If they're a lot like the appetizer will never go again, if they're like the pizza might be worthy of an upgrade.
author: Pierre C.

description: Just ate here and it was less than mediocre food. The red sauce in the lasagna was toooo sweet and the cheese wasn't very tasty. I say if you've never had real authentic Italian food then this place is for you!
author: My T.

description:
I love this place!  It is quaint and cozy!  The food is delicious and fairly reasonably priced.  I brought my boyfriend there and he loved the gnocchi.  I ordered one of the specials and it the flavor was to die for.  I think my boyfriend ate half if it.   I always get  prosciutto and melon to begin and the khalua (spelling) dessert to end.  

I like sitting in the green room vs. the room in the front since it is more spacious.  The service is good to.  If you have to wait for a table, they let you drink wine outside while you wait.  The only negative thing I have to say....they don't take reservations!  But the wait is worth it for this delicious food!
author: Michelle B.

description: It's a nice neighborhood restaurant; people always seem to wait outside. The food is good mainly consisting of pasta and pizza with a few additional entrée options. I wish they served olive oil with bread instead of the buffet-style mini wrapped butter.
author: Anna J.

description:
I recently discovered this gem of a restaurant and I am completely smitten. So much so, that my mom and I came here twice in one day. Our hotel also happened to be right around the corner and I was sick at the time, so it was convenient. But even if those weren't the conditions, I would definitely come here twice in one day again.

I love the look and the feel of this restaurant. Perfect for brunch on a rainy day. For breakfast, I had some sort of a breakfast pizza with apple sausage and mushrooms and fontina cheese. For dinner, I had one of the ravioli specials of the night---butternut squash ravioli I think. Excellent caesar salad here as well (my mom even said it was the best of her life).

The service was excellent. The neighborhood, esp. the restaurant being located at the Grace Cathedral's footsteps made for a lovely stroll back. This place and hood reminded me why it's great to live in this city.
author: Jackie M.

description:
I really enjoyed this place. It looks quaint from the outside, but the food is very good, and the place is always packed. All of the waitresses are very friendly and the wait is never long. 

I have ordered the gnocci and the lasagna and both are favorites. I also enjoy their garlic bread which comes with pesto. 

On a side note, I came here with a buddy of mine and we realized that its kind of a couple's place for dinner haha - nevertheless we had a good meal.
author: Steve S.

description:
A Neighborhood Gem!!  Good, consistent, and well priced Italian food.  Evening wait is about 15 minutes usually......but also enjoy a glass of wine outside first which makes it a pleasant wait.

The evening hostess, Liza, is always bursting with a smile and just makes this place warming and welcoming.

You can eat outside for brunch/ lunch.....but not in the evening to be respectful to the neighbors.  On a sunny, it is the perfect place for brunch!
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Five stars for being the authentic Italian/Tuscan restaurant that everyone needs and would love in their 'hood. It ain't the BEST Italian restaurant, but it doesn't try to be. It's just down home, excellently done informal Italian fare. There are no flaws in the execution or food. The service is a bit hectic, the space a bit cramped, however. Expect long waits on the weekends.

Linguine alla Vongole, I can eat you again and again...

'Nuff said.
author: Kevvy K.

description: Nob Hill Cafe has become one of our favorite Italian restaurants in San Francisco. I absolutely love their Penne Limone dish which they have on special from time to time. We always leave Nob Hill Cafe satisfied. The food is fresh and delicious every time we visit. The prices are moderate and staff is friendly.
author: Katherine D.

description:
Nob Hill Café was very highly recommended and we were so glad because we had a delicious Italian dinner. 

The food was terrific and the staff was excellent. We had Caesar Salad, Linguine Tuttomare, prawns and calamari and Cioppino sauce, excellent Italian red wine and for desert we had the chocolate Ganache this was a decadence to die for. 

This is one of my favorite places in the city; it has a charming atmosphere of a true San Francisco Café. Do realize they do not take reservations therefore; you might have to wait a bit if your arrival is after 6:00PM
author: Gigi W.

description:
Service - 5 Stars
Food - 3.5 Stars
Atmosphere - 4 Stars

A friend and I were at the Fairmont Hotel visiting the Tonga Room, and the Concierge recommended this little place.  It was a small walk from the Fairmont, in a quiet neighborhood.

I was not very hungry so I went for the appetizer menu.  I had the Carpaccio dish, which the waitress informed me was raw beef.  I still wanted it because of the onions, Parmesan, and capers.  I drizzled a little lemon over the top, and it was tasty.  I was not blown away by the dish, but then again, I did order raw beef.

My friend ordered the Penne Pasta.  I really enjoyed the tomato sauce, but she was not overly thrilled with it.

For dessert we shared the Tirimisu.  It was good, down the middle of the road for me.  I enjoyed the cute atmosphere of the place.
author: Jason B.

description: I go to Nob Hill Cafe for brunch pretty frequently on the weekends, but only because it's half a block from my apartment.  The brunch is pretty boring.  A lot of times the omelets come out very greasy and the french toast is like mush.  The servers always act like they're going out of their way to help you, but it's clear they would rather spend their time chatting behind the bar.
author: Addie B.

description: A Nob Hill favorite.  You don't find many tourists here even though it's just a block from the hotels.  It has great food.  I think I had the best salad of my life there a few weeks ago for lunch.  I almost don't want to give it a good review in case it gets even more crowded!  They don't take reservations but the wait is not too bad if it's not raining.
author: Gary B.

description:
A cozy, neighborhood eatery.  This place was packed on a Tuesday night.  I was surprised to find folks waiting in the rain for a table. 

Pasta and soup served in big white bowls.  There's something about eating out of a super-sized bowl that makes you feel indulgent and pampered. I should remember this when I'm having a Cathy night, one of those rare evenings when I've scheduled to relax at home.

I had the butternut squash soup and my friend had a pasta dish.  Both were good, but not immensely flavorful.  For me, the bread was memorable - cakey and delicious.  Perfect for dipping in said soup.

They have 2 dining areas, one side with more mood lighting than the other.  Suggest getting here by 6pm, before the dinner rush.
author: Cathy K.

description: One of my favorite local restaurants.  They have amazing homemade Italian food.  My favorite dish is the Penne Bettola!  Great brunch on the weekends too.
author: Lisa V.

description:
Good, very affordable pasta.  I had creamy pesto pasta with the addition of sausage. topped nicely with toasted pine nuts.  Yum and good portions.  -Prompt service.  -Neighborhood romantic.  However, it was really hot...sweating and eating is not fun.  
-and the wine list is poor. -but overall, absolutely recommended.
author: Jake H.

description:
Nob Hill Cafe is a real area gem. I first ate here about 3 years ago while on vacation, and recently since I moved into the City. Both times so good. On my most recent visit, three of my girlfriends and I showed up around 730pm on a Saturday and had about a 30 minute wait. We sipped wine at a table outside. Once we were seated at our table, we ordered two orders of bruschetta for the table. The slices were generous, and piled high with tomatoes. My sister and I split the DELICIOUS lasagna. Our two other friends (one is vegan) split a simple salad and yummy spaghetti with olive oil and steamed veggies. The kitchen split the dish for them into separate bowls without an extra charge, or even being asked. It was plenty of food for all of us, we didn't feel stuffed at the end of the meal and were happy our wallets weren't suffering either - $90 bill before tip (including 5 glasses of wine). The following day, none of us could stop thinking about how wonderful the food was the night before!

The customer service is adequate, but not overly impressive. The hostess wasn't around when we first walked in, so we weren't sure who to speak to, or if we should just write our name down on the list.

I CANNOT wait to eat there again, and will definitely be ordering take-out next time I have a craving for Italian food.
author: Emily B.

description:
The cable car drivers call it Snob Hill. Maybe it is, maybe it's not, but there's at least one reason to make the trek. The Nob Hill Cafe!

It's such an adorable little place! Candle-lit and romantic, this gem is in Nob Hill proper, and the kind of restaurant that makes you double-take because of its authentic neighborhood charm. Any night of the week, the windows are glowing with happy diners lingering cozily over bottles of wine and huge plates of pasta.

Natalie G and I were lucky. We went on a hot August night, when everyone wanted to be outside enjoying the bizarre weather, and we got a table immediately. We had luckily run into Phil H and his doggie Willie on their evening stroll a few minutes prior, and got some hot tips on what to order.

Mamma mia! The pizza at this place is freaking fantastic. As in, I ate 4 pieces. Any thoughts of portion control went right out the window, along with my inhibitions. Next came a meaty gnocchi, and while I wasn't head over heels for the sauce, the gnocchi was obviously house-made, with a lovely soft doughy texture that melted in my mouth.

My adoration for the place only compounded when I heard "the twins" hang out here. You know the ones? With the matching Chanel suits. Yes!
author: Nicole G.

description: They get three stars just for being so nice about letting my girl use the bathroom.  As close as they are to Huntington Park and Grace Cathedral, I'm sure they're sick of people asking to use their facilities.  The kid and I were walking from North Beach to Cala and her tiny, not-quite-5-year-old bladder wasn't going to make it.  I was surprised when I entered the place...I had walked past it dozens of times and had always assumed it was hoity-toity, but it is very much a neighborhood cafe.  And it smelled wonderful in there!  I will definitely be back for dinner and look forward to updating this partial review.
author: Valeria R.

description: Excellent, locally loved. Must try the carbonara. It's small and cozy an there will be a wait even on a week night, but it will be worth it.
author: Laura O.
