description: Been going to NHC frequently for a while and never disappointed. My GF is addicted to the gnocchi and I don't blame her.  Nice neighborhood atmosphere.  If there's a wait, grab a beer or glass of wine and hang outside.
author: Ben E.

description:
For quite a long time i would always walk  by this lovely place, during the night. And one of those times i got to see the famous San Francisco Twins, eating at a table by the window. 
 So any who just the other day my boyfriend and i went out to celebrate  our 5th yr anniversary. as i searched yelp, to find a Italian restaurant near our place i happen to see the restaurant i had walked by many times. On the day we went it was raining, and we were in a hurry to get there to stay dry and to warm up. Lucky for us we arrived just in time before a line started forming!!!

We were just in luck, anywho lets get to the best part! THE FOOD!! lol!!
I had the Gnocchi Bolognese which was:  homemade potato dumplings with ground beef, sausage & pomodoro......
My Bf had the Lasagne al Forno with:  italian sausage, ground beef, red wine & ricotta 
And we both had Mimosa's.. for dessert we had: 
Tiramisu 
Espresso and Rum dipped Ladyfingers layered with Mascapone and Marsala , and 
Ganache
Chocolate and Cream blended together to a Rich Velvet Texture ..
which was all so yummy!!!!! we will definitely come back!

Great price! Great Service! Great Food!
author: Silvia C.

description:
Consistently good, reasonably priced food.  Simple Italian food in a simple atmosphere.  No reservations but you probably won't wait more than 30 minutes.  The staff is a little rushed but it's a tiny, hectic place.  Definitely the smallest restroom in the Bay Area.

Great place for an early-in-relationship date (see, e.g., reasonably priced and not too formal) or to take an out-of-towner (very quaint and you may see the Nob Hill Ladies).  If you want upscale and fancy, go up the street to Venticello...otherwise definitely eat here.
author: Geoff K.

description:
Bad news: they don't take reservations and you will wait
Good news: you can order from the bar while you wait outside
Best news: the delicious smells coming from the kitchen do not disappoint

The perfect neighborhood setting. There are tiny tables to sit out while you wait and the wine list has some decent priced bottles of reds (the Sangiovese was worth $25). The menu may not be long, but it's crafted well. Antipasti, Pasta, Pizza, Entrees and Secondi. The one page will leave you with many options and don't miss the chalk board on the wall for a list of nightly specials.

 The garlic bread is a must order with a garlic, pesto and olive oil spread. I had the Melezane salad (eggplant) and it was great.  Charming, filling, wine, nice, delicious sums up NH Cafe.
author: Theresa T.

description:
I gave it three stars for the food only.  The food was really good. We had the calamari and I had the margarita pizza and Michael had the nookie. It was all good.
I had arrived earlier then Michael arrived shortly there after. The hostess was very nice she sat us right away. But our server was not that great. He completely ignore Michael.  We felt rushed and our server did not mentioned to us about the specials of the day nor did he ask us if we wanted dessert . I am hoping that not all of the servers are this way. 

The location is nice and the decor is cute but snug like bug in a rug. Great for couples. I will see if I will come here again.
author: Der Maibaum L.

description: The caprese salad was good. I ordered the clam pasta. It was very bland. My friends ordered the pesto and spicy tomato sauce pasta. Those were better. The restaurant is tiny too. I imagine it must be a place where you really just need to know what to order.
author: Dr J.

description:
My absolute favorite in San Francisco. 

It has a super cozy neighborhood feel, a wonderful brunch, my favorite is the Pizzetta Di Salsicia.  It's also a great alternative to North Beach for a delicious italian dinner. I have taken out of town guests here who love it and love that it feels like a local place, not a super touristy location.

http://thatswhatwesaid.us/
author: Claire and Josh P.

description:
Delicious neighborhood spot. No resos though, so there tends to be a small crowd outside even on a week night. The caesar salad was a little disappointing, but my clams over linguine with garlic, white wine and olive oil definitely made up for it. The pizzas are also of note along with the veal scallopini. It's a perfect spot for a first date, date night, casual dinner with a couple friends or to take the 'rents out when they're in town.

Don't forget to try the homemade tiramisu for dessert.
author: Defne A.

description:
3.5 stars

This is a review by a vegetarian (who was making a foray into the land of the blonde)

Rarely have a witnessed a restaurant that so completely is representative of the stereotype of the people living in it's neighborhood. I arrive before the rest of my party and sat out front at one of the nice little tables. Blonde children came with their blonde parents. Not-quite-natural middle aged blonde women in semi-fancy but oh-so-casual expensive clothes feigned excitement at seeing each other and almost touched while faux kissing each other. The regular occupying a primo table in the window nursed his pizza like a broke sailor salting his beer. His solo dining experienced lasted more than an hour while crowds gathered in expectation of being shown to a table before nightfall.

The host called my name while there were just 2 of the 3 of us present, so we had to wait. This would have been fine if we had been put at a table for four, but we were squeezed into a table for 2. Not sure why 2 of us couldn't have hunkered there just as well.

The bruchetta was well prepared on crispy bread with copious garlic and basil but the tomatoes were tasteless. I can't blame them for that though: don't order uncooked tomatoes in early spring. Those suckers aren't ready yet.

One guests eggplant was "bitter". The other guest very much enjoyed the waldorf salad pizza , one of the chalkboard specials. My linguine with olive oil and garlic was good and not overpriced at $9. Service was attentive but the waitress politely demured when asked for suggestions. She did offer useful information when queried about dish A vs dish B.

Certainly not a dining destination, but if you happen to be around it's fine and good.

Don't drive here. There is valet a block away for $10 and a garage two blocks the other way for about $15. You can't park in the neighborhood on the street for more than 2hrs  before 9pm unless you A) drive a teeny car with interdimensial capabilities & B) have a local permit
author: Bob R.

description:
Never had a bad meal here! It's inexpensive, cozy, and has great food.. I really really love this place. More than likely you will always have to wait for a table, but that always gives you time to have a glass of vino! (try the Chilean red.. YUM) What's good?

- Veggie appetizer- UH-MAZING choice for vegetarians.. a place full of veggies for 2 .. Not sure why its an appetizer because it would probably take me three meals to finish. 
-Garlic Bread with Pesto (duh)
-Lasagna (no brainer)
- Pasta with Clams HEAVENLY!
- Pasta Carbonera

Do yourself and your mouth a flavor.. I mean favor and go here ;)
author: Sarah W.

description: Great food. Fun atmosphere. Friendly service (our waitress Robin was fantastic!).
author: Kevin C.

description:
Last night, my lady and I were looking for a place to get a good meal that wasn't too far from the house or expensive and having passed NHC on several occasions we decided to give them a call.  The wait was only about 15-25 minutes so we grabbed a bottle of Frank Family Cab and walked on over.  

I stepped the door and put our name in and the hostess immediately asked if she could open our bottle and bring us some wine glasses outside to the tables while we waited, and this was, unfortunately, where the good service ended.  Drinking our cab outside, we noticed a pair of old twin ladies dressed in identical red cowgirl outfits sitting in the window.  The hostess informed us that this creepy pair liked to dine their twice a week and warned us not to get too close lest we get trapped in a 45 minute conversation about nothing.

The wait wasn't too bad.  The inside was a little cramped but charming in its own sort of neighborhoody kind of way.  I don't really mind places that don't take reservations, it can actually be a good change of pace.  We sat down and they brought us bread.  The Foccacio was really good.  I started with the carpaccio drizzled in a mustard sauce, capers and lemon.  My girlfriend had the roasted roma tomato and eggplant salad which also featured mounds of slightly cooked feta.  The carpaccio was good and even better when paired with the bread and some of the salad.  The melanzane salad was one of the better parts of the meal and I like carpaccio (the quality of the beef was pretty good) with some greens to lighten it up a little bit.

Which brings us to dinner.  Because I would literally say that the span between the time they picked up our appetizers and put down our bowls of pasta couldn't have been more than about 30-45 seconds.  This and the fact that the waiter probably hadn't said more than about six words to us up to that point is ultimately what hurt NHC most.  

The food, though, was pretty good.  My girlfriend got a penne with spicy pomodoro sauce that was actually very flavorful.  I had the spaghetti alla carbonara.  It was an excellent pasta dish.  The romano and butter that coated the spaghetti was rich and delicious and the pancetta added a delicious salty component.  It was finished with some parsley to add some herb influence.  I highly recommend this as long as you feel like indulging yourself.  

To sum up the rating, the prices and $15 corking fee were very reasonable.  The apps and the spaghetti were all great but not incredible by any stretch.  Ultimately, it was probably the service that kept them from going any higher, but I would recommend giving it a shot.  We all have off nights.
author: Matt S.

description: This is one of those places that you go to when you want a good solid meal while staying in Nob Hill.  They do not take reservations, so don't come hungry.  The North Italian cuisine is good and the wine list is solid for a small SF restaurant.  The service was the one thing that sat this restaurant apart from others that I ate ate while in Nob Hill.  Waiter was very intimate with the menu and offered up the Gnocchi Bolognese as his favorite entree which was one of the best gnocchi I have had in a long long time.
author: Happy O.

description:
GOOD FOR ME MEAL for 2 : great place to eat for lunch. 

Starter: Grilled veggies platter (grilled veggies, on top of a garden salad mix with balsamic vinegar & slices of mozzarella)

Main Course: Potato Dumplings in a red meat sauce.

Drinks: H2O

Desert: 1 Hr of Exercise
author: Damion H.

description: Excellent food (highly recommend the chicken Parmesan and antipasto). I didn't love the gnocchi, to be honest, although other reviewers loved it. It was sort of one-note. The service was friendly and prompt, and the prices were fair.  Tourists beware, the walk is absolutely killer from union square. Bring a Sherpa.
author: Courtney W.

description:
[previous review deleted, please refer to below]

-------------------------------------------------UPDATE---------------------------------
Okay, So I have been going here fairly often as the food and service keeps getting better.

I'm eating dinner here and I am having an argument with my bf. What I want to do is slam my wine glass on the table for emphatic purposes, you know, to get my point across.

Before I know it, the stem shatters beneath my hand and I am still holding the upper part of the glass in my hand.  I'm looking down at the table mortified as the glass splashes everywhere.

Saving Grace: our waiter comes over, takes away the glass, does nothing to draw attention to us (I'm mouthing "I'm so sorry" over and over).  He comes back with another glass--this one filled to the top--puts his hand on my shoulders, smiles at me, and says, "Let's all have a good time."

His voice comes out beautifully and calms me immediately.  There is no judgment there, no head shaking, no glaring eyes, nothing.  He just wants me to have a good time.

Lesson learned: the next time I want to do something for emphasis, it is better to throw the contents of my wine glass in my bf's face rather than slam the glass down on the table.
author: Tangerine L.

description:
Nob Hill Cafe is a treasure! I try to come here once a month. The restaurant itself is rather small, but very charming. On Friday nights you'll be able to catch the Brown twins, the elderly sisters who are so famous for their matching outfits and double mint commercials. 

Everything on the menu is delicious, and you can never go wrong with any of the specials on the chalkboard.I'm partial to the caprese salad, any of the gnocchi, and the linguine with claims. I've never had the room for dessert, but I'm sure it's delicious as well. 

I've got two gripes - they don't take reservations, so be prepared to wait outside. Luckily the staff is more than willing to accommodate you with a bottle of wine during your wait. I also wish they opened for brunch before 11. I always try to wait it out, but end up going somewhere else earlier!
author: Kelly C.

description:
So, I'm in San Francisco for a meeting at the Fairmont and after the meeting I'm hungry for some lunch. Since the car was already parked in a garage and I didn't have a pocketful of change to re-park in another, undoubtedly metered, area, I decided to take a walk around the area (or at least the small area that I could walk without having to endure an 85 degree incline) and see what it had to offer. 

I passed the Nob Hill Cafe a couple of times, but not being in the mood for Italian, kept walking. Since I didn't find much else, I decided to check yelp mobile and see how this Nob Hill Cafe rated. 4 stars? Okay, I shouldn't be disappointed at least, so I decided to give it a try. 

After being seated, I glance up at the specials board and see one of the offerings is Seafood Lasagna. Prawns, calamari and scallops in a lobster bisque sauce, topped with mozzarella. Sounds different, sounds good, let's go for it. 

Upon first taste, i wasn't overly impressed. Good, but definitely not great. As i went deeper into the dish, I must admit that it got better. I found some surprise lump crab meat which wasn't mentioned in the description, but was a nice surprise as far as I'm concerned. Had I not liked crab, that may have been a problem, but thankfully I do. 

The atmosphere was nice and the service was quick, but the waitress was kind of surly. I'll give her the benefit of the doubt and say it was a bad day. 

Overall, it wasn't bad, but nothing to write home about either. In a city with so many extraordinary restaurants, I don't know if I would give this one a second try.
author: Dave W.

description:
We just moved a block away from here. Were it not for the seemingly consistent wait, it's possible that this would be our default dinner many times a week.

Our wait last night was about 20 minutes- not hideous, but also not fun. The restaurant is too small to accommodate people waiting indoors, so we froze outside. However, once we were in the restaurant, all complaints melted away. It's really cute and neighborhoody and the waitress was very prompt. We ordered two mista salads, bf had chicken parmesan, and I had the lasagna. Also we ordered a coke and a diet coke- IN BOTTLES! (automatic brownie points)

The focaccia that came in the bread basket was insanely good. I wasn't in the mood for bread, but I couldn't help myself and destroyed the whole slice in 2 seconds- No butter or oil needed. Our salads arrived quickly and were large, simple, and pretty good. 2 people could probably split one.

Our entrees also arrived in no time. My lasagna was better than the chicken parmesan, yet we both enjoyed our meals. Neither was so hideous you'd never order it again- just the chicken was bland. The lasagna was fulfilling and tasty, but I'd be curious to try something else next time. Overall, it was a wonderful experience and I'm looking forward to many more meals here.

* By the way, I'm guessing from the Yelp reviews and our experience last night that The Twins live awful close. This must be their go-to as well.
author: Amanda C.

description: Had a nice bottle of wine with a delicious salad. The pesto with chicken was a little bland but overall was good.
author: Tom U.

description:
If I want an aging, obese white man to make me feel inadequate, I can spend a Sunday morning with my father.  

After living in the neighborhood for nearly a year, Amanda F. and I finally gave Nob Hill Cafe a try for one of our treasured weekend brunches.  

Admittedly, it was almost 11 am that Sunday morning and I had yet to have any coffee or food and my hangover was flashing me back to high school and the last time I forgot to wear a jockstrap with protective cup during a basketball game.  Suffice it to say, I was feeling a little fragile.

And the day was beautiful.  Nearby Huntington Park was crisp and humming with local artists' displays and children under the clear blue sky you rarely find in San Francisco except on a postcard.  And I was ready for some breakfast lovin'.  As I stood on the emotional precipice of this potentially dark moment, I was ready for the one thing in the world that would make me feel like a human being, the redemption from a night of lascivious extravagance and the impending doldrum of another grinding workweek.

I wanted breakfast.  I wanted it piping hot.  I wanted it quickly.  I wanted a quiet place with the soft tinkling of serving ware and the classy notes of a rich wood gramophone or musicbox.  I wanted a newspaper.  I wanted coffee so hot and black as to blister my tongue and burn away to coldness of my soul.  I wanted a beautiful face across the table (Christ, at least I had that) and a newspaper and not to think about one sorry dirty dish.

And we unwittingly arrived at NHC a few minutes before it "opens", even though the chairs and tables were out and both sets of doors (I'll come back to this, but what kind of fractured, irreligious monster expects a new patron to figure that one out?) open and those inviting breakfast smells almost visibly creeping out into the street like a Warner Bros. cartoon.

And there he was, my nemesis, the all-hating anti-semitic Irish god of destruction that turned us poor supplicants back, without offering even the meager succor of a friendly mien or apologetic explanation of the burdens of opening a fine cafe.

Nothing (while my simple mind wrestled with the two doorways, each with a top/bottom half door set-up, the bottom of which I clumsily discovered was locked) but, 

"We are not open." (Read: If you try that locked bottom door again you churl I just might kill you.)

"But, Sir, you appear to be open." (Read: Dear God I just want some coffee.)

"We open at 11." (Read: If I wasn't so hopelessly obese I would reach for my grandfather's scimitar I keep behind the breakfast bar to eviscerate you and with your entrails add a bit of "Jewish" cuisine to my menu .)

"What time is it now?" (Read: I don't think I can make it to 11.)

"10:53." (Read: You will never be welcome.)

Amanda F. and I conferred.  Against my better judgment, we waited in the park and returned at 11:10 to be certain.

Quasimodo sat us down at the window overlooking Taylor St., which was a blessing because it meant my back was to him, sharpening his knives, and the skin-crawling forest green walls of the interior.  Too dark for breakfast, says Amanda F.?  Too dark for anyone who still can't shave all their body hair and run naked through a children's cancer ward screaming, "We're all gonna die!"

No soymilk for my latte (Look, I told you I was feeling fragile).  Only 2%.  Amanda F. hinted I might find the bathroom amusing.  If by amusing she meant an obvious health violation with the close proximity of human defecation to food service hardly separated by a a vinyl draw, not to mention that only Gary Cooper would find it spacious.

 I was ready to leave.  Why did I not? The calming tones of Amanda F. telling me to stop being a jackass.

Ok.  So we ate.  The food was impeccable.  Omelet, hot and steamy with fresh white cheese and ingredients all high-quality.  I disagree with Amanda F. on the coffee which I found unremarkable but fine.  For its location and quality it was not overpriced and we were served our food promptly.

Who the hell cares?  I didn't go there for the food or the cost.  I went there because there was something missing inside of me that I desperately needed to find in the embrace of a warm meal delivered with care.  With care, as in, "I care that you are not feeling well" or "Let me take care of you when you are feeling like you just had a visectomy."

That bastard stole something from me and I can never have that morning back.

Think about that next time "Snob Hill Cafe" sends out an inviting vibe.  Think about your insides ripped out and twisted and squeezed and charbroiled in front of you and then fed to starving baby birds.

Then ask yourself if a goddamn good omelet is worth it.
author: Donny S.

description: Best Italian place in San Francisco, outside of North Beach.  Call 15 minutes ahead for great take-out service.
author: Cory L.

description:
It's a great establishment and of course, a San Francisco land mark and tradition. The food... impeccable! It's great to go with friends, a date or just by yourself. The wait staff is friendly and the atmosphere is nice.

Food is just to die for. It's the kind of food that makes you feel all comfy and warmed up inside on a cold evening. Great wine list and the prices are not so bad.

My ONLY caveat is with the "host". The 5 times that I have been there, the host on duty has been a bit snippy, giving attitude and the message I got was "you're inconveniencing me so please just leave and come back later". I'm a pretty reasonable and down to earth guy and friendly so perhaps they're just overworked. That's the only thing that prevents me from giving it 4 Stars.

Other than that... go for it. But beware of the Guardian HOST. :)
author: Amit S.

description: I had the salad with grilled chicken and the portion was an awesome size. My other half had the Caprese Scramble, which was a great size and he really enjoyed it. I'd definitely go back and try something more adventurous.
author: N S.

description:
i'm not feeling cool or funny but hopefully this will be useful!

Great Food
Great Wine List 
Great Neighborhood Location

Overall - great!
author: Whitney N.

description:
Would actually like to try the food, as it did smell excellent. Waited five minutes on a Thursday night for the waiter to finish chatting with a couple in front of us who then proceeded to leave the doorway and wait for their table.I then stepped up to the door to put my name on the list, only to have this arrogant snot waiter try to close it in my face.  He grabs the door from slamming at the last second, pokes his head out and queries, "do you need something?".  Yeah, jackass, a little 'hospitaliano'....I don't even think you would get that greeting at The Olive Garden on their worst night.  After being in the biz better than a decade, I don't care how slammed you are, that's beyond the pale, when dealing with a customer or even the grease trap guy....
Hopefully better luck next time.  Wound up @ Max's...
author: Johnnie W.

description: We don't seat incomplete parties, even when 3/4 of our restaurant is empty, so go wait out in the San Francisco cold for your friend to get here.
author: Jesse S.

description:
Not a bad place for decent Italian food. I usually order take out. The portions are filling. If you're skeptical, try the pizza or lasagna. 

As for the restaurant, it's small but quaint. The wine list is not large either. We tried going to the restaurant on a Friday night, and since we were early, we got seated within 10 minutes. It gets pretty busy though. Another couple waited what I believe was 20 minutes for a table. The restaurant also has two front table seats that I think they only reserve for "special" guest--like those older twin ladies that walk around San Francisco wearing the same outfit everyday. 

To sum it up, okay food, small restaurant, and a little wait if you have time. Order take out instead.
author: Maureen B.

description: A place for dine in or takeout right atop Nob Hill with great Italian food and reasonable prices?  Yep. Gnocci with bolognese a house favorite.  This is truly a local hangout - small with tons of ambiance.  Locals sip red wine, dine off the specials menu on an old school chalkboard.  Just north of the cathedral - worth it!  Go!
author: Tom K.

description: I just moved right down the street  this place so we had to try it! We went on a Friday afternoon and we were seated right away, but I imagine it gets pretty busy later in the evening. We were seated by a very friendly hostess. I ordered an eggplant salad and a glass of pinot grigio. My friend ordered the butternut squash gnocchi. We were served really good, fresh bread and after consuming the entire basket our friendly hostess brought us over another basket. My eggplant salad was fresh, light and basically perfect. I had a bite of my friend's gnocchi and I found it to be good, but the cream was a bit too rich for my taste. Oh, and my pinot went perfectly with my salad. I'll be visiting this place again!
author: Natalie M.

description: Such a great place!  I am staying at the Fairmont Hotel and based on Yelp reviews, I suggested this cafe for dinner with two colleagues.  We had a fantastic meal at very reasonable prices for the area (dinner with wine for 3 people under $100).  We all loved our entrees (Veal, Cod, and Pesto Linguine), and the bread served was out of this world.  Two caveats; the place is tiny and older, so understand you should expect tight spaces and an eclectic ambiance.  If you are looking for a neighborhood place for really tasty food, you have found it.
author: Heather T.

description: Olive garden eat your heart out. Nob Hill Cafe is the best Italian food I've ever had in the states! Absolutely a must! Everything on the menu is to die for. Great service, warm hospitality and excellent food!!
author: Austin B.

description:
This is my favorite place to eat in San Francisco. Period. 

Growing up, my family went to church across the street at Grace Cathedral, and would every so often walk down the block for a nice casual lunch/dinner. The food here is so mouthwatering yummy that it is well worth the hour long wait, because they don't take reservations, outside in the cold city night. My suggestion? Simply order a bottle of Sangiovese or Pinot Grigio and enjoy the wait because the food is well worth it!

My suggestion for dinner if it's your first time is to try the lasagna or gnocchi...but, as I've said to every person that I've taken to eat here, there is nothing on the menu, or the specials board, that would be the wrong choice. And if you love chocolate like I do, you must go for the ganache. In addition to lunch and dinner, they serve an excellent brunch on the weekends. The staff is very friendly and are just attentive enough to be helpful but not bothersome.

For it being in Nob Hill, it is surprisingly not uptight. I've dined at the Nob Hill Cafe in everything from jeans and a t-shirt, to a sparkly New Years Eve dress . A favorite of my family's, my friends, and mine, I will be going to this place until I die! 

If you're looking for reasonably priced, delicious Italian, in a great casual neighborhood atmosphere, then I suggest you make the trek up the hill. If you have the patience to wait for it, you'll definitely leave more than satiated.
author: Tory K.

description:
I can't get enough of this place!  Seriously, the wine is great and the location is so cute...so cute!

The best part is the Spaghetti al Pomodoro e Basilico Fresco.  Now, this is my absolute favorite Italian dish because it is so Italian.  A few fresh ingredients added at just the right time.  Now, it is tricky because it doesn't seem that hard to make, and it's not.  However, that being said, it is easy to screw up.  You need timing and just the right amount of everything.

Nob Hill Cafe has brilliantly achieved this every time I've been in.  The service is friendly and the atmosphere is warm and inviting, cozy and perfect. 

This one of my favorite places in San Francisco.
author: Jess S.

description:
This place is quaint and cozy, serving some wickedly delicious Italian cuisine.  Healthy portions... allowing you to fill up on a great meal while leaving enough left over for a fantastic lunch the following day.  And another reason to hit up the gym after work.  

A bit too cramped in the front - with no standing room to speak of.  This equates to some very chilly, windy nights when you have to wait for a table. And since they don't take reservations, you can plan on doing a lot of waiting.  My advice?  Bring someone who is sure to provide witty banter. Or if you can't find anyone to keep your mind off the wait and potentially the chilly air, pack a crossword puzzle.  That way you'll have a side of good old fashioned fun to go along wtih your penne.
author: Whitney H.

description: My wife and I went here while vacationing in San Francisco over the summer.  This is mainly an Italian type place, and it definitely has good food.  It isn't too expensive, especially considering you're in San Francisco, where I'm convinced the word "cheap" doesn't exist.  I had the gnocchi pasta which was very good.  Not wonderful, but very good.  My wife had another pasta dish which she liked.  There are only a couple things I didn't like about this place.  First, the place is very small and is very busy.  There is no place to stand inside and wait for your table.  Secondly, you are forced to sit outside at these patio type tables while waiting for your table.  This would not be a big deal, except for the fact that in San Francisco in the evening it gets quite chilly.  My wife and I waited for a good 20 minutes and were freezing our butts off by the time we got inside.  Overall, this place is good, but the waiting outside in the cold gives it 4 stars from me.
author: Derek H.

description:
I LOVE the Nob Hill Cafe.  It's only a block from where I live, and there's no better place in the city to go for an amazing breakfast.  They don't open until 11, but it's worth the wait.  Their french toast is to die for, covered in powdered sugar, fresh strawberries and raspberries.  I always end up eating half of someone else's if they order it.  Their shrimp and avocado omelet is also good if you don't like a sweet breakfast.  With perfect outdoor seating, great hot chocolate and delicious mimosas, the Nob Hill Cafe is breakfast heaven.

When my friend recently broke up with her boyfriend, I suggested the Nob Hill Cafe for dinner.  The wait was about a half hour, but since I'm only a block away we went back to my place an had some wine while waiting.  Since their wait time isn't always what they say it is, I called while at my place and they told me exactly when to come in.  We sat at a cute little table inside and had a fresh Caprice salad, good Chianti and she had a sausage pizza while I tried the lasagna- they all were all perfect.  My friend's mind was off her split and we had a great time chowing down.

Bottom line: try this place if you're in the middle of the city and want something quieter.  I guarantee you'll love it.
author: Jessica C.

description: Super cute place, went on a Wednesday evening right around 6 and were sat right away... I know it fills up quickly and there is often a wait, but it's a great place to try out. Delicious, reasonably priced italian food. Cute atmosphere, and our waitress was a doll. Perfect for a cheap quick meal or a glass of wine!
author: Victoria J.

description:
How unlike the mighty Parthenon that o'er looks storied Athens!

The Parthenon was decorated with the most lavish and distinguished marbles, frescoes, and statues splendid. Nob Hill Cafe, in all her humble glory, would know not where to place such spectacles! And even a shrew might titter at the woeful prospect of dancing to the latest harpsichord melodies in this veritable Black Hole of Calcutta. 

Nay, even Sir Jonathan Swift would scratch his head before creating a wretched race of diminutive half-dwarfs able and willing to sit in this dining room!

Spare me any rhetoric to the contrary!

Even we esteemed Penwells, with our venerable crypt near St. Bartholomew, might denounce Nob Hill Cafe as a precursor to entombment. 

Just last Lords Day, an old acquaintance and former prefect, the insufferable Charles Robin H. Culpepper received an accidental jab to his spectacles at the elbow of a serving girl. How fortunate that such an outrage befell this boring dinner guest and not yours truly.

But do such perils overcompensate for the whimsical gnocchi?

Perhaps.

I leave such philosophical quandaries to my cherished readers. Do you value your gymnastic freedom to rise and gallantly mingle about the room? Or do you prefer pastas made before your very eyes?

Oh, the Lord gives us two questions for every answer!
author: Oliver P.

description:
Consistently good-but-not-excellent food, with nice atmosphere and
reasonable prices. It's _the_ comfortable-italian-place for the part of
Nob Hill centered around Grace Cathederal. It's also the only place to 
dine within the 5 block distance without climbing hills and/or paying far 
more at Venticello ( which has better food, at higher prices, and requires 
reservations ).

The only two downsides:
 - Rarely is the food great; but it is always good.
 - Quite often there is a line.

But if you're in the neighborhood you can't really go wrong with it.
author: Max R.

description:
Nob Hill Cafe has food that takes me back to Italy. It contends with my favorites in North Beach and doesn't have all the tourists. I came here with Nicole G. on a Wednesday night and made it by 6:30, just before the rush came. They sat us right away at the last open seat in the house. I wouldn't imagine coming here with more than 3-4 people, you would take up the whole place!

Since we heard through the grapevine that you should try a pizza and pasta we did just that. We both were impressed by the fresh bread that came first...  I am however always a sucker for a good slice (or two). Next, we got the house Margarita pizza. It was very cheesy and simple. A great staple dish to start off the first half of our meal. Next was the gnocchi, which the waitress explained was homemade. It was so different than other gnocchi I have had. Probably because it was just made. It has a meat sauce and I cleared my plate. 

The atmosphere was cozy and warm. I could see myself ending up here on a rainy night with nothing but an empty stomach and a need for a Peroni.
author: Natalie N.

description: Delicious Italian food, great service, and great prices for SF! Really enjoyed dinner here.
author: Deanna B.

description: Took a hike in the windy cold for this place. And it was worth it. Nice, intimate dining room, would be great for a date (maybe a little noisy though, can't remember). Gnocchi Bolognese w/ fennel and sausage was great. The chicken parm and lasagna look very good as well.
author: A A.

description: I came here for dinner and I got the eggplant dish! It was pretty good. Only thing is that the wait time took a while but otherwise, the service was good
author: Amanda L.

description:
Absolutely amazing!  A hidden local gem, it hides on the top of Nob Hill, a block from grace cathedral.  

It is almost always is full, but after just a short wait, your reward is worth it.  I typically ask for a seat in the green room.  It has such a romantic feel with dimmed lights, and warm cosy atmosphere.

You will often see the Twins of San Francisco sitting in the window, enjoying a little company wearing matching outfits.
author: Kai N.

description: Great location, prices and of course, delicious food!
author: Liz D.

description:
I've been here once to eat during the non-touristy season and the food was good.  Based on that experience I returned in August, only to find a line of people waiting outside.  The waitress took my name and told me 30 minutes.  Then I waited with my date for 45 minutes.  I went in and asked about how long, and was told there were still 4 couples ahead of us!  Frustrated at waiting 45 minutes for no purpose, I complained and left.  I won't be returning.  There's a good French place right down the street (walk towards the water) that is not so crowded.  We had dinner there.

p.s. "having a drink outside" means "stand on the sidewalk and drink"
author: Kent L.

description: Came here with a friend's family who is italian and it was amazing! I was really impressed with the portion sizes and the price. A legit italian place! It's small and quaint and can get quite busy so be forewarned. I got the penne bettola (penne al a vodka) and it was delish!
author: Keegan M.

description: Great gnocchi and pizza...plus the Nob Hill twins are a fixture in the window every Tuesday evening and they always wave to Willie when we walk by.  That makes me feel all fuzzy inside.  Glad it's a block from my house.
author: phil h.

description:
Tasty menu, with lots of dishes that are just as ambitious as they need to be.  Losing a star for really noisy tables next to the kitchen, and no heat lamps outside while waiting (30") for a table. 

Be warned!: The gnocchi special was so delicious that I ate it ALL and it put me into a serious food coma (think: curled up, fetal position, groaning).

Update: Went back on a Friday night and they were totally understaffed with rather rude service.  Not changing the 4-star rating, since the food is great, but check it out on a school-night isntead.
author: Heather C.

description:
This spot is great. It's inexpensive with great food. They serve great American food like eggs and home fried potatoes, club sandwiches, BLT, and yummy milkshakes and malts. My favorite is the eggs and home fried potatoes. The eggs is never over cooked and potatoes is always crispy in the outside but soft in the inside, well seasoned. 

It's really cozy and a great neighborhood breakfast/lunch spot.
author: Juliane N.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for here. I have only eaten dinner here. My hubby and I are pretty predictable, pasta for me and pizza for him. We love the food and how fresh it is. The deserts are also really good.

I do like the fact they do not take reservations as I'm sure they would probably be booked out far in advance.

The wait staff are always friendly and cheerful!

You're always sure to catch our famous SF twins Marian and Vivian.

I really need to catch brunch here so they can earn those 5 stars.
author: Christina B.

description: We dined here last Wednesday for lunch as it was highly recommended by the hotel. The cafe was very quaint and cozy. The service was fantastic. We were greeted by a friendly hostess and seated immediately. We ordered the calamari and pizza which were both very delicious. The price was reasonable as well. This place was a great find! We would definitely dine here again the next time we are in the bay area.
author: K R.

description:
Highest accolades. The cafe is tiny, which makes the setting great for a date. The food is also delicious. When I went, my date and I split the bruschetta and I ended up eating the penne with vodka cream sauce. The wine list was smaller, but they offered most of the wines by the glass (which is nice if you aren't in the mood for a bottle). Prices were really great, which kinda surprised me. 

I'll definitely be back sometime soon..
author: Jenn G.

description: Three meals over three days here while visiting SF.  Had lunch and two dinners.  Food and service was great.  A real feel of a local SF neighborhood resturant.  Super fresh ingridients and everything prepared quickly and just as described by our waiters.  Plan to wait if you get here after 7pm on the weekends up to an hour to get in.
author: Mike P.

description: One of my favorite places in the city. Not only is it walking distance from my apartment, the service, food and ambiance is spot on- It is well worth the wait!
author: Sara V.

description:
Well, Yelp let me down this time.  It's a rare occurrence, so I'll let it slip!  I read all these reviews and was really hoping for a solid, no-nonsense, good Italian meal, simple but homey and real.  Sadly, all four things we ordered were mediocre at best- I've had better at Pasta Pommodoro, and that place is nothing to write home about.  The lasagna tastes frozen, the sauce canned.  The same sauce was on the gnocchi, to my disappointment.  The pizza was thick and gummy.  The calamari was soggy and overly breaded, with a pungent lemon sauce.  The wine was ok, and a good value for the price.  We didn't try dessert.

The server and hosts, on the other hand, were fabulous... they win all two of these stars.  They were warm, welcoming, and handled a crowd beautifully.  Unfortunately, I'll never see them again.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Yum!! Pizza or pasta, or ? GET THE PIZZA!! This is authentic thin & crispy pizza with great sauce and cheese. The pepperoni is fantastic (and small)! I will be back!
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Always amazing when I visit....nob hill  cafe is the most charming little restaurant.
The food is consistantly fantastic, the owner is lovely and the staff rocks!
Feels like a little escape to somewhere in Italy.......just walk past it, and the aromas coming out of there will lead you inside....but make sure to arrive early for dinner, as they dont take reservations and you have to wait because it seems like everyone in the neighborhood wants to eat there....also very reasonably priced for nob hill.
author: Sarah A.

description: Heard about this gem from the bellman at the Mark Hopkins. Didn't expect to be blown away but we were. Yes, it's a small place but well worth the short wait ... go a little later and you won't wait long. The Gnocchi Bolognese will have you wanting more, the Linguine with clams is creamy and rich, the rosemary bread is a real treat. And the gelato spumoni was a great finish. 27 years old, this place is a must for great Italian food made just for you. Highly recommended.
author: Justo N.

description:
So i started to give this place another shot for take out only as i live so close.  last week it was hot real hot.  i ordered a pizza to go as i have been consistently for some time now and decided to eat outside on their tables.  it was abotu 6:30pm, still over 80 degrees in the city and i was on my way to the ball game.  

"um its not really protocall to be eating on our tables"  that is what one of the glorious serves tells me as i've just paid 16 dollars for an individual sized pizza.  this is after i infomred the chef to equip me with the knife and fork + napkins to eat OUTSIDE.  

are you kidding me? the place was not busy at all and to basically kick a customer out it unheard of.    so you don't serve food out huh?  what do i find the next day its nice? all the tables filled with customers eating outside.  

this place has lost my business for its lack of service and jsut plain rudness to customers.  i could not beleive they think that is how you retain local business.  

i've alredy informed everyone that i know in the area to boycott this place.  

advice to the owner: Fire the dark haired girl who thinks she owns the place anc lacks any kind of customer service to speak of.  



POSTED LAST YEAR:
What are you people thinking!!  this place is a nightmare and lacks any kind of resemblance to a GOOD restaurant.  the service says it all.    when great by a server with "well, what do ya want?"  you really can't expect much out of an establishment.  

Fix the attitude of the service staff, give the place a makeover and maybe you'll get my business.  Oh, and i live within a block and would be here all the time if they had it together.   on occasion i will order take-out.  the hostess is forced to be nice so you grease her plam with a few bucks for taking your order..  

this place makes me sick..
author: Ryan M.

description:
great food, great atmosphere. 
but you may have to wait awhile for a table so get there early. 
wear a warm jacket... you may be waiting outside...
wine list is decent. 
great authentic Italian appetizers and delicious pasta.
author: Susan L.

description:
Ok this little cafe got me walking in with that za za zu feeling.  Very cute and simple.  As you enter, you can see the kitchen staff hustling and bustling away preparing people's meals.  The space is small and cozy with an authentic Italian setting which actually gets you in the mentality that you are temporarily out of SF.  

Some of the dishes we ordered were the crostini di polenta, melanzane, and the margherita pizza.  They also served warm, fresh and delicious bread throughout our dinner.  I loved all the food and could taste the freshness and incredible seasoning.  The wine was great too, had a glass of the cab/syrah and was incredibly satisfied with it.  

Service was friendly and efficient and the restaurant is located in a great spot.  If you want a little escape to Italy, I enthusiastically say try this place!
author: Swetha G.

description:
Compared to a lot of the other brunch places around the city, this place is only so-so in my book.  

I admit that on a sunny Sunday afternoon, it's quite charming and quaint, especially if you're sitting outside basking in the rare sun.  We sat inside because everybody else was outside basking in the sun at their tables, but the dining area wasn't bad.  Some tables near the window had a curtain, making the seating a little more private.  

Anyway!  Other than the quaint dining area, the great things about this place are...um...that was pretty much it.

I ordered an Lime Chicken omelet with cheese and chunks of avocado on the top.  It sounded delicious, but it ended up being - flavorless.  The omelet was also a little too crispy on side, and I couldn't taste any thing "lime-y" about the lime chicken. The potatoes that came were okay, not too crispy but not soggy.  

If you had this on your list of brunch places to hop to, better cross it off and move to somewhere else.
author: Shay F.

description: I have to qualify this by saying I never go out to eat Italian food. Nonethless, I have been meaning to try this place for years. Finally five years after that thought I got around to it. What have I been waiting for?  I grew up with Italian food as my dad is Italian. Hence my fear of  Italian restaurants. Ok.. This place is getting all five of my stars because they are fantastic. Try the gnocchi with the bolognese. Come early or wait forever. Oh and be warned you will be surrounded by tourists.
author: Penelope S.

description:
A quintessential San Francisco neighborhood restaurant located atop Nob Hill. I visited this gem with my neighbor/friend/co-worker. Laura M.

Laura absolutely raves about this place, so I was very excited to dine here.  According to Laura, the SF twins (you know the twin older ladies who dress alike like they are five)  are Nob Hill Cafe regulars. 

Low and behold, we were seated right next to the twins. True to form, there they were, dressed alike in their senior glory.  Matching red suits and black hats. Makes me wonder, what they do they do all day?  Are they the inspiration for the phrase "all dressed-up and no where to go" ?  Do they roam the streets of SF looking for a place befitting of their attire?

Anyway, I digress...

I had the polenta and the pesto tortellini and a glass of wine. Both carb ladden dishes provided the comfort that I need after a long work week. The pasta was amazingly fresh and tasty.  The service was great.

The place is on the small side, so be prepared to wait a bit for table. If you are looking for a quaint, comfortable neighborhood joint, this is the place.
author: Gray S.

description:
We went to Nob Hill Cafe a couple weeks ago before going to the Steeley Dan concert.  It was so wonderful.  I have to say I was a little leary when I saw that there was no room inside to wait and all the tables where cramped together.  I was skeptical.

Then, the food came, it was awesome!  Even though the waitress made a mistake on my order (gave me eggplant on my pizza when I asked for artichoke), she was very apologetic and brought me another meal pronto.  

It was well worth the wait.  I would suggest that you get there only, as we were there at 5:30 and only had to wait about 10 minutes in the cold.  Definately worth it!!!
author: Carey V.

description: A nice place that though cozy, had a nice intimate feel. The service and food was good. It'[s located in a very nice neighborhood where the architecture stands out. The prices are also reasonable. I'm looking forward to my next visit.
author: Darryl L.

description:
I went to NHC for dinner last Sunday, and it made me really miss living in Nob Hill.  I used to get take out regularly, and it was always delicious.

Now I am nostalgic about Nob Hill-so many great things about it.

Great place for a date.

Also, I went in workout clothes, which was a lot more casual than I usually dress, but I didn't feel out of place or anything.  I see a lot of solo-diners here with a book-it's a very relaxing place.

My favorites are the insalata mista, the fedellini, and the linguine vongole (clams) it was amazing!
author: Rachel F.

description:
I've lived in Nob Hill for almost 6 yrs yet never tried this restaurant.  So, last Sunday a fellow neighbor and I decided to stop by for dinner.  First of all, we had to wait 45 minutes in the freezing cold while I watched 2 differest parties (who came at least 20 minutes after I put my name of the wait list) be seated ahead of us.  BTW, I've been told that your are not allowed to wait at the bar.  You have to freeze outside with your glass of wine.  

They finally sat us at a table after we complained.  The service was good once we got inside, so I'm giving them a star.  Also, my friends spaghetti carbonara was great.  Inspired me to make it tonight for dinner.  Unfortunately, I had the gnocchi which was so overcooked that it was practically mush.
author: Angelique B.

description: I have only been here twice for brunch even though I live nearby. The food was good but I can't say it's my favorite place. The server (who was the same guy who served us during our first visit) was polite enough but I felt he had his nose in the air when he waited on us both times. He was not like that at other tables so I wonder why-- maybe he just didn't like us????
author: Paula U.

description:
At first I wasn't too pleased with the wait, approaching a small room packed to the brim, isn't usually an exciting prospect for me. The location was certainly private and away from the touristy areas which was a plus. One got a sense of being "part of the neighborhood" which was charming. 

Overall: the Bruschetta was delicious, the nice Irish waitress was sweet, and the food was great. I did have an issue with the omitted details of the fish I ordered. I didn't know what it was coming with; that a cheese layer would be on top of the fish, and that capers would be generously used. Lastly it seemed to be mostly frequented by 35-78s, so a perfect place for an older crowd and somewhat noticeable if you're younger.
author: Val E.

description:
One word, GNOCCHI. I walk by this charming place every day on the way to and from work and I finally stopped in for dinner. It has a menu that is comfortable to work with and an ambiance that is warm and inviting. I have always wondered why I didn't like gnocchi more and it was because it has never tasted quite like this. I always hear people on the food network describe gnocchi as pillowy-puffs of heaven but until a few nights ago they had been sort of chewy stick to my teeth puffs. 

My co-worker ordered the mushroom pizza and we split both dishes and even had leftovers. The food is definitely good and I agree that it is a great place for a date. Beware of the long wait even at 6 on a Tuesday night, luckily I live right up the hill from it. A cozy treat!
author: Sugey G.

description:
I first went here because I had heard and read great things about it, it is always packed, and it isn't even a block away from my place. Seemed to good to be true! Well, it was. I went here with my bf Pete and while our appetizers where fine, our entrees were less than great. He had a  simple pasta dish which was good, and I ordered one of the specials...and that was the beginning of the end.

The special was grilled chicken breast and sauteed summer vegetables tossed with linguine, garlic, and olive oil. The price of this was $15. Now while I  though this price was a little high for the dish, I was still ok with it upon ordering. Then the food came. My chicken looked like that pre-cooked Purdue chicken slices you buy at the grocery store, and didn't taste much better. Also, it was extremely bland, and once our entrees were given to us, we never saw our waiter again. He even tripped (and I mean literally tripped) over my bf's chair, and still didn't ask us how we were doing, if we needed anything...nothing!  

I am not sure why this place is always so busy, and as I walk by I often think "Maybe we went on an off night" but I agree with Brody M. that I need to listen to myself and take my money elsewhere.
author: Sasha C.

description:
We were in San Francisco for a week,and ended up at Nob Hill Cafe 3 nights.Yes,you have to wait for a table,but luckily the weather was good so we didn't mind.The garlic fragrance coming out of the doors was enough to make me stay!
I tries the pasta special the first night,the chicken parm (totally unlike others -better!),and then the gnocci on night 3.All were delicious,but the gnocci was my favorite.
My partner had the veal picatta all 3 nights-when he finds something he likes,he sticks with it!
The walk up Taylor from Union Square will increase anyone's appetite,especially the hill on the last block.
Prices were reasonable,service was friendly,food delicious-a real treasure!
Bon appetit!!
author: Michael M.

description: i'm sorry to my wife for this one.  I know you love this place babe, but it just didn't make the grade.  for as crowded as it was, i don't feel as though it delivered.  prosciuto and melon app was not very good... melon not too ripe.  linguine with clams, very tasty.  gniocchi with bolongese decent but not a revelation.  the service left me not wanting to return, even though the food was pretty good.
author: ari b.

description:
I live 2 blocks from this place and I love going all the time. Every dish is so simple and delicious, esp the Linguini w/ clams and of course their signature -  the Gnocchi! Wine selections are not as great but their bread is worth the sit down. It's a soft and warm focaccia that pretty much make the chilly Nob Hill fall nights all nice and warm.

The atmosphere is definitely casual, but their year round Christmas lights really make it a nice date spot. It's a small place but doesn't get really loud.. everyone's just there to have some good food and fair prices and just people watch and have a good time. Excellent choice for a first date since it's not too expensive, the food is good, the mood is right and the service is fast, so you can jet out if its not going so well! :)
author: Peter K.

description: This place is amazing! Tiny little place but has a romantic charm to it. Very limited outside seating and there usually will be a wait but it is worth it. The food was delicious they have a great zucchinni risotto and chicken parm. Service was fabulous even with them being very busy.
author: Adrienne P.

description: Awesome small neighborhood restaurant with a very old school hometown feel . The. Foood is awesome and the prices are very fair ! Love this place will always come back !! And that's from an Italian guy from NY/NJ !
author: Austin T.

description: Ate here for dinner on vacation....definitely one of my favorite places we went to, the pasta was really yummy and the place wasn't too expensive. Just what we were looking for!
author: Theresa H.

description:
Went last Saturday night around 9 p.m. with a party of three and waited about 20 minutes (you gotta wait outside because it's so tiny inside there's no room to stand...but my friends insisted on crowding inside anyway cuz it was cold).  The open kitchen is a nice touch, and our waitress was really nice and attentive.  I got a pizza (the quattro formaggio with eggplant special) and my friend got the creamy pesto tortellini.  (The bf had already had dinner, so he just got wine.)  Both were AWESOME.  Loved the pizza crust--good flavor and consistency, and not too thick nor thin.  I ended up eating a good portion of my friend's pasta too because it was so delicious.  And there were a dozen other things on the menu I wanted to order.

We got the kafeluha gelato for dessert, and it came like a slice of pie with CHEESECAKE for the "crust."  Drizzled with chocolate deliciousness.  It was so good we ordered another "slice" of strawberry gelato.

Even though it's in (and called) Nob Hill, there were some folks on the funky side there--I didn't feel bad showing up in jeans.

Even though there's no parking and I live across the city--the bf and I definitely decided to come back sometime.
author: Gina K.

description: Great place off the beaten path for a late night espresso or cappuccino on one of the outdoor tables.
author: Lucas K.

description:
Have eaten here numerous times and found it enjoyable until snippy new hostess lectured me.  Restaurant was almost empty early in the evening when I was seated at a two top.  My spouse was 5 minutes behind me.  Hostess said she would be "fired" if her manager found out that a second person would join me at my table for two.
As a restauranteur, I understand the policy of seating only complete parties, but this girl was on a power trip.  The only other table in the room commented on her rudeness.
Nice place, nice food, previous hostess very nice and personable, but this one needs to work on her "people skills".
author: kathy g.

description:
I used to love this place and frequented the Cafe at least twice a week; every Sunday after church at Grace and then typically on Friday nights.  I have lived on Taylor / Clay streets since 2008 and have referred this restaurant to not only dozens of tourists, but also friends and acquaintances from out of town.

I moved above the cafe about 2 years ago and had no complaints until last Fall.  I don't know whether it was a change in management or what, but they began playing music loudly throughout the week nights - sometimes until 2am.  I asked nicely if they would please turn the volume down a touch after 10pm.  I was met with resistance, the owner denying that it was them, despite their speakers being mounted on their ceiling, which is my bedroom floor.  This issue became so bad that I was unable to sleep some nights and was awakened by the cleaning crew at odd hours, including 4-6am on a Tuesday.  

The building owners repeatedly spoke to the Cafe owner, whose name I'm debating mentioning, and she kept claiming that it wasn't the cafe breaking the noise ordinance.  

Here I am, 22 months later, same situation, no change.  The last 2 times I called to beg them to just turn down the volume so I can sleep, I was met with attitude by the hostess, who argued with me and had the gaul to tell me they are allowed to play the music as loud as they want until the last customer leaves.  

I've lived above other places of business in SF before now, and have never been met with such disrespect and attitude.  I also know the ordinance law is 10:00pm in SF.
author: Hannah A.

description:
I can't understand why this place is rated so highly!  My husband and I came here while apartment hunting on a Sunday afternoon.  We split a pizza and the prosciutto and melon appetizer.  The prosciutto was fabulous, but the melon was so unripe that is was almost too hard to eat!  The pizza was totally mediocre- think something you get at Sbarro.
     To be fair, we totally made the wrong choices. Everyone around us was ordering off the brunch menu, and their food looked one hundred times better than ours.  So, I am stilling willing to give this place another chance, given how yummy the brunch looked.
author: Jessica S.

description:
we've eaten here so many times and taken many friends. the staff is wonderful, and the atmosphere is great. i often felt as though we had the restaurant to ourselves with our own personal chef.

get the gnocchi with pesto sauce. you will thank me
author: Kelsey O.

description: Once upon a time I spent a long evening with a friend who RAVED about Nob Hill Cafe, which was nestled somewhere within two blocks between her current apartment and my future apartment. I don't know how I ended up waiting for fifteen minutes to be seated (I absolutely hate waiting for anything) but I did it outside in the cold. The restaurant in itself is very charming and warm and reminds me of the holidays (I think I went there sometime in July). It's too bad the bread was cold. The risotto was bland. BUT, my fried polenta was off the hook! I had a dessert but I can't remember what it was for the life of me. Some kind of custard maybe? Eh. Shrug. I guess this is what happens when I take advice from a friend who severely overcooks her chicken.
author: Natasha P.

description: This is a very cozy little place.  I'm rating it more for the ambiance.  Get here early around 6:30pm/7pm and you won't have to wait, otherwise the wait could be long (this place is small and they don't take reservations).  There are two rooms and we sat in the back room which is away from the kitchen and so much nicer.  Try and get the seat at the window, it's super cozy and away from all the other tables.  I came here with a friend and we both got pasta.  I ordered linguini vangole (one with clams, mussels) and my friend ordered the gnochi.  My dinner was great, but I expected the clam and mussel chunks to be bigger.  It almost seemed like it was ground clam/mussels (could have been from a can?).  It tasted good, but was mostly pasta and had the clam/mussel flavor.  They have small wine selection but there is a good range of price options.  The first course options seemed to be your basics like bruschetta, calamari, salad, etc.  We were too stuffed to order dessert.  I would definitelt come back here again and try the pizza or one of the second course options.
author: Tanichka B.

description: PESTO TORTELLINI WITH PINE NUTS. does not get any better, so creamy and so delixious. Polenta is outstanding with the Marinara sauce and cheese to top. By far one of my favorite places to eat in San Francisco, Simply the best, the staff is wonderful Even writing this review is making me want it for dinner! LOVE NOB HILL CAFE!
author: Felicia E.

description:
The dining experience here started out as a solid four stars. I loved the wait staff and the cute atmosphere. Our bread and drinks arrived promptly and I was excited to start our meal. 

We ordered the polenta appetizer, gnocchi and spaghetti carbonara and the food bumped down this restaurant's rating to three stars. Everything left more to be desired. Heavy and bland would be the best way to describe the fare. Was it edible? Sure. Did I enjoy it? Eh. 

When I woke up with a really upset stomach at 3am, the rating plummeted to two.
author: A K.

description: This is my favorite neighborhood restuarant in that area.  It gets you away from the toxic tourist pit near union square - to a lush italian cuisine.  You can watch the cook do his magic, its fresh and affordable.
author: Manny F.

description: Old faithful! I try new places all the time, but still crave this home-style restaurant. YUM!
author: Honest Y.

description: Fabulous! Came here with my husband based on a tip from a local and we were blown away. Definitely will come again :)
author: Nydia B.

description:
We have walked by this cute little place so many times and it is always busy. Come to find out some of he local concierges may be sending customers here because it is so close to five very large hotels. 
We arrived and had to wait,  no place to have a drink or sit and relax. Finally they gave us a table and we waited and waited and waited for what was abrupt and hurried service. I have been a chef for over twenty years and own three restaurants and I understand things can get busy however rudeness and poor service is not acceptable. The food was far from being decent. It was bland and portions were small. The wine list is short and overpriced with mediocre choices. 
The next day we went back in the morning to ask if we could buy some take out containers as we were cooking up some Christmas meals to feed the homeless. The cooks laughed at us and would not help us out. I offered them twenty dollars for twenty disposable containers and they said no and laughed again. 
If you want a decent Italian meal at hald the price go to Uncle Vitos or walk a block further and go to Venticello's for more upscale and far better food and service.
author: Alfonso C.

description:
You really can't go wrong with anything from this place. The food is amazing. Simple dishes with a lot of flavor. The bread is great. Wine selection is pretty decent but I have seen better. I have always had good service whenever I go in. Prices are really reasonable too!

The venue is really small so depending on what time you go, you can wait for a while, and they have you wait outside (bring a coat). At times, I have sat down and felt like I was right on top of the table next to me, but you make due. They do have an option for take out if you don't want to wait.

If you are looking for a good place to go on a casual date, I would definitely recommend this place. Get the chocolate mousse for desert, its to die for!
author: Diana R.

description:
Visited for brunch one afternoon on the recommendation of the concierge at the Fairmont.  

Though the place has a very obvious Italian-decor feel, the name certainly does not indicate that Italian fare can be found within, and our waitress had a very strong Irish accent.  

We ordered:

Tequila lime chicken omelet: This definitely tasted like tequila lime, but was oily and drippy.  It came with a corn cake muffin and potatoes, both of which were dry as though they've been sitting under the heat lamp awhile.

Breakfast pizza with chicken sausage and scrambeled eggs: The crust was dry, but crunchy.  The sausage and eggs were a nice addition.  This is a large portion, and I ended up eating about 1/3 and giving the rest to a homeless gentleman outside.  For the $12 or so this cost, the size of this pizza made this a very good value.

The interior is Italian-cafe like, with mismatched decorations and small cafe tables.  While the food we tried was just mediocre, the prices are definitely nice for the portion sizes.  However, I do realize that we only had brunch here, and therefore may not have sampled Nob Hill Cafe at its finest meal.  The gnocchi and risottos are raved about, and were I to return for dinner, I would likely sample one of those.
author: Heather G.

description: just wanted to add a hint for others that you need to go early and this place fills up fast.  i was the first of 4 to arrive about 5:45 on a tuesday and they wouldn't seat us till all were there which was understandable.  they did fill up about 3 minutes later and the hostess was very helpful and honest to say the wait was 30 minutes (too long for us) and offered a sister restaurant down the street (Ala Romano) that does take reservations and would seat me and it was wonderful!  hope to try nob hill cafe some other time but will get there by 5: 30 latest.
author: Pm H.

description: A 35 minute wait, but was worth it for the excellent tiramisu. The penne bettola pasta was average, bruschetta was up to the mark. They do serve bread at the start.
author: Soujanya K.

description: Such a charming yet casual atmosphere and it smells so amazing in there!  They have the best rosemary focaccia bread I've ever had!  I've been there twice now - the first time I had a mushroom ravioli with gorgonzola that was to die for!  Last night we took a friend who had just arrived in San Francisco for the first time and was staying at the Mark Hopkins, so it was really convenient.  They were busy, but we only had to wait for about 15 minutes.  I had the gnocchi and it was so fresh!  My boyfriend had the carbonara and it was so good, I think I'll have it next time.  I love the Nob Hill Cafe!  It's really one of my favorite restaurants in the city!
author: R. B.

description:
Accidentally came here on a date (we were supposed to go to Nob Hill Grille but there was text message confusion) - however I had always been curious about it and was excited to try it out. From the outside it looks very warm and inviting, and while the atmosphere is cozy, it isn't much more than your run of the mill Italian restaurant. My date said the Caesar salad was sub par (apparently that's his thing)...and I only felt mediocre about the Tirimisu (dessert being my thing). I just have something against any place that doesn't serve wine in real wine glasses.

I'm sure neighborhood locals love it as it seems dependable - but I wouldn't plan an event (anniversary, birthday dinner, etc) around it. The server was attentive....and the company was good so overall it was a pleasant dining experience. 

Ooo...they also don't seat you until your entire party arrives. But they will give you wine while you wait!
author: Rachael W.

description: The gnocchi melts in your mouth! The ambiance is really cute. The restaurant is on the intimate side, so there may be a wait.
author: Grace L.

description: Well worth the wait.  This is a small place and the line was pretty long, but just order a bottle of wine and drink it outside while you wait.  The food was delicious and very reasonably priced.  No complaints about the service
author: Kim S.

description: Neighborhood gem. The wait is horrible but my new discovery is to order it to go and walk down the block to pick it up. Win win.
author: L. L.

description:
Talk about great authentic food here.  I mean its just so damn good and its right in the heart of the neighborhood!  The wait is short and the decor is light and simple.  I've had lunch here many a times and just enjoyed the ambiance.  

A bonus is the park near by so that you can go for a walk and enjoy the day after a great meal.

You'll be missing out if  you don't have the time for this place!
author: Harry H.

description:
Stopped by with a friend on Wed night and got a romantic table for two by the window.  The waiter immediately brought over a basket of doughy herb bread, sourdough, and pats of butter.  The herb bread was really good and I ended up asking for more.

The two of us decided to split the mixed green salad, pizza margherita, & lasagna.  Honestly, I thought the food here was pretty average.  The brick oven pizza had a nice chewy crust but was covered with too much salty cheese and oil.  I would have preferred for them to use fresh mozzarella rounds instead of the shredded mozzarella as well.  The lasagna was pretty good but again, super oily.

We ordered the caramel flan & tiramisu for dessert.  Both dishes were quite large and we were unable to finish either of them.  Of the two, the tiramisu was slightly better as the flan was on the chewy side.

Service was very good and the place is quite inexpensive too (about $70 for the two of us).  I would probably come here again, but I don't agree with the 5-star reviews.
author: Sonia C.

description:
My Nob Hill Cafe Sunday Brunch experience would have been almost glorious had it not been for our host who showed the full repertoire of his hospitality - ranging from snide and curt through to downright rude.

Donny S. (who vowed to post a more detailed analysis of our host's behavior) and I rocked up to one of the half-doors on Sunday at 10:45. As I'd eaten lunch in the Cafe the day before, neither of us knew that the establishment opened at 11. Rather than politely inform us of the opening time, Mr. Grumpy stared as Mr. S. struggled with the locked half-door (the top half was open and afforded full view into a very much prepared cafe) before barking at us to come back at 11.

Come back we did, despite Mr. S.'s better reservations, and I was placated with a window seat. I began with a black coffee that I am certain was made from instant granules - or very, very bad beans. I perked up, however, with a perusal of the brunch menu - a fabulous egg selection along with some tasty sweet/side options and of course the regular menu.

I had the salmon scramble, which was bordering on superb. While I wasn't a fan of either the potatoes or the (home-made) corn-muffin that came with my eggs, there was more than enough eggs and salmon to satisfy me (seriously, the portions are enormous).

Bottom line: nice decoration (although a little dark for a brunch), window seats are lovely, food is wonderful, coffee sucks. Put a less abrasive host on your line-up, and folks you almost have a winner.
author: Amanda F.

description:
Cosy Italian comfort food. Shatangi take out of town guests here when Contadina is fully booked. Last time we saw the SF Twins there

Shatangi told you
author: Njon W.

description:
I've eaten here many a times because it's convenient and priced reasonably when you are in the Nob Hill area.  Have had many lunches and a dinner here and there.  The food is average--all their pastas (non red sauce) have this similar glaze in the sauce them that you find in large chain restaurants like Olive Garden.  I don't know what it is. The one thing that I do like is the carpaccio.
The wait people vary in terms of service and attitude.  Wines are very average.  But for a neighborhood join in a pinch, it will do.  I would say it is NOT worth the wait, but go in if you don't have to wait.
author: Nancy H.

description:
NHC is a nice, cozy, neighborhoody kind of a place.  It's right there in the hood, so it's easy to just drop in -- however, I wouldn't go out of my way to go there.

Nothing grievously wrong, just not great.  Lighting could be a bit more subdued, the whole place could use a bit of a re-do.  

Bruschetta was tasty, but needed salt and less garlic.  The gnocchi with meat sauce and the fettuccine with creamy pesto were great.

Again, this is a great neighborhood haunt -- to bring the point home, the Nob Hill Twins were dining there and posing for pics for whomever wanted them.  Those gals know how to turn it on!
author: Karen C.

description:
This is right across the street, so I can't complain about location.  The other reviews all have merit.  The wait can be crazy, the food is good/not great, etc etc.
I like the place.  It is cozy and it is the only semi-reasonable place on the hill to eat. 
Their pizzas are soooo close to being good, but too much cheese!
Every time I'm there, I ask "please, light on the cheese" and every time they're covered with lots of stringy, gooey mozzerella.  I like cheese.  I really do.  But the balance is just off.  Their crust (a little too thick) is tasty, and their sauce is just right.  
I think they should offer a 9 dollar, light pizza, instead of  14 dollars for a too-heavy-for-one-stomach feast.
author: Alexander T.

description:
Did someone say pasta?  

Raised as an Italian, I must say that I am quite the critic on eating Italian food.  My mother has mastered the Italian cooking and I was lucky enough to eat pasta as often as my heart desired growing up.  If you asked most of my friends they would probably agree that in any given year of my life, I have eaten more pasta dishes than any normal person does in a lifetime.

So I am confident in giving this cozy, romantic, notoriously San Franciscan spot five stars.  There is a reason that they don't take reservations, because it is simply worth the wait.  And who doesn't mind waiting when they serve you a bottle of wine while you wait at an outside table on a nice summer night?  

The food is exceptionally authentic Italian cuisine.  The wine selection is delightfully simple.  The service is personable, prompt, and friendly.  I have always been pleased with my dinner experiences and the prices are almost too cheap (although that is not possible in SF).  This is a five star restaurant with two star prices.  

Unbelievable?  I know.  

I was almost nervous to review my favorite dinner spot in the city.  But I had to review the Nob Hill Cafe because it deserves to be raved about because it is one of a kind.  And as I said, I know my Italian, and so do they!
author: Michelle N.

description: I moved to Los Angeles two years ago and have dreamed wistfully about Nob Hill Cafe ever since. It is some of the most delicious, flavorful Italian food i've ever had (other than in Italy, let's not get crazy). I always order the penne bettola, or the capellini with tomatoes, but everything on the menu is great. Other standouts include the gnocchi and actually, the pizza.The portion size is quite large, so you can have leftovers the next day, the service is great, the restaurant is small and charming, and if you're lucky you'll spot those ancient San Francisco twin sisters, who are definitely a sight to see. I definitely stared at them throughout my entire meal and took about 10 blurry blackberry pictures, but to be fair, even an annoying, gawking patron could not ruin Nob Hill Cafe.
author: Claire S.

description:
This place is a nice little cozy stop for those of us in the neighborhood - the food is simple Italian and reasonably priced (as I think was mentioned by another Reviewer).  Some nice wines by the glass.  Not a very logn wait at all.  

They don't open til 11am for Brunch, so if you like to grab breakfast early on a sunny weekend morning, so that you can do something else with your day, then you're a little out of luck.  That said, if Brunch is your only goal for the day, then this is pretty good, as the sidewalk scene is peaceful and the park is nearby so you can continue laying in the sun as you digest your frittata.
author: Robyn C.

description:
My boyfriend and I were looking for a new restaurant, and I was craving Italian food. Thanks to fellow yelper Anna G., along with the reviews promising a romantic date spot, we decided on Nob Hill Cafe. What a great choice!!!

We arrived around 8pm, and after finding a really scary parking spot on a sharp decline, we walked into the sweet cafe. It is actually two large conjoined small rooms, with about 10-15 tables total. Although we anticipated a wait, we were seated promptly.

We shared the garlic bread antipasti ($4), which was three thin slices of bread topped with a mild pesto, garlic, and grated cheese. For the main dish, I ordered the Tortellini Romana with the romana cream sauce ($11.50) and my boyfriend chose the Gnocchi Bologonese ($13.75). Both dishes were fantastic, my Tortellini was well prepared with rich, creamy sauce. My boyfriend's was just as good, the savory potato dumplings perfectly complementing the meat sauce.
