The atmosphere presented by Nob Hill Cafe was just as refreshing as the food. Filled with couples, families, and friends of the owner- the cafe has a vibe of friendship and community. The wait staff was kind and diligent.

In all, we were extremely pleased with quality, atmosphere, and price. I can't wait to return to Nob Hill in order to try all the rest of the menu items! :)
author: Erin M.

description:
I love this little restaurant! The setting is extremely charming, and you get the feeling of eating in someone's house. While you will most likely have to wait to get seated, kick back outside with a glass of prosecco while you wait.

The bruschetta is some of the best I've ever had, and I love the lasagna. Don't fill yourself up with the bread basket because the portions are generous! 

I'm excited to try brunch sometime because there are always happy people soaking up the sunshine on the weekends.
author: lindsay w.

description:
Favorite neighborhood place on a cold night! I love the closeness of it all. I especially the lady server. SHe's beautiful and has a couple of daughters my age I think. 

The food isn't the best thing about the place but I always leave feeling buzzed and content. Great for people watching and a nice, but casual, dinner out withg the boyfriend.
author: Annette M.

description:
Cute Place. Good Breakfast and Dinner. It's always busy since all the hotels near by tell visitors to go here. Go early!!!

Nice staff.. 

The people eating here can be somewhat snoody... it is in snob hill.
author: Colleen M.

description: Incredibly rude waitress. Meal started off with water that had soap in it. The food was average, but too long of a wait for such mediocre food. Overall, bad service and very rude staff.
author: Taylor A.

description:
I love the location. Very cute part of Taylor Street. Probably even too cute for those who need a little bit of edge. The food though, is only alright. It never tastes bad, but I don't find it much better than what I can prepare myself without too much trying. And I ain't no professional chef.

However, if you're looking for some affordable Italian without any sort of surprises, this might be for you.
author: Janne K.

description: My wife and I have been here several times since moving to the neighborhood. They are consistently good and we have had amazing service each time. I don't usually give a 30% tip but I felt compelled after eating here one night. There are two very different and distinct rooms to be seated in, and we prefer the darker, more romantic side. The ambiance is much nicer than the side with the kitchen and you aren't bugged with the cool breeze every time the door opens. We have tried several pastas, pizzas, and salads, and our favorites have been the beet salad, calamari salad, and fettuccine with pesto. The flavors are great and mostly authenic- I think it is one of the better deals in the area, with all entrees between $10-20. Worth the wait (you will likely wait for a table), so order a glass of wine and sit outside before being seated!
author: Ben S.

description: Darling restaurant, very romantic. No reservations taken so we had to put our name on the list and wait in the cold SF evening. Then we lucked out and got to sit in the window alcove - perfect for ppl watching and intimate conversation. The food was fabulous and plentiful - we both had leftovers!
author: L L.

description:
This place is both cute and convenient. My boyfriend and I go here about once a week for either a fun dinner or a glass of wine outside. The food was very well prepared and wait staff was attentive.

It does tend to get very crowded. We try to go as close to 5 as possible to avoid lines or crowds. I wouldn't recommend it if there is a large group of you or if you have a stroller. It's pretty tiny inside.
author: Aubrey W.

description:
You walk into this restaurant and immediately feel warmth and smell garlic. It's a wonderfully softly lit cozy place for a truly delicious dinner. Italian standbys, generous but not too huge proportions, decent pizza (I'm from NYC, it takes a lot for pizza to impress me, to be fair), and good specials, too - I had the halibut the last time I was here and loved it. 

I feel lucky to live a few blocks from Nob Hill Cafe. I recommend taking a walk through Huntington Park after your meal, but leave a swing open for me!

Oh yes, it's a perfect date restaurant.
author: Jacqui M.

description:
My husband and I have come here a few times.  The first time was thanks to a recommendation by the concierge at the Fairmont (which is down the street).  We love the small restaurant and love the window seating (when available).  

We went there today after a year of not going.  We started with bruschetta which was very nice - garlicky country bread and fresh tomatoes and basil.  One this is that I like my food a bit more on the salty side and needed to add salt.

For our main course, I had the pizzeta salsicia (their brunch pizza) which has fontina cheese, eggs, and chicken apple sausage.  It was very good.  My husband ordered our typical comfort food - spaghetti carbonara.  Its one of the best carbonaras I have had.  The pasta was al dente and the sauce was amazing.  We finished the meal with cappuccinos which were very good.  

Overall, a great place to go for a lunch in Nob Hill.
author: Ingrid P.

description:
Good italian food.  Decent wine selection.  Small venue, so any parties of 6 or more, good luck trying to get a table.  Even for a party of 2, be prepared to wait.

I had your basic capellini in tomato/basil sauce.  It was quite tasty.  The chianti we had complemented it very well.  My friend had the lasagna and he really liked it too.  This is a good place to go first, then head over to the Top of the Mark or the Tonga room for drinks.
author: Alison N.

description:
For years, this cozy little cafe has been just a couple blocks from my house. I have eaten here in the past and it was, well, just not good.

Every once in a while, as I see people piled outside, I say to myself - "self, why don't you eat here more often". After a lengthy [and usually fruitless discussion with self] I cave and vow to give it another try.

The moral here is that sometimes you should listen to yourself.

My latest lapse was yesterday. While the the brunch selections are a bit better than the pedestrian pasta and pizzas I have had in the past, it was still nothing to go out of your way for. The wine is pretty mediocre. Actually, the first glass I ordered was a Pinot Noir that had obviously been opened for a day or two and stored near the stoves or a heater. Awful. I requested a replacement and was cheerfully given one. Nice touch.

I will admit that it is very convenient if you live in the neighborhood but I cannot imagine anyone thinking this is the best Italian SF has to offer. Venticello is just down the street - far better food and fewer tourists, although it's only open for dinner [it could be owned by the same people but I am not sure].

Food 2
Decor 3
Service 3
other I give them a 4 for convenience
author: Allan H.

description:
On the one hand, it might be nice if this place were a bit bigger, then it wouldn't be so hard to get a table. On the other hand, if it were any bigger it wold probably lose all the charm and ambiance it has as a solid neighborhood Italian bistro. the food is fresh, the staff are super nice (to the point where the one time I ate there, I walked by on the way to the girlfriend's place -- stopped in, put our names in for a table and the hostess was cool with the fact that I wouldn't be around for most of the quoted 30 minute wait...went to the gf's place, we got to the restaurant within the quoted time and waited maybe 2 minutes before being seated). 

The meals were tasty and best of all, Marian and Vivian Brown, the "Nob HIll twins" were eating there that night. Perfect.

Worth the wait and the price.
author: dannebrog ..

description:
I went here on the advice of Chowhound reviews, but I can't recommend it to anyone.

My appetizer, an eggplant, tomato and feta salad, arrived not 60 seconds after I ordered it.  It was a little rushed for my taste.  The meaty slices of eggplant were flabby and damp where I was hoping for something thinner with a char or roasted texture.  The other ingredients were serviceable, but lost in a heavy handed pour of vinaigrette.  Presentation was nowhere to be found, much like the ambiance.

I wasn't halfway through my appetizer when the waiter brought over my lasagne.  He politely took it back when I commented it was too early, but should I really have to remind him?

The dish itself was humdrum at best.  Pleasantly cooked noodles were lost in a flood of sauce.  The ricotta was used too sparingly and the sausage wasn't spicy enough.

There have to be better options than this.
author: Alex C.

description: My dear friend lived a few doors down from this cafe and ate most of her meals here. I can not even think about a trip to SF without a stop at this cafe. I am so THRILLED to be heading there again this weekend for the Chicken Picatta and Gnocchi with a Carbonara sauce. The service is out of this world, the atmosphere charming, and the food is an exciting experience for your taste buds!
author: Dimple D.

description: Best minestrone ribolita soup. Penne with the vodka-garlic-marinara sauce. I'm happy. Annoying when there's a wait, but what can you do. Great anytime place, Sinatra blaring, love taking my lady there for a romantic casual bite. Service is always great, super friendly staff. Pizza is cool, chicken parmigiana is cheesy, chicken marsala special rocks, petrale sole is my favorite. Good casual Italian food, neighborhoody, love it.
author: Adam S.

description:
Okay...lets just get this out of the way...the wait to get in this place for parties larger than 2 is absolutely ridiculous....however:

Once you get inside...the wine list is reasonable, the staff is personable and the food is absolutely amazing.  Not only is the standard menu out of this world, but the specials are always great.  Sounds lame...but the Chicken Parm is world class...and anything you can get with the spicy tomato sauce is guaranteed to be a hit.
author: Ken S.

description:
Ok food.  Service was great - no gaps there.  

But, can someone explain to me what the hype is all about?  I get the basic arguments - this is a local neighborhood joint where you can get some good basic Italian food.  But, I had also heard along with all this hype that the place was something special.  I never encountered anything special.
author: Joel K.

description:
When My Girlfriend reads this she'll probably be pissed.  Anyway, this is a great place to take girls.  Its small, romantic, kinda fancy even.  It makes you look like you know the city's best kept secrets.  The food is great.  Just go with the specials and have some wine.  The price is pretty good too.  Its not gonna break the bank, but it wont leave you looking like a cheapo.
You can walk around the neighborhood while your waiting for your table.  Top of the Mark is right around the corner, there is also another park 2 blocks away.  You can't go wrong with this place.
author: Robert S.

description:
Third time is a charm for us.  Restaurant came highly recommended so we had high expectations.  First time we tried it I had the pizza (which didn't impress me for some reason).  Second time we came for brunch.  Omelettes were not good.  Too much eggs not enough ingredients.  We were ready to write this restaurant off until we were assured that the pasta from Nob Hill is worth it.  Third time I got it right and ordered the special pasta of the day - curry pasta.  Verdict...delish!  I'm looking forward to trying the other dishes.

Ambiance and service is great.  Wine list not bad.  Just come early so you don't have to wait too long for a table.  If it's a nice day you can order wine and drink in the front patio while waiting for your table.
author: Johannah P.

description:
Couples only.  The place is too tight for family dinners.  A romantic simple place, drink mostly the wine and eat a simple meal, walk hand in hand in the romantic neighborhood and neck on the steps of Grace Cathedral.
It's not a foodie joint.  It's a first date or second date kinda place.  If you have a group, go some where else, there are plenty of places in this town for groups.  This is the ideal couples resturant.  I mean IDEAL.  It will make you horny.  But not if you are in a group.  Did I say that already?
author: Sarah H.

description:
The owners are close personal friends (Hey Christina & Michael I miss you guys) so I would have to say I am more than a bit biased.

Very fresh, very simple, very cozy Italian bistro with that local neighborhood feel. With that they make you feel like family and you start to notice that almost everyone who eats here has been coming here for at least 15 years. Like Cafe Jacqueline, try and get the only table facing the window. Very romantic and always hard to get.

The Linguine a la Vongole (Linguine w/clams) is the best I have ever had. Beer and Wine only, but a very eclectic well thought out collection of Italian beer and wine.

The Deeb family also own the more upscale, very romantic Venticello just down the street, the newly acquired Enrico's Cafe in North Beach, and used to own the Sausalito neighborhood favorite Vicino. None of these should be missed.
author: Xavier P.

description:
Aaaah, the joys of first date bliss. Jeez, that was a year and a half ago!

Anyway, I came here on a first date, per my date's suggestion [after I suggested meeting in San Francisco, as it was in between both our locations]. Luckily, I left early, because it took me 25 minutes to drive around in circles to find parking before I settled on the Cathedral parking lot. And, hey! I made it there with 5 minutes to spare.

Said date was waiting graciously outside, sipping on a glass of red wine, which we shared. As the waitstaff had been warned I was due any moment, a table was ready the moment I arrived. We dove in, a bottle of wine, appetizers, and fairly sizeable portions - he the pesto [I think], and me the capellini pomodoro. Again, I think that is what I had. I remember eating red, and he commenting on how he had a nasty habit of spilling red food on his white shirts, which lead me to question his choice in alcohol... We then went on to share tiramisu [I only managed one bite].

After that first date, we kept attempting to go back, only venturing there once more together. But, it was just as yummy and just as tightly packed. One exceptionally wonderful thing I would love to point out is that he took some of his friends there once and ordered me dinner to go. A couple hours later, I was handed a box full of veggie lasagne. I ate half of it that night, and the rest the next day. Their leftover veggie lasagne is to die!!

My little issue I have is the location/parking. Yes, it is San Francisco, and parking is a b*tch. But, if you are driving there, don't. Get BART to Powell, and walk. Who doesn't love a great workout to feel justified in eating yummy food? Or you can just park your car in the cathedral lot [which closes at 11, maybe 12 on weeknights, which lead to some crazy split-second, blood boiling planning on first date night, as we opted to take a drive over the golden gate in his car after dinner].

Another thing: the bathroom. It's a joke. It's cramped. Too close to the dining area/bar. The "door" isn't really a door, just an accordion-style pull thing that latches. Yes, they are pressed for space, but why not build a bathroom out back? At least it's away from the dining area.
author: Ellie M.

description:
We came in at the last dinner service around 10pm and the place was still buzzing.  Great neighborhood haunt, excellent food and wine selection
The seafood risotto special was excellent!  It was a huge order, maybe good for two. Romantic and a charming walk around the neighborhood after dinner.
author: Hang the DJ S.

description: Great gnocchi! Normally restaurants under cook gnocchi but this place had it just right. Pasta sauce was equally as good. Highly recommended.
author: Keith K.

description: Cute little Italian cafe with the BEST service ever! The staff is personable and always willing to give you an honest opinion and suggestions about the menu. Very well priced, delicious, rich food, and excellent Rosemary soda bread. Fast service, but not rushed, even the bussers are sweet and helpful. You can't eat outside after 5pm because the neighbors don't approve, but sitting for a glass of wine outside while waiting for your table is very relaxing. A+ for this little "hole-in-the-wall" cafe!
author: Megan A.

description:
A great romantic date place! Super cute little Italian place-
The pizza options were great you could pick your own toppings etc. 
Next time I go I am trying the pasta! 
Also if you happen to be sitting outside at a certain time you get the joy of seeing the 'Vampire' tour walk by- so ridiculous!
author: Janae L.

description: After being in relationship for a while with my city, I've racked up quite the number of brunch places I've eaten at. Nob hill cafe has such unique delicious omelets that I've never even heard of. The best are the tequilla lime chicken  and the Louisiana omelet and don't even get me started on the breakfast potatoes. The only downside is that their mimosas are overpriced, small, and weak. I like my mimosas mostly champagne and a splash of oj. I definitely want to come for dinner sometime.
author: Jamie E.

description: I really like Nob Hill Cafe. I can't help it.  How can you not like a warm, inviting neighborhood place where the people are genuinely friendly and treat you like a next door neighbor who just happened to pop on over for a  visit? In fact, you probably are a neighbor who decided that it's too late and you're too tired to cook tonight.  If it's too busy, just go and sit in back and wait. Sip some wine together and talk.  Time really does fly when you're enjoying a still moment together. Let's face it. Those quiet, still moments in time mean more than all the other frenzied moments in our world anyway, don't they?  And before you know it, you're at your table.  The food is nothing that is going to blow your mind or anything.  But it's good. Nob Hill Cafe is like home. And home is good--or at least it ought to be.
author: Shadi G.

description:
We've gone to this place countless times thanks to its proximity to our apartment, but, as a would-be classy little neighborhood spot goes, it's only so-so.
The food, both dinner and weekend brunch, is relatively uninspired, and the waitstaff is slowly getting better (I'm pretty sure they finally got rid of this one waitress who was rotten to the core). The main reasons to go are its location on one of the prettiest blocks in the city, and (foodies cover your ears) the chance celebrity sighting. 
Probably not worth your time if you can't make it there by foot as parking on Nob Hill is always a joke.
author: Justin M.

description:
Best italian food in the City.

Could be better if it was a little larger and took
reservations.   Oh, but wait, that is exactly why
I like it.  It's small, hectic, cozy, a little dis-organized
but lovable for all those reasons.
author: Mike R.

description:
A great NEIGHBORHOOD restaurant filled with locals, not tourists.

I lived and worked in Nob Hill for a number of years. And this place was always like coming into a freinds home for dinner.  I recently was back in SF for vacation and wandered back over for old time sake. I am glad I did!

This is not the best Italian food in the city, it does not have the best wine list. HOWEVER, what it does have is a warm and friendly staff, very good basic Italian food at a very reasonable price, without the tourists.  I will come back to this restaurant every time.
author: RJ W.

description:
I am lucky that this is my neighborhood spot and only a couple blocks from me because the food is always so great. 

The atomosphere is inviting and warm and the staff are very friendly. The restaurant is small and popular, so you will most likely have a wait of anywhere from 15-45 minutes on any given night. 

You can't go wrong with what you order, the linguine with clams is amazing and the margherita pizza is yummy. Don't leave without trying the tiramisu, perfect finish to your meal. If you go on the weekend to brunch, I highly recommend the prawn and avacado omelette.
author: Melanie T.

description:
Great location(outside seating).
Food is OK.
Pizza very good also the pasta but the salads are little boring.
But it is worth going there in the afternoon when the sun is out.
author: Sandy W.

description:
Best in class simple no-nonsense Italian food.

Expect simple dishes and good service.  This is definitely not the best Italian food in SF.  It is also not the best atmosphere (although the twins are awesome!).  But it is the best mid-range Italian place SF has to offer.

This is the perfect spot to take a break from the typical over-done, over-priced and over-hyped yuppie restaurants in SF.  

Heads up:  be prepared to wait 20 - 40 mins during peak hours. . . and forget about parking anywhere near this place if you drive.
author: Trevor T.

description: The food is yummy and the proportions are very generous, so you're actually paying for lunch the next day too (my boyfriend, who is a large guy, couldn't even finish his pasta).  They give accurate time estimates for how long the wait is, which is appreciated.  The wait once we say down to eat, however, was a bit long. The only disappointing element was dessert: the options were minimal and not exciting. At least have a good chocolate option!  Overall, though, I'm very satisfied.
author: Mithra H.

description: Nob Hill Cafe is my favorite date spot in SF. I love the "mom and pop" feel to the restaurant. I cannot stray from the Fedelini alla Cecca, delicious every single time. The only downside is that there is not much parking around the restaurant so I would recommend cabbing or walking, if you live around the area. You also can't make reservations but they are really good about serving you drinks outside while you wait for a table.
author: Courtney D.

description: A wonderful little neighborhood cafe at the top of Nob Hill. On a Sunday night the place was packed and I waited 45 minutes for a table.  Luckily, the food was wonderful and the server excellent.  My gnocci bolignese was excellent, the wine well priced and the chocolate ganache dessert superb - I think I'm going back tonight to try their pizza!
author: Rick R.

description: My 3 friends and I came here at around 9 AM on a weekday, and we didn't have to wait which was great.  I ordered the French toast, which was great!  I highly recommend that dish.  My friends had the veggie burrito and pancakes, and they told me that they enjoyed their dishes too.  Their service was prompt, and the waitstaff was very polite.
author: Rona H.

description:
Our group of 5 were walk-ups at 8PM, had to wait 25 minutes or so for a table to accomodate us. The restaurant is cozy, bustling---wonderful neighborhood ambiance. No hint of tourists (except us!) Sipped some chianti outside while waiting. 
We all enjoyed our food; we ordered garlic bread (nothing ordinary, loads of grated parm on fabulous bread);
caprese salad, dressed with a mild balsamic;
proscuitto, pear and goat cheese pizza, also an anchovy and onion pizza. Note--these pies are plenty large enough for two people! 
Pasta carbonnara was my choice--even though I vowed to be good and eat light, I almost always give in when carbonnara is present. It was creamy, not over-rich. Pasta cooked perfectly.
Hubby had the pesto-I didn't taste it, but I did notice that he quit eating the generous portion at least 3 times! He kept going back for one more bite.
If my travels find me in SF again, I hope to return to this wonderful little place.
author: Patti T.

description: This is a spot we go to, without fail, on every trip to San Fran, usually in the middle of the day. It is a charming little place, with simple, made to order food and a decent little wine list. You cant go wrong here. I have eaten here 20+ times, always good. They get a bit slammed at lunch and dinner prime time, but, thats half the charm.
author: ken s.

description: I can't believe that this place gets such great reviews and is packed most nights. I was in temporary corporate housing for a while in Nob Hill so the Cafe was right at the end of the block. Nob Hill is apparently an authentic Italian. My experience has been reheated over-cooked pasta, served by a rather hasty Irish waiter. There are plenty of really authentic Italian restaurants in San Francisco, this is not one of them.
author: Cat R.

description: I've eaten here many times, but feel compelled to post this as I went here for my last time. The food is so mediocre and the hosts are so arrogant, yet they are so busy which is only explained because it is the only game in the Nob Hill area. The same owners have another restaurant in the area called Venticello and the food quality is equally mediocre. I'd accept the mediocre food for decent service, but bad service and mediocre food makes an evening very disappointing. Avoid this place if you can.
author: Jon B.

description: Cutest little spot! Phenomenal food, and the friendliest, Irish hostess!! Well worth the wait to have a beer outside while a table opened up.
author: Maryn M.

description: We had just come from a convention...and were looking for a place to eat and stumbled on the Nob Hill Cafe.....they were packed and we had a bit of a wait.  While we were waiting, a waiter, on vacation from Ireland, brought us drinks-outside-while we waited for our table.  Our waiter for the evening was Eamon, another lad from Dublin, very professional and quite chatty.  The food was outstanding...from the appetizers to the specials...the stuffed pork chop was off the hook...soup excellent and the vegetables very fresh.  All 5 of us really enjoyed our meals.  Hard to find issues with the restaurant, the service or the food...but, It would be nice if they had a full bar...not just beer and wine...and the restaurant felt crowded with the tables being so close together....otherwise, looking forward to returning.
author: Mark M.

description: Yummy, comfortable, casual, and they liquor you up with wine while you wait for a table.  I've been here a handful of times and have nothing but good things to say about this place.
author: Angela R.

description: mmmmm......that's what comes to mind when I think of this place.  My favorite restaurant in San Francisco.   It's very charming and the food is delicious.  The pizza is to die for.  I've also had their carbonara and bruschetta.  Both are excellent.  The tiramisu was probably the best I've had yet.  Even though they don't take reservations, this place is worth the wait!  Can't wait to visit again.
author: Sera L.

description:
Unfortunately, I have to agree with Lisa (below).  The food here is hugely mediocre and I don't understand how its gotten such high ratings on Yelp (are they all tourists??)  Went here on a Sunday night (no reservation, no line) at 7pm and...

Pros:
+ It's on a cute, tree-lined street near some parks, hotels and with scenic views from the top of Nob Hill
+ the service staff is SUPER nice.  Hostess and waitress were very sweet, busboys were friendly.
+ It has a homey, friendly but upscale feel to it
+ Its not super expensive.  Most expensive entree was $20.

Cons
- Food is very mediocre at best.  Went here for dinner and while the Polenta crostini appetizer was delicious and the Tiramisu was tasty, the two entrees we ordered were absolutely TERRIBLE.  We had the chicken parmesan and a mushroom pizza.  Pretty easy to get right, you'd think.  Not here.  The chicken came in a baking pan (like the polenta) but was smothered in cheese.  It was very bland and lacking in flavour and the chef had clearly tried to mask it by throwing a giant blob of parmesan on top (except it tasted like a much cheaper cheese).  If you dig beneath the cheese you get to some really boring chicken and penne.  And the pizza... cmon!  Again, smothered with cheese. Crust was not crispy, not properly cooked either.  Very little flavour, no interesting mushrooms (just a few boring button mushrooms thrown on top), no fresh herbs or anything! And the tomato sauce tasted like it came out of a can of tomatoes.  Yuck.  We could barely eat one slice.
 
- Another thing to note (I don't know whether you consider this a good or a bad) is that this place is incredibly touristy.  I think all the people riding the Powell St trolley end up here.  They probably think they're escaping the tourist traps of Union Sq.  There's also a LOT of kids (like an average of one at every table).  Its a very family type of place so keep that in mind if you were thinking of having a date here.

Bottom line: save your calories (and money) for something else.  Even Pizza Hut can do better than this.
author: Tash P.

description: I automatically knock a star for service and wait on a Wednesday night. Waiter had no personalty, never asked us if we needed anything and the wait for 2 was over an hour! I thoroughly enjoyed my gnocchi, and beet salad, but there are plenty of Italian places out there. I'm sure I'll go back and try something else amazing, until then only 3 stars.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Okay low rating was due to my idioticness of getting a Napoleon style pizza here. BUT I did look at every other dish that the other 4 people got and they didn't look to lavish either. My dear friend Ryan did grab the special of the night and it was a weird special for being in an Italian restaurant, Seafood Risotto Jambalaya! BAM! Yea I was going to get it but I was skerred. So he got it and I snuck some off his plate. It was very good. So with that said, I would deff recommend getting the specials, and also would recommend this place to mix it up a bit. There Italian style stuff just seemed to "Olive Garden" to me. Sorry Sarah, I know your gunna hate me for that, but the twins will forgive me. (inside joke) Moving on... Bruchetta was good, but I mean ca mon, rinse the tomatoes with balsamic and EVOO before you top that sourdough, love the fresh basil though. 


Okay it was also last minute on a weekend night for a table for 5, the wait was not long, but after that we were CRAMMED into a small table that usually I think would seat 2 but no worries. It was pretty busy in there and our waiter did wait so much on us. When in doubt just reach over and do things for yourself like we did. 

Menu lacked, wine list was OK, service was no bueno, but I had to give it 3 stars because the special for the night was very innovative, edgy and delicious! If there's a line, move on, if there isn't, sit down, cram up and order the special.
author: Ryan P.

description: No wait at 5:15pm on a Saturday. Had the special - butternut squash gnocchi with sage cream sauce ($19). The gnocchi seems to be the only fresh pasta they offer. The taste was excellent but I had to send it back because it wasn't hot enough. I also wish it was not sprinkled with whole peppercorns. The atmosphere was cozy and the server was pleasant. One minor issue was the oldies music that was a bit loud for my taste and seemed an odd choice for an Italian restaurant.  Coffee and tiramisu were fine, ganache was better.
author: Anne Marie A.

description:
I've been to this restaurant with friends and family close to a dozen times now and I've never been disappointed in my meal. The pizzas are delicious, the pasta is good not mind blowing but in my opinion there is only so much you can do.

The real stand-out menu items are on the brunch menu, the french-toast is phenomenal, I also highly, highly recommend the grilled potatoes. The best thing on the menu though is the Gnocchi Bolognese, it is fantastic!
author: Ty L.

description:
my favorite 'nob hill italian restaurant'.  Love the ambiance, very solid food, great wine.  (If they still have the Big Tattoo cab/syrah blend, GET THE BOTTLE!) Great pasta, decent service, worth the wait.  If you are super lucky you get one of cute window tables in the front.  Saw the famous SF twin ladies there the other night! 

Plus, politely offering me a free glass of wine for leaving my table after dinner?  Oh I think so!

This is the quintessential San Francisco italian restaurant.
author: lindsey s.

description:
Oh my gosh. This place was horrible.  The service was terrible.  The food was goddarn awful.  

My wife and I wanted to try this place for the longest time because we live in the neighborhood.  So one night, we decided to finally try it.  

First and foremost, what's with the sarcasm from the waitress.  We had to flag her down, and she wasn't even all that nice.  Plus, we didn't get her jokes.  I'm a smart mouth and a sarcastic personality, even I didn't get her .  It was extremely obvious that she didn't want to be there.  She did offer exceptional service to the people seated behind us.......

We ordered a Linguine alla Vologne and the Gnocchi.  The food was disgusting.  The gnocchi was not soft, but had a mushy texture and it was obvious that the sauce was prepared earlier and kept in a warmer.  The linguine itself was ok.  The clams were obviously from a can and tasted like so.  We tried the flan for dessert and it was hard.  I understood the gingery taste of the caramel sauce, but it didn't work with the hard consistency of the flan.  The flan looked like something you get at Safeway.  

Good atmosphere and good wine selection.  Plus, they do not serve dinner outside... only lunch.  What?!!
author: Stan V.

description: Absolutely love this charming lil place @ the top of Nob Hill. Have to walk up a huge hill from downtown to get there, but well worth it! Typically, the wait on a Friday night is about 25+ min.  Ask to be seated on the right half. Much cozier. We sat next to an out of town couple that suggested the Filet of Sole, and it was SO GOOD. Melts in your mouth. Those cute lil old lady Nob Hill socialite twins were there, sitting at their usual table by the window, in their legendary leopard print coats & cowboy hats, talking to anyone that stopped by their table. Also some celebrity dude was dining in the corner, (my date and I couldn't remember his name), but the guy has def been in movies...Nob Hill Cafe has quintessential SF charm, great food, and great service. Can't wait to go back!
author: Rebecca S.

description:
My boyfriend and I were on a Valentine's vacation and decided to try this place after reading the reviews. I ordered the lasagna because I had read the reviews and the server had told me that it "was the best."  My boyfriend ordered the gnocchi.

LASAGNA: I was shocked when it arrived. The sauce was watery and terrible tasting. I would have preferred Ragu from the jar. The pasta was overcooked to the point that it broke when I tried to pick it up with my fork. This is just a brief overview. I've never had such awful "Italian" food combined with haughty service.

GNOCCHI: The gnocchi itself was not bad but the sauce was bland with unseasoned ground beef thrown into it. 

I sent the lasagna back and declined the offer for a replacement dish. If you in town for vacation and looking for a decent meal, this is NOT the place to waste your time at.
author: chis j.

description: This place is delicious and charming, even for someone who can't eat gluten, which seems to be kind of a staple ingredient in Italian cuisine. Our waitress was really nice and helped me pick out something gluten-free (chicken in a butter, lemon, & caper sauce w/ big side of fresh veggies). It was the best chicken I have ever had & I wasn't even sad that I couldn't eat any of the pasta or bread that everybody else was enjoying.
author: Matea H.

description:
We moved to the neighborhood a few months ago and every time i stroll by i think to myself what a cute place this looks like, and the smell is always very tempting too. Finally this sunday while wandering home from nob hill spa the hubbs and i both totally relaxed and not in any mood to shop for groceries or cook dinner we decided we'd give them a whirl. But we didn't have the patience to wait for a table nor did we feel like dining there we wanted to get home and continue our relaxing evening so we ordered to go. We split a pizza, lasagna and a salad. 
The pizza was good, I'm sure I'll order it again. The salad while being my favorite soft mixed greens, the dressing was bland and no vinagrete or balsamic at an italian place? that's weird. It was only ok. 
The lasagna was good, extra extra saucy. The bread, just ok. 
The servings sizes were pretty small so we'll remember that for next time. 
I'm sure eating in would give it an extra star as the ambiance seems nice. But I was hoping this would be my new replacement for Cinecita (my all time favorite fresh pizza and salad place in the city, which used to be right down the street from my house). But this didn't fit the bill.
author: Audrey V.

description: This place is just a couple blocks from my house, and I can't get enough of it.  The Carbonara is ON POINT!
author: mar m.

description:
The first thing I want you to know about this place, is that this review is being written two months after having eaten at this place.

This was our best dining experience of our SF vacation.  

We found the place by accident after walking home from Grace Cathedral.  We both decided we were hungry, looked around and said "that place looks as good as any"  We eventually found the front door (it's got two doors, only one actually let's you in).  

The place was busy, with a good buzz.  we sat near the bar and had comfortable space and volume for conversation.

Our server was Eamon from Dublin.  A little out of place at first consideration, but very easy to talk to, and he knew the menu well.  Even with the place as busy as it was, he was still easy to find and nothing was amiss at our table.  

The regular menu was a little uninspired,  but looking around at the other tables, everything looked well prepared and the people were happy.  I would recommend ordering from the specials board instead.  

I had a seafood lasagne which was a risk on my part since I usually don't order that type of dish. It was fantastic and the reason I suggest ordering the specials.  My wife had the pepper tortellini which was spicy, but not over hot.  

The place isn't a kids place, but children were welcome and seemed to be comfortable there as well even though the place was grown-up, but not stuffy.

Eat here. nuff said.
author: Martin D.

description: Quite possibly the best lasagna I have ever had.  Stopped in with my wife and daughters, ages 16 & 13.  Everyone enjoyed their meal.  The service was excellent.  I would highly recommend.
author: Mike L.

description: We went to the Nob Hill Cafe based on a recommendation from one of our tour guides.  We are very glad I did.  I would have eaten here every day on our trip if I could have.  We sat right next to where you could see the food being cooked.  It was pretty interesting to see how the food is prepared.  They make it look so easy!  Our server was Robin, which was very good.  She provided excellent service and great recommendations on what to order.  If you love Italian food, this is the place to go.
author: Ashley R.

description: I took my friend here for our 15th friendship anniversary. The wait wasn't long. In fact, I don't think we waited at all. This was a Tuesday evening. I had a special: risotto with pesto and chicken and she had the fettuccine al pesto. The food is delicious. And it was plentiful. We had left overs for lunch the next day. It might be a bit over priced but still reasonable. The service was great, and friendly. Great for a small date or night out. I did not get a chance to try their dessert but the items on their dessert menu sounded delicious. Good food, good atmosphere.
author: Alex E.

description:
We had a great dinner this past Friday at the Nob Hill Cafe. It must have been our night because not only did we get parking near the restaurant, and a table right away on a Friday night, we got to eat right by Marian and Vivian Brown, San Francisco's famous twins. They got pretty sticking drunk too--so much fun!
The food was good but nothing special. The service was good and the atmosphere was the same. I'd go back again.
author: Steve A.

description: Fantastic! Read about it here on Yelp, decided to try it. Great service, great food, great prices. My son fell in love with the Chocolate Chip Gelato.
author: Diane S.

description: The food is fine. But what century do we live in? I took myself out to dinner there, as my partner had dinner plans with his mates, and it's only a block from my apt. The waiter was so incredibly rude to me. They stuck me conspicuously right under the specials sign, where everyone had to look. He barely spoke to me at alll, and when I left, did not say thank you, or come again--he actually SCOWLED at me and made like a humph noise. Now, I had ordered a nice glass of wine and a fairly expensive dish and was dressed very well. I was polite, and confident, and he was a complete moron for treating me this way. His demeanor with ALL other guests, including a single gentleman that was there, was totally different. I would never go there again with or without company.
author: Rudy S.

description: I went for dinner with a friend on a Friday night and the blonde Irish waitress is the only waitress on duty there. I tell her I have a friend coming (and it was already me and my girlfriend there), and she says that the whole party has to be there first. I wasn't sure if my friend was in fact coming so we sat at a table for 2. Then my friend texted me and said that he was a few minutes away. I tell the guys next to me, only two guys, sitting at a table of 4, if it was okay to switch with them when my friend arrived.. and they said no problem. When my friend came, the blonde Irish waitress makes a HUGE SCENE, tells my friend frantically "Excuse me, stay outside! You just entered in the middle of an ARGUMENT!" She gets really red and angry and tells me that I didn't follow the "rules of the restaurant", gives me the card voluntarily of the manager and tells me that I should leave because "[I] won't be happy here."  People around me were looking and thinking, "what the hell is wrong with this waitress...?!" I was so shaken by her attitude and her voice that my hands were trembling and me and my friend left the restaurant. This was a very very odd night and although previously this restaurant may have been one of my local favorites --- I highly advise anyone to not go there anymore because of how they poorly treat their customers. Be cautious of the big blonde Irish waitress because she may ruin your weekend!!!
author: Julia G.

description: This is a great little Italian restaurant in Nob Hill. The service is excellent as is the food. We came here to celebrate a new job :) and we really enjoyed ourselves - it wasnt cheap but believe me we enjoyed the food & the wine & the dessert. We are fans and we'll be back soon :)
author: Kimberly R.

description:
"I like it a lot"

lasagna was tasty, but served coldish.  I'll let it go, perhaps it was just my luck of the draw.  homemade gnocchi was fab.  the meat sauce was the real star.  finished the meal off with chocolate ganache.  'twas truly a fatty marathon.

we sat in the cozy window nook.  this definitely provided for excellent people watching, engrossing conversation, romanticalness.  

highly recommended.
author: Sammi C.

description: By the time I'd walked to Nob Hill from SOMA I had worked up a hunger. Read a review saying the lasagna was great and it didn't disappoint!
author: Tim G.

description: A very nice little quaint Italian restaurant with exceptional pasta and classic Italian dishes to offer. The chefs are always fantastic and on top of their game, but the waitresses can be short at times. Regardless, a favorite of mine!
author: Matt D.

description:
Brunch was excellent there.  They open at 11 on Sunday so we were able to get there at a little before and able to beat the crowd but I could see since it is tiny (but beautiful), there could be a wait.  
I had the prawn omelette and it was moist and very well made.  Wish I got an extra serving of the potatoes but we saved room for their unbelievable ganache.  
Only complaint is that I wish they came by to check on beverages more.  My glass was empty a couple of times and it was hard to make eye contact with anyone to get refills.  
My husband and I will be back.  We had a great time.
author: Alisha B.

description: Worth a walk.  Timing is important as space is limited and this joint can pack 'em in.  The herb bread is amazing.  Affordable wine list.  Great service.
author: Shad A.

description: I just LOVE LOVE This place. I used to live a block away in Nob Hill so I frequently ate here and took ppl to the restaurant. It usually is crowded...the SF twins do come here...and it's not exactly cheap but I think it's worth it. My fav. dish is the fish...and my least fav would be the gnocchi. Everything else is fantastic!!
author: A G.

description: I'm a huge fan of italian food. My g/f and me were in San Francisco on vacation and wanted Italian food. First off this place is tiny and tables are small, which is great for dates. Its a very cozy/intimate spot. We rarely drink wine(because we never know how to order it) so we asked our waitress for a recommendation and she recommended the Valpolicella. Very great suggestion, before we knew it the bottle was empty, and im a casual drinker, very smooth. Now on to the meals... We ordered the Bruschetta- i'd give it 4 stars, good but not amazing. My g/f ordered the Fedellini alla Cecca- a 3 out of 5, nothing special. I ordered the Spaghetti alla Carbonara- a 5 out of 5. WOW this dish was amazing. My g/f ate more off my plate than her own. This dish is a must! For dessert we ordered the Gelato Try-Its Mango with toasted coconut and walnuts. Another amazing dish, very delicious. Service, atmoshpere and dishes were all great! Next time I visit San Francisco I will definetly be back.
author: Cuate R.

description: One of my favorite places go to! Everything about it is fantastic - the food, the cozy romantic feel, and the location. I heart nob hill cafe!
author: Alex S.

description: "The lasagna is very good but the service is terrible. The first time I went there to drink a coffee with my dad they served us bread with butter then we got the coffee. We were eating the bread and the waitress took it from us because it was just 2 cups of coffee. The waiters are very rude and racist.
author: Anuardi J.

description:
always a huge wait during peak hours and no reservations, but i guess i understand why.  the food is delicious, the location is nice and quaint, and the atmosphere (though loud and busy when full) is indicative of people enjoying a good italian meal.  

I had the special lobster ravioli which was delicious.  I had a bit of the carbonara (another favorite of mine) that my table mate really enjoyed, but I found a bit dry.  Our third party member got fish, which was light and buttery.  

Even though it was crowded the wait staff was attentive.  It also helped that we closed the restaurant down so once the last tables were leaving, new people weren't replacing them and then our experience became much more enjoyable...though we did have to wait about 30 min. to be seated.  

we even saw the infamous twins while we were there!  so i'll probably be back, but maybe on a weeknight when there are fewer people vying for tables.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
i had an incredibly bad experience at this place, and am still pissed about it. 
i had gnocchi bolognese which were fantastic. 4 stars for the food. 
service - HORRIFIC! a big fat zero! LITERALLY THE WORST SERVICE I HAVE EVER SEEN IN MY LIFE! that bitch is in a category of her own! everyone i told the story to was in disbelief, apparently i am not the only one who finds this kind of behavior shocking. 
i wanted to describe my experience here, but it's so long and ridiculous, i can't be bothered. i manage a small restaurant, a bit bigger that this place, and i run the entire front of the house operations, so i know for a fact that it is not necessary to be as stressed out or as big of a bitch to people around you as this woman is. not only is it unnecessary, it is unacceptable! if you work in the service industry then act like it. 
whoever owns this place should fire her ass and save some customers, and save other employees some grief and unhappiness for having to work next to that monster. i am personally not going there as long as she is around. plenty of good restaurants around, no need to be going somewhere where the server treats you with such disrespect and lack of manners as here.
author: Ilovelife Z.

description:
When we arrived at the Nob Hill Cafe they were surprisingly not too busy and we were seated promptly. We ordered and shared a salad and pizza, which were delivered within a reasonable amount of time and were both fresh and delicious. Wife and I shared a tiramisu which was the best I have ever had, definitely made in house with all fresh ingredients.

Service was attentive, but not overly friendly, but didnt detract from the experience in the least.
author: Jeff M.

description: Stumbled on to Nob Hill Cafe when I was staying at the Stanford Court Renaissance. It's darling. I walked right in, was surrounded by locals, and enjoyed an incredible bolognese gnocchi with a glass of chianti. Small, crowded lay out gives it an intimate feel, which I loved. Service was great. Highly recommend stumbling on to this one.
author: Aubrey C.

description:
If you taste buds crave exquisite Italian food, forget venturing out to North Beach, Nob Hill Café is where it's at! This place does not take reservations so expect to wait outside sometimes for as much as forty five minutes, but it is well worth the wait and the hostess will gladly let you indulge on a glass of wine (or a few ) as you do so. I recommend coming here for lunch on a sunny day when the crowd is less bustling so you can soak up some rays while feasting on this venues' fabulous food. 

My meal attack plan~
     Appetizer: Fresh Bruschetta on the lighter days or on the "I'm so hungry I could eat a horse" days the mouth watering grilled polenta with home made marinara and fresh basil, MMMMmmm! I don't usually like polenta but this one is on a whole other scale of fabulousness!
     Main Course: For a luncheon I usually order one of their thin crust New York style  pizza's (which you can order with any variety of toppings to suit your fancy, but the simplicity of the pizza Margherita is superb) or their calzone which could feed two. Order a side of their marinara so you can dip your pizza or calzone in it, so good! For dinner you HAVE, I repeat HAVE!!! to order the Gnocchi Bolognese! I thought their regular marinara sauce was mouth watering until I tried their home made Bolognese sauce and nearly licked my plate clean! The Gnocchi is freshly made the day of and is tender, not chewy like most pre-packaged gnocchi's in restaurants now days. I always accompany every meal with either a glass of their Riff Pinot Grigio or an ice cold Peroni, so refreshing.
     Dessert: If I have left an ounce of room for dessert I usually order the Tiramisu and a shot of espresso. The Tirimisu is again, made fresh daily and they use an exceptional quality of ricotta. They serve Illy coffee which finishes off any meal exceptionally!

Pricing is moderate depending on what you order. The wait staff is very friendly and informative, although can be a tad slow to get your order in due to the mass amount of patrons that visit this venue. Expect to see the infamous San Francisco twins dining here at least once a week! Great venue for a romantic night out with your girl or a casual lunch with a long lost friend!
author: Bri C.

description: GNever had a chance to experience the food.  The hostess was not welcoming--asked us to wait outside while she checked for a table.  We were seated in a very cramped table were the front door would bang into the chair of one of our guests.  We asked for another table--while many tables were empty, we were told that would not be possible.  She was not helpful or interested in making guests feel welcome--we left.  Hostess lacked both class and tact.
author: Karen B.

description: great ambience, great date location, food is solid authentic Italian, very Paris bistro feel, very intimate...
author: Shane P.

description: I have eaten here many times and every time I do I walk away feeling wonderful. The food is great. The atmosphere is very intimate. Place is  very small so space is limited. If you go during high traffic times plan on a wait and not in the bar. It will be worth the wait.
author: Tim O.

description: my girlfriends and i came here on our trip to SF and just happened to stumble upon this super cute and quaint italian place.  thanks to yelp, we saw it had 4 stars and so we were happy to try it.  i ordered the linguine and clams and it was TO DIE.  my friend had ordered the tortellini special, which was really good, too.  i dont usually eat all my food and i didn't here, but if i could i would have annihilated the entire bowl.  generous portions.  i'd go back for sure.
author: Kris R.

description: I read the Yelp reviews of this place before attending a birthday dinner here, so I was excited about it; so many four and five star reviews!  I tried many dishes from the dinner menu, including the awful gnocchi that is actually recommended on Yelp several times  (chewy and tastes overwhelmingly of nutmeg, canned tomato sauce).  Does an Italian place that uses canned tomato sauce, crappy cheeses, mediocre dried pasta and only frozen meats (we asked) deserve five stars?  Really? I don't think so.
author: Bucky M.

description:
I'm a little biased because it's right down the street but it's amazing nonetheless.  

Let's start with the bread.  Amazing, some of the best bread you will ever have, but make sure you go for dinner because they don't make it until dinnertime.

The atmosphere is great and if you go on a Tuesday you will probably catch a glimpse of the famous SF Twins.

The gnocchi with meat sauce is tremendous and order a pizza on the side.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Jake B.

description:
I was here with 3 friends on a Wednesday night. We arrived at 5:00 and had no trouble getting seated, but by the time we left an hour later people were lined up outside waiting to get in. The table was a little bit small, but we didn't feel cramped. 

They have several specials listed on a chalkboard, which our server mentioned to us. It took a little longer than I'd expected before our server finally took our orders, but not too bad. I simply had a caesar salad with a bowl of cream of artichoke soup -- the soup was fantastic! Two of my companions enjoyed their veal piccata and linguini & clams. One also ordered a caesar salad, but asked if she could add grilled chicken to the salad (not listed as an option on the menu), and they were happy to accomodate her request.

Two of us had a glass of wine; our total with tip was about $29 per person. I found the service to be good; our server was fairly attentive, and empty plates were removed pretty promptly. I will definitely go back, but when I feel more like taking advantage of the pasta or other traditional dishes (not just soup & salad!).
author: Tom M.

description: Kathy C., a font of Nob Hill insight, and I were disappointed by the absence of the Nob Hill Twins (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marian_and_Vivian_Brown) when we came here, but not by the presence of the lasagna, which was piping hot, savory, and filling. I could have skipped the salad and gone straight to it. I love how many seats they've manager to cram into their little restaurant-on-a-hill.
author: Jon F.

description: WOW!!! this place is amazing!! it is super tiny and they only serve wine and beer, but this place is amazing! the pasta here is top notch!! and you know when you go out to eat and you are hella hungry,  you are craving some big ass bowel of delicious pasta.. you order it.. and 30 minutes later they bring out a plate with 4 pieces of ravolis and your left with that thought "how the hell is this going to fill me up?!"  so you eat the 4 pieces, then grab the bread and start dipping it into the left over sauce and the end of it your bloated and unhappy.. well this place gives you a big ass bowel of pasta!! hella good!! i got the penne with spicy, cream, vodka garlic sauce!! eric had the pasta with egg and bacon.. he loved it!! but the best thing about this place was the ice cream its it.. it has a cheese cake crust and some type of crumble on top to match the ice cream!!! wow.. i want that ice cream its it.. this place is totally worth it and has wallet friendly prices!!
author: Ashley M.

description:
I've tasted great dishes here but both food and service are inconsistent. Had lasagna last Sunday which had potential but was overly salty and not hot all the way through. Sent it back and it returned bubbly hot. Last time my girlfriend has a penne pasta with lamb sausage that was to die for, one of the best Italian dishes I've ever tasted. The hostess is cool and not very welcoming. The server was friendly but disappeared for long stretches. Wine list is ok but limited - you can bring your own and have them uncork it for $15 but they only have those little Italian wine glasses, not big goblets that let a fine wine open up.

Overall this is a classic SF place: small, cozy with occasionally great food, but frustrating in the end because it doesn't consistently live up to its potential. And the lukewarm hostess makes you feel like they're doing you a favor rather than appreciating that you're patronizing their restaurant. But if remains popular because there are few options in the neighborhood for casual dining with good food.
author: Michael S.

description:
This is a good, solid neighborhood place in Nob Hill that is very homey and inviting.  

Though it is in a tony part of town, the restaurant itself is not pretentious at all.  It comes across much more as a neighborhood restaurant, and the prices are not excessive. 

We've been there 2-3 times, and the food is good, solid food.  It's also one of the few places we've been able to score whole roasted garlic cloves.  Drizzled with olive oil, this stuff is milder than you would think, but you will still smell like garlic for days, because it'll be coming out of your pores.

A couple glasses of wine at a small table near the window, and you have the perfect getaway.  It was rumored that the famous San Francisco Twins-- elderly twin ladies who always dressed in exactly the same outfits in public-- were regulars here.

I'd give it 5 stars, but what with so many other great restaurants in SF, it if were *that* good, we would've been back already.
author: Dave N.

description: Sure, the wait is long but let me first say I love the location and the ambiance of this place. It's located in the rather quiet Taylor st with a cozy feel inside. The dim light, the small space, the cute decoration, it almost makes you feel you have just wander into some hidden restaurant in the streets of Italy. It's just what you need for a peaceful weekday night. The gnocchi is great, their gnocchi is well made with the right chewy and firm texture, and the classic combination with tomato sauce makes it heavenly. I returned last week on a not so busy night for carbonara. That was just ok, and it certainly didn't stand out at all from other Italian places.  We also had eggplant parm which was below mediocre. Regarding the staff, first time when we were there, super friendly, but last time was with a grumpy big man who seemed unsatisfied with his job and managed to show it all on his face, and he was simply clumsy as a waiter with a lot of bumping onto you or the table. With the last remark, I am gonna give it an overall of 3 star but otherwise 4 star for its gnocchi and ambiance.
author: Fung S. O.

description:
Very rude and apathetic service.  I was with 2 friends, they got their entrees but the manager brought the wrong thing to me - I ordered a pizza, everyone at the table heard it.  So he says, "Oh...okay.  Sorry.  It'll be a few minutes."

So we have that awkward situation where they have hot food, and I tell them to eat...eventually they start.  Now I'm sitting near the oven, and I watch about 2 dozen pizzas come out.  NONE comes to our table.  We asked the manager and he keeps saying, "just a few minutes."  After about 25 minutes, my pizza comes out.  I asked him why he didn't put my order in front of all the others and he says, "Oh, they had their orders in already."  "Yeah, but I ordered first!"  So he says, "Uh-huh."  Like, call someone who gives a shit.

Now I've been in situations like this before, and I just expected them to take the lousy 10 bucks off of the menu.  Did they?  NO!  They charged the full amount!  Just pissed me off, no real apology, no effort to make the customer happy, and no offer of a free glass of wine, dessert, any of the things a decent restaurant would do.
author: David R.

description: Fantastic Gnocchi! And wonderful Pastas, Calamari, Veal as well. Not to mention the killer Tiramisu. Pizza is OK. Salads range from good to very good. This really is a hidden neigborhood gem. Been going there even under the previous owner since the '80's. Far better than most of the big name Italian Restaurants. Summary: You really have to try this!
author: A K Y.

description: This is a little gem of a place in a residential area frequented mostly by locals.  Very modest looking, but what great food.  Not the place to go for a date or if you're looking for wow factor.  This is a come as you are, jeans and casual attire place.  Wines by the glass are reasonable and good quality, always changing.  Caesar salad the absolute best with freshest hearts of Romaine, sweet and delish. Great sourdough bread.  My favorite dish is the Petrale Sole, always consistent and yummy.  The best I've ever had.  All entrees reasonably priced.  Expect to wait most of the time except early lunch or dinner times. One of my regular spots when visiting San Francisco.  The famous twins are there every Tuesday for dinner!
author: Mr. Helper L.

description: Just came here for the first time, and really wish it was closer to home so I could come here all the time!  Very friendly and cute place.  We were downstairs at the back table which was  little darker, so get a table near the window if you can.  I had the classic eggs benedict and my husband had the pesto scramble, and both were excellent.  The home fries are particularly tasty!
author: Kristin G.

description: I'm from Texas, and we went here based on Yelp reviews. lives up to it's rep!! What a calm area with legit Italian food, and the house wine is even phenomenal. so impressed.
author: Anna S.

description: Have eaten here many times over many years.  Food is always solid.  kid friendly if you go early and do not have to wait.  Staff is always friendly and efficient.  Great local neighborhood  place.
author: Eric D.

description: After waiting 40 minutes to eat, because the careless hostess gave away our table, we finally were seated to a sub-par experience. While the food was average, it certainly was not worth the wait or the cost. The appetizers were pretty good, however, the entrees were bland. Overall, I would not recommend this place, and the service was definitely lacking.
author: David D.

description: When I lived on Snob Hill, this was one of my regular rotating dining spots. At first glance, it doesn't look like a nice Italian restaurant, nor does its name convey, but just stroll by and you'll be stopped dead in your tracks by this sudden, intoxicating waft of heavenly yet simple Italiano cookery. It's a cozy, charming place (read: small), and the spicy Penne Bettola in vodka sauce is superb! Say hello to the Brown Sisters from me if they're perched in the front window.
author: Gregor G.

description:
This place is awesome. The food is great, somehow it feels more spacious than it is (this place is tiny!), the service is great, and the cooks are really friendly.

It can be quite busy, but it's worth waiting for. And it's always a great surprise when there's no wait.
author: Elianna G.

description: Gnocchi was delicious. Best homemade ever tasted in San Francisco.
author: Gina R.

description:
me: where are we going for dinner?

him: You'll see

me: Uh, not really into surprises... where are we going?

him: :)

me: *annoyed* Do I have to dress up?

him: no

So after a couple days of being super annoyed and looking up every Italian joint on nob hill on yelp... I was STOKED when I finally found out this is where my mystery Tuesday night day was going to be.

20 Minute Wait out side with HUGE drop of water landing on my perfectly styled hair... who cares they just brought me a big glass of wine to keep me warm.

Once inside we order a bottle of wine and the perfectly salted carpaccio. our waitress was delightful and totally funny. he order the pesto and I ordered the gnocchi. 

Night was fun and laid back UNTIL our waitress arrives looking a little frazzled... "Would you like desert?" We both decline and pour ourselves a little more wine. She returns "I'm SO embarrassed... we have a large party coming in and we have to move you to the back. I will buy you both another glass of wine!"
We don't refuse and the next thing you know we are being poured to the rim glasses of red wine and the chocolate/strawberry desert is being laid out in front of us.

I'm pretty laid back about most things but this experience (despite the table change) was absolutely wonderful. Kinda want to take Mom and Dad here next weekend when they are in town!
author: Nancy B.

description: Had to wait a little bit for a seat, but was definitely worth it. If I ever come back to San fran, this would be first place I goto again. Absolutely love the food!
author: Nathan W.

description:
Since my last review, I have eaten here many times (mostly for brunch). The sliders (egg, sausage, cheese) are yummy but try to share them if you can b/c having 3 might be too greasy for you. Their eggs benedict w/salmon was pretty good, the egg cooked just as I had asked for it (soft).

Had dinner here recently for the first time & had mixed reviews. Service was a little slow but I think there was only one cook & one waiter for the whole place! Had the beet salad w/tomatoes, greens, & goat cheese croquettes which was very good. Split the vegetarian cannoli & the crepes were so thin they were barely existent, so don't order it if you are expecting pasta -- it was good filling but practically eating all filling & crepe. Also split the stuffed burger (portobello & brie) which was okay but a little dry. The sweet potato fries were very good.

Good customer service though -- when we commented that the canneloni wasn't what we expected, our waiter took off one of salads from the bill. Very responsive.

Will definitely eat here again (& again). It's a neighborhood joint & apparently they change menus seasonally so should have new options coming soon
author: D L.

description: It's so nice to have THIN pizza again! I'm glad my reintroduction to the "better crust" was from Nob Hill Cafe.
author: Esme W.

description: Love this neighborhood eatery. It is cozy and warm and the food is delicious. Whenever I am craving Italian food, this is my go to place. Their pastas are amazing and they have a great selection of wine. They don't take reservations, so I recommend going when the weather is nice so that you can enjoy a glass of wine outside while you wait.
author: Lauren Y.

description: The place I beg my boyfriend to take me on dates. Cozy and romantic and simple, it's the picturesque night out. Not too expensive, the fare is Italian and delicious and comforting.  If my biography film is a rom-com, this is the place that we'd meet cute, fall in love, have some misunderstanding hijinks and break up, and then get back together in front of.
author: Shannon V.

description: Friendly service and super yummy pasta! Order the linguine & clams, it's to die!
author: M C.

description: Cozy atmosphere, great location, and very delicous pizza and salad. This is our new sf favorite!
author: sean o.

description: I've only had brunch here but plan to go for dinner asap. OMFG the French Toast was fabulous! Yummy sourdough topped with raspberries and strawberries. It was a nice day out so we got a table out front and enjoyed the cute neighborhood and people watching. Not overwhelmingly busy and the waitress was really friendly. Now that I live close I will be back for more!
author: Valerie N.

description: Stellar service. Excellent food. Reasonable prices. What's not to love about this place? Minus one star because they don't take reservations, but other than that I have no complaints. I came here for brunch with a friend and had the French toast on ciabatta bread and fresh fruit and the potatoes with rosemary on the side. Everything was tasty and well-portioned. I took a peak at their amazing dinner menu and will definitely come back again, hopefully with a date this time ;)
author: Natalie T.

description: What a great place for brunch!  My girlfriends and I love coming here for the warm & cozy atmosphere.  They provide wonderful customer service and we've never had to wait long to be seated.  The food is delicious and the portions are huge.  Also, they have corn muffins that's to die for!
author: Suzanne C.

description:
Basically, it's not worth the wait. 

I think this place is popular because there aren't many restaurants in the area.  We waited a really long time for what was only decent Italian food.  Also, some of the dishes came out cold.  It was a convenient location for us, but there are tons of better Italian restaurants in this city.
author: Tina S.

description: Delicious...went here last night for a grand meal. I think that all four of the girls that I ate here with had no complaints, everything was great.  I split the Spaghetti alla Carbonara - pancetta, romana cream sauce and the pizza special with a friend and both were awesome.  I also tried my friend's Melanzane alla Parmigiana and thoroughly enjoyed that as well, although it was super cheesy, which was not a bad thing.  The pinto grigio was great, especially because they let us enjoy a bottle outside while we were waiting for our table.  All in all a great time.  Although it conquered any of my plans of going out after being as full as I was when we left.
author: ELIZABETH W.

description: Great food! Great atmosphere! Great service! Great location! Great eye candy! Not ideal for kids, wheelchairs or whiners. Why? Because it's teeny tiny inside. Traditional Italian cuisine and a decent wine selection, a stroll in Huntington Square on Nob Hill after wards is a must as it is no more than two blocks away. Easy to access from downtown too, hop on the California Cable Car, depart at Grace Cathedral then simply walk one block over. Voila! Who needs North Beach? Superb.
author: Jack G.

description: Great restaurant! I really liked the ambiance and food was very good. I had the sole cooked in white wine and caper lemon sauce. There were snap peas and asparagas that were cooked perfectly-still crunchy. They do not take reservations and we did have to wait awhile for a table. The menu has pizza and other italian dishes. The hostess and waitress were very nice. Prices are reasonable for the nob hill area.
author: greg w.

description: I shared the cold antipasta and a pizza. Both were excellent. Loved all the grilled veggies in the appetizer. The pizza was a great Cali style pie. Will definitely return here.
author: Joshua S.

description: Great spot for brunch, very cozy environment, the food is very good, some outside seating, nice little street.
author: Eric W.

description:
Went here last night with the g/f.

The food is very good and the price is even better (their wine list is small but the price is worth it)!

Starter: Calamari

Main Course: We went with the recommendations and had Gnocchi  and the Chicken Parmesan.  Both were great

Dessert: Vanilla Bean Cheese Cake

Will definitely be back.  Warning though...it is small and they do not take reservation. So don't be surprised if you'll have to wait
author: Adam E.

description: Great location.  Went with a large party and the waitress did not take good care of us. Got our order wrong and didn't listen much else either. It wasn't anything special
author: Paigey B.

description: I've eaten here many times over the past decade, and the food is always excellent.  Come early if you don't want to wait (and be forewarned that parking in this neighborhood is challenging).
author: D. S.

description: I loved sitting outside this restaurant and enjoying the chicken parm. The server was friendly and the food was good as well.
author: John G.

description: I am so happy to have NHC as my neighborhood restaurant. It is always delicious and the atmosphere is cozy and relaxing. When the sun is shining I always get the urge to head over to the outdoor tables for the pizza specials, hefty caprese, familiar staff, the list continues. Catch the twins at the window seat and eat some oily and cheesy carbonara. If you live near, you're lucky, but hey get ur ass over here anyway wherever you are, but don't take my seat!
author: Cassie C.

description: One of my favorite places in the neighborhood.  I don't think you can really go wrong with anything on the menu.  They can often forget to tell you the specials, so be sure to ask, they are usually what I order when I go!  We had a group of six of us for Christmas Eve and they had to split us into a table of four and a table of two, kind of a bummer.  But, they were patient with us and understood us popping over now and then to the other table.  I mean, it was Christmas Eve!  If you find yourself wandering around Grace Cathedral, definitely stop by for a bite here.  There can be a wait though, but it's worth it.
author: Lauren H.

description: Last weekend I came here with my bf to visit his sister, Michelle, who is a waitress at this restaurant. We only had champagne and some complimentary bread while we waited for her to get off work. But I definitely want to come back to eat the food! The place is small so don't come by if you get claustrophobic easily! When the place is busy there is barely enough room to walk to the bathroom (which is all the way in the back of the restaurant in the farthest corner too)  :) But I saw the menu and the items looked really appetizing. Mostly pastas and pizza entrees. But the prices were reasonable too..about $11-15 a plate so not bad at all!! The desserts looked soo good too! My favorites were the Ganache and the Gelato "Try-Its." Next time I come here I will definitely order both...I love dessert!
author: Lauren S.

description: Carbonara, margherita, tiramisu, cramped tables, kitchen in the front, and the twins in the window.  'Nuff said.  Eat here.
author: Daryl E.

description: This place will flip your whig man!  Deeeeeelicous!
author: Scott L.

description: This is one of those places that makes me feel like I live in San Francisco.  You are up on a hill, the fog is rolling in, and you can sit outside with a glass of wine and watch the people walk by.  As for the restaurant, I liked it.  The food was nothing spectacular but I am sure I didn't try the most adventurous thing on the menu (spaghetti aglio olio).  It sure did hit the spot though.  Plus a glass of prosecco is a mere $6 so I could have two without feeling guilty (but still a little tipsy).  All in all a nice place with friends or a date.
author: Lindsay P.

description: Nice little cozy restaurant. Great food, decent wine, excellent deserts, and the service was perfect. I would give this place 6 stars if I could.
author: Deepak J.

description:
We went for dinner before drinks at the Top of the Mark.  I was so upset by the end of dinner I couldn't tell you if the food was any good or not.

Half way through my glass of wine I found not 1, but 4 small flies in my glass!

I was so disgusted and the waiter was very unsympathetic, only taking the glass of wine off the bill and barely an apology.

I will never ever go back.
author: BH ..

description: As of late this has become my local date spot, no complaints there. Nob Hill Cafe is that local unknown gem that became famous, or so it seems. What I love about it is that despite its popularity it has resisted putting on any airs of pretension. The staff and the food are both amazing, but not frilly or up tight. It's a great place to go get a decently priced home style Italian meal with good service. The usual hostess is probably my favorite in the city because she always has a smile on her face and is ready to help without being in the least bit fake. P.s. - its also a favorite hang out of the double mint twins. Last time I was there we were sitting in "their" table. Those little old ladies can pack a seriously mean punch...
author: Jennifer C.

description: Great place for a Sunday brunch. Parking is hard on Nob Hill but worth the effort.
author: Colin B.

description: Wonderful little cafe near Grace Cathedral. No reservation, so be prepared to wait but you can have a glass of wine outside while you wait. Lovely thoughtful hostess, polite and friendly server. A treasure on the hill!
author: anne c.

description: what's not to love about this neighborhood cafe? Yes, it's tiny and noisy and you'll probably have to wait for a table. BUT! the food is fabulous. Such a fresh and light Italian menu. Super cozy on a foggy night. Very reasonably priced. They aren't trying to be a food snob restaurant. They just execute flawlessly on what they do! fresh Italian food served in a cozy authentic neighborhood cate at a fair price.
author: Annie N.

description: Really bad service and average food.  Nothing else was nearby, so it really was a pointless trip up to Nob Hill.  We heard it was good, but later found out it was Nob Hill GRILL and not this place, Nob Hill CAFE!
author: Kendra M.

description: Food was very bland.  The pesto was below par.  Service was slow as only one waitperson was trying to serve the entire restaurant.  Not worth climbing the hill
author: B B.

description: Nice Brunch type spot but teeny.  Good coffee, good pasta, interesting specials (we looked in the door one day but went elsewhere).  I very nice spot to stop and have a good cup of coffee on the way (walking) down the hill from Nob Hill to Fisherman's Wharf.  I did like the looks of the dinner menu in this food-fabulous town.  Give it a try.
author: Gadget G.

description: Nice place, they do there best so you don't wait to long. I lived next to Italy for 15 years. The food is good while not really Italian for some meal (bruschetta is not some hard bread with a few tomatoes). Good Mozzarella. Carpaccio could have more parmazzano but it's pretty close to the concept. It would be better if a bit more tasty. The place is crowded and not very intimate so I would recomment to go with buddies.
author: Amaury d.

description: Really enjoyed this place.Very good  Italian food. well worth the wait.
author: Howard P.
